Take a long walk through these quite streets, enjoy a tasty coffee and have an italian pizza or spaghetti.........Absolutely worth it.

Place to eat !. If you arrive in Rome, and you want to eat good food at a good price, this is the place ! (preferably, to bypass restaurants downtown where food is not so good and the prices are very high)
Interesting area. We walked all around Rome and thought ths area was the most interesting both aesthetically and historically. Don't forget your walking shoes as there are plenty cobblestones.

Vibrant, bohemian neighborhood. We were thrilled to find ourselves strolling the streets of Trastevere not once, but twice in the evenings of our trip to Rome. Every turn revealed a diverse mix of restaurants, vendors, entertainers, and history which provided a wealth of character and ambience to a city that is dominated by awe-inspiring ancient history. We enjoyed dinners and drinks at several restaurants in our time in the area and loved the bustling, energetic vibe of the region. If you like an energetic, eclectic environment, you must spend at least one evening exploring Trastevere.

Fun!. Had dinner outside while watching a huge tv screen being set up with music by Super Tramp and kids dancing. Sapore di Roma menu with delicious v fries, veal in sage leaves, macaroni, salad and tiramisu. Lovely neighborhood.

So. Much. Graffiti! . Trastevere reminds of what the NYC subways looked like in the 70s. I was shocked to find the neighborhood completely riddled with graffiti. It's awful. Truly disappointing. There is so much charm and beauty hidden beneath all the spray paint. Unfortunate.

Authentic Neighborhood. We used the Rick Steves map and self-guided tour and ended our evening at an awesome restaurant in the neighborhood...which we researched on Trip Advisor in advance...Da Enzo Al 29. Lovely walk followed by incredible dinner...we even sat beside Richard Chamberlain!!! And I am NOT kidding!

Unique. Trastevere is a funky, unique enclave just across the Tiber river from the heart of Rome. We found it to be the perfect area to stay, as it's an easy walk to many of the major Roman sites. Great restaurants, and of course, plenty of gelato!
Quaint area. Good place to find restaurants! Be sure to ask directions as we walked a ways before finally stumbling upon the restaurant area?

Wouldn't stay anywhere else in Rome!. This is where I prefer to stay in Rome. A short walk across the Tiber and you're at Victor Emmanuel. Convenient location but out of all the noise and traffic of the city. Trastevere is like a little village inside Rome. Great food and shopping.
Great Place to be. Trastevere is the old part of Rome, it has great character. You find street performers and loads of restaurants. Best to visit in the evening.

Stuck in the eighties. Somehow most of Trastevere missed passing into the next century so the main streets and the place around Santa Maria in Trastevere are sort of an open air museum of 1980s outdoor live with a lot of tourists consuming self-made jewelery, soft ice-cream, pizza, beer or Lambrusco (where else is that still served from bottles coverd in bast fiber?). If you feel nostalgic, have a look! If you happen to be in this area and are less retrospective, try out the small side streets, there are some really interesting ice-cream shops experimenting with organic icecream or special origin choclates and some good bars too, for example Akbar at Piazza di Piscinula with a very interesting interior, a nice menu selection and really good music.

Medieval streets and churches littered with restaurants. Trastevere is Rome's 'other' centre. Not an alternative to the usual tourist attractions but complimentary to the history of this amazing city. Cross the bridge over the island and spend a day touring the medieval narrow streets. Stop at the Church of St Cecilia with all its pale pink and cream beauty. Buy freshly baked biscuits from the family run bakery, now in its 4th generation, Innocenti in Via Della Luce. Take a glass of rose in the Piazza Santa Maria after looking at the church of the same name. Dinner at one of the many restaurants.

Can't really miss that. This is where the magic happens. Here you will find the true Roma by day and all the nightlife you want by night. Also, it is an intricated and interesting place to take a stroll.

Fun place to visit. It's a nice area just over the river from the 'main' part of Rome. There are plenty of bars and places to eat and it has a different feel from other parts of the city. Worth a wander through for a drink and something to eat. A fun place.

Great variety of eating choices and very active evening activities. We liked trastevere due to its wide variety of restaurants, most with out door seating , that allowed you to feel you were part of the activity surrounding you. There was a positive , friendly ambiance , throughout the area. Whiler we were a couple, a person traveling alone, would feel comfortable walking among the many small crowded streets lined pn bothnsides buy restaurants with the out door seating. Om most evenings we engaged in conversations with fellow travelers from many countries ( Italy, Spain , Mexico, Sweden, Germany, and a few others). The outdoor seating in the restaurants was very close throughout the area ( Probably can check out youtube for some examples). Many small piazzas with entertainers each night and tons of Gelato stores.
The heart of Rome!. Some call it the "food district of Rome", but here lies what "romanity" means. Don't forget to pass by. In company or alone, you will breath the essence of the Eternal City.
a nice walk!. it is a very beautiful area with many things to see and many restaurants to have lunch or dinner.i think it is better to visit trastevere in spring.it reminds me a greek island,Corfu.
Loved the area. Lots of nice shops, bars and restaurants around here worth walking through to soak it all in, and lots of nice little lanes

Take the time to wander the streets of Trastevere . Get away from the crowds and wander through Trastevere. Plenty of reasonably priced cafes and restaurants. This is where you experience the casual side of Roma.

Get lost here!. If you do happen to get lost here, dont fret. There are hundreds of lovely restaurants to dine at and they are friendly enough to help. We planned to visit Trastavere, maybe lost our way slightly but were pleasantly suprised with what we found.Sone tiny curvy streets with hard to read signage does make it hard to navigate.
It's pleasant, gets busy later. Worth a look and a meal. Has a nice vibe and a nice walk across the bridge. Check the restaurants on TA because there is huge variation.
A very interesting area of Rome. We downloaded Rick Steve's Audio Guide of Europe and did a self guided tour through this area. With his commentary it was a good way to explore out of the way places.

A nice walk from Vatican.. We walk along the river side and entered the district. It is like taking a trip to the country side. First, we came across church S. Maria de Scala, a beautiful place to absorp tranquility and recharge, then had lunch at one of many local restaurants. Then we walk across the bridge Ponte Garibaldi to the city. Wow, the scenery of the river and the little island is amazing.

Great neighborhood in Rome. I would consider this one of the most beautiful sections on Rome. From cobblestone streets to its churches, and the many cafes. This is a must-see place. Marvel at the Piazza Santa Maria.

Enjoyable Day and Night. As mentioned countless times before, the neighborhood is a vibrant and lively area both day and night. A daytime stroll offers the opportunity to walk along the Tiber and up through small and winding streets with great architectural charm. At night you have several choices for dining and entertainment. We found it to be a nice afternoon activity following a busy morning / early afternoon visiting the Vatican Museum

So romantic at night. I love trastevere. This area is so romantic. There is a large british community living here, the atmosphere is magic and typical. I suggest a walk around and dinner followed by a walk on the river for a cocktail or a grattachecca (typical roman dessert made of ice and juices)

Not what it used to be. This area has a history of being a hangout for students and not all that busy. Well, the secrets' out and it's packed with tourists looking for cheap eats. Too late. It's hard to find the pizzerias that will sell you a slice on a piece of paper because it’s been taken over by bistrots, trattoria and hostaria like what's found in the rest of Rome and they're not cheap anymore! That's if you can get a table. If you're looking for the old Trastevere, you won't find it!

Like being in an Italian movie. Amazing place to walk around, narrow streets, beautiful buildings with flowers on the walls, cosy small bars and restaurants. Amazing street art and graffiti everywhere. At night every square becomes a venue for people drinking beer outside, usually with a street musician playing on the side. Perfect place for an aperitivo, without fancy attitude. True Roman spirit.
The beating heart of Rome. Trastevere is teaming with a lovely mix of locals and tourist enjoying the tangled narrow streets, the fine cafes, and one of a kind shops.
Old city. I loved walking down the streets of this location, a walk back in time, but make sure you read up on the history of the area so it makes the trip worth it.

Favorite Nighborhood. I stayed in Piazza Bella. My flat was picked because it had the Italian feel we wanted. The Piazza has many quaint eateries that we found to be very enjoyable...would stay again in a heartbeat. Was close to all we wanted to do. Loved walking the cobblestone streets. I shoot photo's and taking photo's of everything we enjoyed was a absolute must.
One of the Best Areas in Rome. We loved Trastevere for the restaurants, the energy of the place and the wonderful boutiques. This was a highlight of the trip to Rome.
Lovely neighborhood. We had a delightful time just wandering this neighborhood. It would be a great place to wander and stumble upon some wonderful eatery.
Nice Neighborhood. Great place to stay. Just across the Tiber from most of the great landmarks of Rome. Vibrant neighborhood; attractive and safe.

Loved this area!. Trastevere is one of those areas in Rome that I felt was amazing and an area I will need to continue exploring next time I visit Rome. Packed with small streets filled with restaurants and places to enjoy. If you visit Rome, then Trastevere is a good choice for food and entertainment.
Gorgeous part of Rome. You must visit this part pf Rome. Safe cool and interesting. Will stay in this area when i return to Rome and hope that is very soon.

Terrific little area. An area characterised by lots of lovely buildings, interspersed with great little restaurants & interesting shops. It's perhaps too much on the tourist path, but hey this is Rome, and what isn't touristy! Go there, you'll enjoy it, just wandering around, looking at all the great buildings.

Super Location. My wife and I stayed 5 nights at Casa Mia which is 12 rooms on two floors above their excellent restaurant. Simple, new, dbl room with windows overlooking the small plaza provided lots of entertainment - viewing of the crazy local traffic, daily smell of La Renella bakery, place to dry our laundry and watching the people come and go. Cabot University and Beige bar were active late at night but the noise was manageable even with our windows open (except Sat). We are in our 60's and had no issues with walking everywhere in Rome. Admittedly a daily siesta during the heat at midday helped. Local eateries are abundant, food fantastic and people friendly. A must stop is Casa Mia for the food, staff svc, hotel accomodations, Aperol spritz and LAa Renella for take out bread, sheets of different flavored pizza (more like flat bread) and pastries.This is the place to be in Roma.

Village feeling. I've been to Rome many times on business and have always heard that Trastevere was a wonderful, quaint neighborhood that was a "must visit". I finally had the opportunity to spend several days there. It is true, that as far as Rome goes, this is a little bit of village atmosphere a stone's throw from the center of Rome. However, if you have the chance, go and discover other parts of Italy that are many times more charming. The hill towns of Umbria and Tuscany offer much more charm. For me, Rome is all about the big sights, the cultural aspects of Rome as a ruling power. Whether is it the Forum, the Coloseum, the Trevi fountain etc. etc. etc. These, and all the other great historic landmarks are why you go to Rome. I wouldn't waste a day on Trastevere when you can have an expresso in Piazza Navona or a granita de cafe in Piazza del Poppolo or hang out on the Spanish steps and people watch. There are so many great things in Rome to see and do. If you want Italian charm - head to Positano or Montepulciano, go to the Cinque Terra or the many wonderful places on the Adriatic Coast. Rome is Rome - drink it in. Find your charm elsewhere.

Must see area of Rome. This is a very busy are of Rome, the nightlife is lively, traffic and people all over the place, shops open til wee hours, many, many restaurants of all kinds, must see to get to know the real Romans

Not to be missed. My wife and I enjoyed very much Trastevere both in the day time as well as the evening. The whole place is one where you need to walk around and enjoy the scenery as well as atmosphere. Very picturesque and quaint.Lovely bars and restaru

Beautiful alleys and streets. We were told by our host about this area of Rome, so pleased he mentioned it as it is absolutely fabulous, restaurants bars, shops, and quaint streets at every turn, highly recommended.

Feels like Italy. This area makes you feel like you are really in Italy. Less crowded, narrow streets, quaint shops and restaurants. You feel like you are in a totally different part of Rome, away from the hustle and bustle of all the tourist spots. Take time to eat at one of the restaurant with outside seating and enjoy a laid back Italian day.
Site seeing in Rome. This area of Rome is a hidden gem with narrow streets numerous restaurants and in the evening lots of stalls selling their wares.

Amazing place. This really is such a special place. Really lovely streets and restaurant and one of my favourite place in Rome. Had such lovely authentic food and happy friendly people. Well worth a night out here
Nice neighborhood with one of the oldest churches. This is a cozy neighborhood to stroll around. We still found it too touristic. Some told us that Santa Maria church here is the oldest in Rome.
Wonderful place to walk. Just what you think of when you think of meandering through Rome. Lots of neat shops and lots and lots of places to eat! Beautiful.

Best evening of the trip worth a visit. Found this area in rough guide to Rome. It's worth the trip over the Tiber. Go in the evening it's buzzing with street sellers, entertainers and lots of wonderful cafes/bars and restaurants in the winding cobbled streets. Once darkness falls Santa Maria de Trastevere is lit up and very picturesque. Best meal of the holiday.

Charming area. This was my 5th visit to Rome and I hadn't even heard of this area before. We booked a gourmet walking tour and it was all around this beautiful area. There are lots of amazing places to eat, and a lively evening atmosphere
A Lovely Stroll. A lovely stroll along ancient streets during the day with restaurants tucked in here and there. At night it becomes the club scene.

Great area to visit and chill out. Wonderful old town that you can either walk to or take the tram from Venizia over the river. (Get off just over the river and wonder down into the old town). Lots of local clothes and craft shops, and more bars and trattoria's than you would ever need. Visit the church at Santa Maria de Trastavere which is an absolute gem.
Love Trastevere. This was our favourite area for eating, wandering around, watching life all around! Although busy, it feels less touristy than the very centre of Rome.
Exactly what you picture.... ...when you imagine walking streets in Italy. This is a lovely area to shop, eat, and people watch. Beautiful.

The best place for nightlife. This place has some of the best bars in all of Rome and certainly the narrow cobbled streets take you back in time while downing a few drinks. The evenings in the square is something to remember.

AMAZING! Must visit!. If you are in Rome you MUST visit Trastavere at night. It has a lot of nice restaurants, gelato places and creative souvenir shops. Very lively at night with musical and/or street fire performances!

Still my favorite part of Rome to stay!. If you are burdened by a car in Rome, skip Trastavere.
If you are smart enough to be on foot, this is a fantastic location to start from. Doesn't really come alive till 7 or 8, then stays hopping till at least 12 or 1. Later, you'd have to ask someone else!

Amazing area. This is what Rome is all about - small narrow streets teeming with cafes, restaurants and bars. Although it is quite touristy you can still find a good meal and lovely atmosphere with international travelers from all over the world. I wouldn't think of staying anywhere else in Rome.

Charming area to stay. We stayed in a hotel in this area of Rome and always enjoyed meandering around the tiny streets with it's busy bars and restaurants, narrow lanes, churches. It's real life around you - washing hanging out of higgledy piggledy houses always made me smile, especially old bloomers and long johns :-)

where you feel the vibe of the city. If I tell you that every tourist will eventually pass by this street, it wouldn't be an exaggeration. It is busy and cosy at the same time. There are all kinds of restaurants are there on the street.

Like a movie. Such a pitoresque and lovely neighbourhood!
I recommend you explore the hidden streets, drink a cappuccino al fresco and just enjoy.
Great food, lots to see. Loved this area of rome, had a couple of very good meals here. Would recommend wandering around for a couple of hours.

My Kind of 'Hood. Of the 5 days we spent in Rome.......we wandered through Trastevere part of 2 of those days. We were staying in an ap't on Via Giulia and since my NEW thought is to return and spend a month or two in Rome wandering......I would definitely consider this neighborhood.The connection was great.......for a bit more solitude and local color......and the restaurants and market.
FOOD TOUR in TRASTEVERE. So cool!!! We walked in Trastevere a lot...so amazing, don't miss the opportunity to enjoy a corner of Rome that is incredibly charming!

Best area in Rome to have dinner. Trastevere is a small neighbourhood full of small restaurants, wine bars and taverns (Osteria). The best place for you to head by the end of the day. You can have a seat and enjoy Rome's great typical dishes.
Awesome neighborhood in Rome. Take time out from the touristy things to visit this awesome off-the-beaten-path neighborhood! Colorful, friendly, charming.. Go!

Unique Lively Neighbourhood!. I loved my visit to Trastevere. I went around 7.30pm to eat pizza at a local joint. The area really comes alive as the night sets in. The beautiful alleys, the mix of local and tourists, and the little restaurants really add character to this place. I wish I had more time. I would love to return here one day!
The old working mans area of the city. A poorer area of the town but still beautiful with many buildings and houses and cobbled lanes. A trendy area with food outlets now and street entertainers.

Beautiful area across the river. We stayed in the city center of the Jewish Ghetto but, our favorite places to eat and wander were in Trastevere. We found the food more reasonable and of better quality in this area. There are so many little back streets and hidden gems to be discovered without the street peddlers and crowds. It will definitely be remembered as the more slow paced and romantic area with great fondness by me and my family.
History. We love just walking the small and winding streets of Trastevere. You never know where you'll come out and it's always fun to explore.

My favorite part of Roma. "truh-STEV-⟨r⟩ay"Studying abroad at JCU, Trastevere has been my home for the month of June.I've fallen in love with the neighborhood atmosphere and laid back nature of this portion of Rome. With a MAXIMUM 20-30 minute walk to most of the big attractions (Colosseum, Vatican City, Trevi Fountain, Pantheon, Roman Forum, Palentine Hill, and more) it was secluded enough to not have a high tourist traffic area and still seem quaint. There's plenty of restaurants (many family owned and operated) and charming street art fills the walls around Trastevere. If in Roma for a few short days, you might consider housing closer to the main attractions. However, if you have a week or more in Roma, I would recommend Trastevere.
Upbeat neighborhood. Lively neighborhood with beautiful spots everywhere. Fun happy hour bars, wineries, piazza with street performers! Entertaining for all ages
Must food visit. This is for Italians and tourists who know where to look for great food, great price and a lively evening. Just wished I had known earlier instead of the end of my trip
A quaint neighborhood in Rome.. Get lost in Trastevere! Wander down little streets and explore and then you will be closer to finding out the real character of this ancient neighborhood.

Great location to visit or stay. We stayed in an apartment in this district for 5 nights.It was an excellent location for visitting all the sights. We walked everywhere (although we took a taxi to Termini with luggage to leave) The area closest to Ponte Sisto was very busy and hectic with nightlife, but it was all much quieter to the east of Sydney Sonnino. Plenty of places to eat all around.
Wander around. A lovely area allows you to soak up the residential areas and their winding streets. Some lovely restaurants. Worth exploring so set some time aside.
Great for Food. We were fortunate to spend a month in this area in 2007. We returned last month and it was just as good. Old, authentic and full of great places to hit.
MUST SEE NEIGHBORHOOD!. We went as a group of 13 for a walking tour of this neighborhood and then had dinner there. Very very nice. Do this tour. It's a fabulous neighborhood!

Visited for a meal. We visited here for a meal after being recommended by our hotel staff. We caught a bus from outside Termini that took us straight to the area.There are lots of restaurants to choose from and the area seems less touristy than other parts of Rome.

Nice neighborhood. We enjoyed walking through Trastevere in the evening and stopped into a restaurant for dinner. Lots of trees everywhere, which made it nicer than many other Rome neighborhoods. Plenty of good restaurants and shops. Fun to walk across the bridge from Isola Tiberina.

We did not want to leave!. We stayed in Trastevere for 10 days and it was so much fun! Rich with cafes, eateries, shops, bars, nightlife and culture! We were walking distance from many attractions and public transport was so convenient! We will definitely stay in Trastevere again!!

Seemed like more food options than shopping. We went during the day to do some shopping as we read this was a great area to shop in. We walked up and down the streets for about 2 hours and didn't find much outside of restaurants so we left and went back across the river to shop. Just wanted to add a shopping comment as people are looking for day options to explore the outer part of Rome.
Busy. Student area open all night offering cheap food and drink. Very lively. Great for people looking for fun. Some interesting history but very crowded especially at night.

Rome like the Romans do. Visit during the day for cute shops and cheap coffee, before climbing Romes 8th hill for incredible city views. Stay in the evening for a plethora of restaurants filled with Rome residents and then live out the evening at one of the many bars. It's a busy place, for good reason. Soak in its unique atmosphere and live like a real Roman.

Great Atmosphere. I would go back again...and again.. We really enjoyed wandering around Trastevere. We specifically went there to visit the church of Santa Cecelia (which was worth the visit). We then wandered the streets and chose an outdoor restaurant for dinner. Afterwards, we wandered the winding streets and took and took in the sights, stopping at a small bakery, which was crammed full of great snacks and desserts. We enjoyed it enough that we went back a second time and chose a different restaurant the next night. The area is well-lit after dark, and has a lot of foot traffic, so you feel entirely safe.We will always look back on the evenings in Trastevere with good feelings. Our hotel was on Via Giulia, in the heart of Rome, so this was only about 15 -20 minute walk. It would be about the same from the area around the Pantheon and Piazza Navona. It is just a hop, skip and a jump from Campo de Fiore.

This is where modern Romans come to relax and play. If you have never thought of crossing the river while staying in Rome you are in for a pleasant surprise. Still just a little off the beaten path this neighbourhood in Rome is a great place to spend an afternoon wandering around relaxing, eating and recharging with locals. Lots of restaurants serving classic Italian food, give yourself at least 3 - 4 hours to stroll around. Access this area by Tram 3 or 3B (tram ->bus combo) or tram 8 (easier).

Lively, warm and pleasant.. Me and my little family kept on ending up here during our one week in Rome. Got a few slices of pizza at La Bocacchia and enjoyed people watching at the piazza by St.Maria's church. Always some entertainers around, like street musicians and artists, or bubble makers for the kids. The St.Maria church is also well worth a visit. Beautiful golden tiles and a serene atmosphere. Sure, it is a tourist magnet (and we're usually more in to "off the beaten track" kind of places) bumped in to a lot of people of my own nationality. But is still a charming area that has a genuine feeling to it.

Beautiful. Exactly hat you have in mind when you think of Italian lifestyle !!. Stunning narrow streets, nice restaurants, and music everywhere it definitely is the place to visit when in Rome. It felt like a little holiday in our holidays. Absolutely loved the vibe and had the best pizzas !!

One of the most typical districts of Rome. Nice location to spend a day or an evening. We spent the evening there two days in a row, enjoying a Spritz on a terrasse and having diner in one of the restaurant. Really nice

I wished I lived here. What a great neighborhood - restaurants, wine bars and more. You could spend an afternoon and evening here and walking no more than 5 minutes in any direction and have a great meal, drinks and a lively environment. Do yourself a favor when visiting Rome, get away from the noted tourist sites for part of a day and cross the Tiber to this wonderful enclave - you will not be disappointed.

Family stays in Trastevere -. My family and I recently stayed in three different apartments in Trastevere and were delighted with the neighborhoods. Each had its own terrific coffee bar/market/pizza places and delightful shoppes. I would definitely visit this area again!

Charming and a nice pocket of calm in busy Roma on a Saturday morning. We walked across the bridge before ten a.m. on a hot Saturday, just to take a look around. No real plan, and we found ourselves charmed by the quiet, tourist-free streets and interesting nooks and crannies we found as we walked around for a couple of hours... There were lots of restaurants and bars, but all we tried was a quick organic (bio) espresso and bottled water when we stopped in a little shop for a few minutes. The owner was very friendly and told us that what we were seeing was because it was early and that the tourists and busy-ness comes later in the day... and that the nightlife was very very busy. Not our scene, so we wandered a little further, ran into a band practicing (beautifully) a few blocks 'in' to the neighbourhood and then to Santa Maria Capella, and ancient church consecrated in 1090. Only €5 each to enter and we had the both the ancient church and it's in-progress excavation and relics to ourselves. Most everything there is in Italian, so bring a friend or a guidebook if you want to translate as you're viewing the relics.Finally, completely unexpected and very moving and sad, were the three cobblestones that had been replaced by bronze markers remembering three people in one home who had been taken to Auschwitz. As sad as that was, it was a beautiful and everlasting tribute to two elderly people and one young man who were victims of the holocaust atrocities. It was a memorable two hours, wandering alleys and back streets in a most ancient part of the ancient city of Roma

Fun to explore. A man at the hotel recommended this area
Fun to wander through and such quaint little roads (although alleyways are probably more of an apt label!)
Lovely restaurants, cafes etc as well as churches
Worth a stroll through and cheaper to eat here than other main attractions!

A great place to wander!. We just jumped off a trolley in Trastevere with no specific plans - and loved it! Just a down-to-earth shady Italian area, a surprise around every corner! We had a four year old with us and stumbled upon a neighborhood park with play equipment. We got to mingle with Italian families, though we can barely speak the language, they were all very friendly and many wanted to practice their English. We found a great gelato cafe with good bathrooms, and for dinner we found a gem called Poppi's. Excellent food, reasonably priced, great ambiance with the checkered tablecloths, etc - but not a tourist trap! We came too early (5:30 pm - Italians rarely eat before 7pm) but they accommodated us anyway. We loved just wandering around - we only wished we had more time to explore.
Beautiful architecture. The architecture again is amazing as most of the ruins around Rome are. This little village has narrow lanes You can get good views of the Tiber river as well.

Definitely check this area out.. Took the bus to the Trastevere area at the advice of a local. Thoroughly enjoyed walking around the small streets. Stopped and had some excellent gelato. Many restaurants/bars-wish we hadn't eaten right before we went there! If I get back to Italy it will definitely be on my list of areas to re-visit.
Lovely area. I loved this area in Rome. It has a great vibe with it's intricate streets and piazzas, quaint shops and great restaurants, Visit at night time, it's the best.

Great for exploring. Loved, loved, loved this area! Felt like there was something new to discover at every turn. This is the perfect area to really just explore and see where it takes you. Don't have a plan, just go with it.

Quaint neighborhood with great restaurants.. The area is fun to explore. It is fairly quiet but still enough going on to make it fun. Great place to stay while in Rome and within tram and walking distance of many of the major sights.

Authentic neighborhood. This neighborhood is on the other side of the Tiber River. There are very good restaurants, a wonderful bakery and churches to visit here. I like the feel of this area and if I were to live in Rome, this may be the area I would choose - far fewer tourists.

Walking tour!. Went on a walking and eating tour of the area, and it was amazing. Really great tour guide who gave us food from many different restaurants, as well as a great overview of the history of the area. Definitely would recommend a visit, but would be better if you went on a tour.

This place has soul.. Great restaurants, cafes, interesting little shops, beautiful cobbled streets, away from all the traffic. I love this place. It's really quaint. Get lost in all the alley ways. I felt totally at home here. Quick access via the walking bridges and you are in Rome city. The Vatican City is only about 15-20min walk. Centrally located you can go from here and see just about everything you want to by foot or tram or bus. There is enough local people living here too to give you a nice homely feeling. We felt totally safe wandering around the streets at night, there are enough people around. Use common sense (as you should with all your travels) when walking around.
Recommended by Tour Guide. Love this place. It is off the beaten path, so not many tourists. You can get the real flavor of Rome here.
Charming. This neighborhood has so much charm to it. If you have some time, walk over the bridge (s) and check out this area. Nice restaurants, bars, cafes, etc

Did not feel safe in the evenings.. Visited in the evening. Quite dark and did not feel safe as there is no one around and its easy to get lost. Had some (poor quality overpriced) dinner. May have been better planned by ourselves in advance so visit in the day time. Poor transport unless you know the trans.

I love it. We stayed there for 6 days and I love the borough. Casa Mia in Trastevere is a beautiful, peaceful and comfortable hotel. Owners are wonderful, Claudia and her husband but also the people working in the hotel and in the restaurant,great people, great job...

Interesting Area. It was interesting to walk through Trastevere and see how the neighborhood is being transformed, but I did not find it as charming as other areas in Rome. To me, it had a touristy feel with lots of street wares for sale as your walk the bridge and enter the area and graffiti interspersed on the sides of some of the buildings.

Put on Your Walking Shoes. If you have spent enough time in Rome to see all the Big Attractions, take a day to wander the streets of the Trastevere Neighborhood. We started at Isola Tiberrina to cross the river and wandered the little streets filled with small restaurants and quaint buildings. We visited the Basilica de Santa Maria, a beautiful church in a lovely square. From there we climbed the steep streets to Janiculum Hill were we found fountains, a beautiful park, and beautiful views of Rome. We followed Via Garibaldi almost to the Vatican. At this point we walked down narrow streets of steps and back to the river.

Everyone says this is the real Rome. It is. The restaurants are full of Romans, there are street performers everywhere and it doesn't feel like you are surrounded by hoards of tourists following a tour guide's flag.

Great time . We went to this area twice. Trastevere was very chill. Had a few different places to choose from and of course plenty for drink options. We had some very nice beers and chatted with some cool locals. Def recommend this area to chill and drink a few. Love that there's no laws about drinking in the streets. Saluti

Very cool, hip neighborhood!. Our teenage daughters suggested we go for dinner and drinks to the "Ghetto" as its called. Very cool area with many bars and nightlife. Streets are full of people with vendors selling jewlery and sunglasses at night. A lot of college kids in this area.
Amazing place - so beautiful and charming. Amazing place - so beautiful and charming, i don't see enithing so magnificent. Recommend for all - it's like a real old century pace where you live in.

Rustic, Authentic and Village-Like. I loved Trastevere!.. It felt really authentic....It felt like the East Village in NYC before it became gentrified.... most menus were in italian only :~D good sign of authenticity. We enjoyed browsing, shopping and had an authentic and delicious Italian lunch with champagne on the other side of the Tiber!.. Waiters barely knew any english.. Just the way we like it!
Cosy Roman neighbourhood. Very nice and lively neighbourhood crammed with restaurants. This place might seem less crowded than on the east side of the river.

A different experience. We've stayed in Trastevere twice now, once for three weeks and recently for a week. Both times we rented apartments and "lived" here. This is where the Romans go for an evening out. You have some very interesting churches here, plus windy narrow streets filled with bars, cafes and restaurants. Piazza Santa Maria in Trastevere is a great place to hang out, and gets very active on the weekends. Sit at the fountain and watch the show, or explore the streets for a drink or dinner. If you stay here, you have very easy access to Centro Storico--Campo di Fiori, Piazza Navona, Pantheon, Forum. Easy access to tram and busses. This is a great place to stay for an extended period.

Nice evening walk. We walked over the bridge into this area of Rome. Lots of tiny narrow streets and easy to get lost. We used our map and wandered around. Stopped for dinner and got a feel for a real neighborhood in Rome.
Lively Neighbourhood. There are numerous restaurants, cafes and shops along its narrow streets. We enjoyed our evening having a glass of wine in one of the cafes while watching the world go by.

Do not miss a visit to Trastevere. This is a wonderful area in Rome, easy access, fantastic restaurants and quaint streets and shops that you cannot miss! It is most pleasurable to take a lazy stroll through the cobblestone streets, relax with a glass of wine or enjoy a gelatto.
fun casual place to visit. Visited Sunday moring for the huuuge flea market with some bargains.Lively place at night for dinner I understand.

To much choice. Excellent bustling area full of places to eat really glad we went wish we had checked the area before as we walked around for quite a while trying to find a restaurant hard to choose to much choice almost

Close To Everything. Base yourself in Trastevere and you are within walking distance of many of Rome's major tourist attractions, the Colloseum, Trevi Fountain, Castel Sant Angelo, The Pantheum etc. You will also be in an ancient part of the city, with many photogenic buildings, narrow streets, and picturesque squares full of bars and restaurants. Visit at night and you will find the streets lit up, street performers and stalls selling everything touristy you can imagine. Be aware that the area is very popular so expect crowds. We loved it.
Get lost and enjoy. Narrow cobbled street, hidden restaurants and churches make Trastevere a peaceful change from the bustle of central Rome - the narrow streets also guarantee shade!!

Wonderful neighborhood visit the canal area at night.. Wonderful neighborhood visit the canal area at night and take a stroll. Stop at the many spots for food and drinks. The canal area gets very crowded as the sun goes down because thats when the nite life begins.

The Hipster Neighbourhood. Trastevere is a very lively neighbourhood and no trip to Rome should be considered as complete without a visit. I prefer the evening time when it is all prettily lit up. Plenty of small boutiques, restaurants and street vendors.

Quaint streets. Visit here to get away from the busiest part of Rome. Santa Maria in Trastevere is a must. Beautiful inside during the day and outside at night lit up. Free. Go before 1.00 or after 4.00 pm

Disappointing and dirty. The place was run down and graffiti was everywhere. Had to dodge the beggars and the tramps. Didn't feel safe at all. The church was worth a look. Trastevere is not a place to linger.

A great place for lunch or dinner. We strolled around Trastevere after lunch near Piazza Navona. If I were to plan that day again, I would have had lunch there or gone instead for dinner. It is a charming area of Rome with narrow, cobblestone streets and tons of cafes and restaurants. A great place to bring older children as Tratavere is bustling with activity and filled with those in their 20s and 30s.

Touristy and crowded. Everyone just has to go there once to eat. It's got places where a meal on a budget can be had and there are roadside cafes and pizzerias full of tourists. Food may not be great.
The other side of the Tiber. Excellent people watching... Young musicians on the bridge..,. Great food stops.... Excellent Bacala a must..,,
Great for foodies!. Very nice places to eat, away from the tourist places, not expensive and really tasty - go there for seafood

Best places to eat at reasonable prices. Just like the guide books said, it's narrow streets and eating houses are just the thing for tourists. Walk over or get a cheap tram and grab lunch or spend the evening. For people watching I recommend Sundays when it gets very busy but bustling and lively.

Good fun. We had an apartment in N Trastevere for 5 days, complete with roof terrace, and loved being based there. It's easy from Fiumicino airport - just get a stopping train to Trastevere station for €8 then, having bought your transport pass, a no8 tram to Belli or so. It was crammed with tourists and locals Saturday night but not too crowded other times. There are lots of little streets with bars and restaurants to wander round. Transport is not great but the no8 tram is a good start. It's also got a totally dysfunctional rubbish collection system - leave this out on Wednesday, that out on Friday etc. Utterly impractical for tourists so there is a fair bit of random dumping of rubbish. Other areas of Rome do it better, with rubbish and recycling bins in the streets. But we did enjoy the area. To the North is the charming Botanical Gardens and at the South end are some particularly good restaurants, some of them very reasonably priced too.

Trastevere - Slice of Rome away from Tourism. We stayed in Trastevere (apartment booked on VRBO for four nights. You can take public transportation, taxis, or walk to all major tourist attractions. We did all of the major tourist sites for three days, but came back to Trastevere in the evenings and enjoyed the night life and restaurants away from the many tourists in the heart of Rome. Highly recommend staying in this area if you visit Rome.

Lovely neighborhood. We spend a day exploring the quieter streets of Trastevere. Found a great, casual lunch spot. Afterwards we walked up to Fontana dell'Acqua Paola for a fantastic view of Rome. Trastevere was a nice break from the more touristy central neighborhoods. We heard it has fun late night, clubs but not quite our scene.

Stroll these little streets. Located across the Tiber River from Testaccio is Trastevere. Stroll through all of the little streets and alleys, finding wonderful cafes, restaurants, bars, and lots of local charm. This cobblestone-filled area is popular with expats.
Quiet. A quiet, mostly residential neighborhood on the other side of teh Tiber (but the same side as the Vatican). Stroll around. Good eats.

Very lively place. We had our hotel in Trastevere. This is a great place if you like some entertainment on the streets. The nice small streets offer so much to see, many great shops, cafes, restaurants. In the evening and at nighttime there are many people standing on the streets, drinking beer and chatting. Great atmosphere. Very close to all the sights. You can walk everywhere.

Close to all the attractions and a lot cheaper. Just a 10 minute walk from the vatican along and across the river and loads cheaper . The bars and restaurants are lively and again much cheaper than central Rome .

Small gates, charming shops in a typical italian neighborhood. In Trastevere everything is possible. To eat wonderful food, to let you get trapt in that italian atmosphere that made this place famous. Don't miss the Basílica di Santa Maria !

Cosy and romantic atmosphere. It was a very romantic area with loads of restaurants and bars, a bit to touristic in some parts but well Worth a visit. Generally better prices on food and drinks than closer to the"centre"

Lovely part of Rome. I really loved Trastevere.It's a lively, buzzing part of Rome with a lot to offer.There are small shops, nice restaurants and good street musicians around every corner.In the evening it's the best place for a romantic dinner in one of the small, family owned restaurants.This part of Rome is not as old as the "roman" part of the city, and therefor it has a more "medieval" flair and I enjoyed every minute there.There's also a nice botanical garden, which I did not visit myself since it was closed, but looked really nice from the outside.If you have the chance, combine this with a visit to the Colle del Gianicolo, where you'll have a fantastic view over the eternal city!

The Real Rome. A beautiful part of the city with lovely winding streets and super restaurants to eat at. There are lots of individual shops to wander in and out of at your leisure. This part of Rome is calmer and more relaxed.

Loved this neighborhood. I had read so much about this area that we went there on our first night in Rome. It was just lovely. The juxtaposition of old buildings, street art, and greenery was amazing.

Home of Food. We journeyed to this area for food and a night out and had a blast.
Worth scheduling in some time and use Trip Advisor to find some great restaurants!
Lively buzzing atmosphere. Lots of great restaurants used by locals. Of course lots of churches but the whole area is full of life. We ate there 3/4 of our nights in Rome.

You weren't there? Pitty!. Wonderful part of Roma nobody should skip! We were really surprised what a lovely spot we found. Narrow street full of life, bars, restaurants, people, art, sun, flowers, ... Really enjoyable.
Lovely place to dine. If we wanted to grab some diner we came here. A variety of styles, the traditional Italian and casual bars were our favorites.

A Rambling array of streets and shops. This is the artisan area of Rome, there are numerous restaurants cafes and shops along its narrow cobble streets. It makes an interesting and clam escape for the insanity that is Rome!

Loved, loved, loved Trastevere!!!. We were so lucky to have decided to rent an apartment in Trastavere. It is part of ancient Rome. Still quaint with cobble stone streets, vines crawling up the fronts of apartments with balconies full of flowers and laundry hanging from lines hung between window ledges. By day it is quiet and in the evening the doors open, wonderful outdoor patio restaurants are set out and the smells of delicious food fills the air. Other than being romantic having friendly people and great food Trastevere is close by bus or taxi to all the sights of Rome. I would never stay anywhere else in Rome!

Perfect base. Loved Trastevere. A great location within walking distance to all main attractions. Great atmosphere with lots of picturesque bars and restaurants, lovely old buildings and the wonderful Santa Maria church, well worth a visit. It has a wonderful atmosphere, both day and night with many musicians and street performers adding to the vibe.

A quieter side of Rome. We got the metro to Circus Maximus and the walked to Trastevere across one of the bridges (getting a good view of the ruins of an ancient Roman bridge on the way). The streets of Trastevere were lovely to walk around, we stopped at a small cafe for a bite to eat, the wound our way through more small streets and visited the church (Basilica of Our Lady in Trastevere) which was well worth a look around. All in all a pleasant way to spend the day.

Sunday market in Trastevere. A view bus stops from the Colloseum take you to the neighborhood of Trastevere. Just over the bridge on Sunday mornings is the greatest largest flea market. Bring a backpack or rolling suitcase for the great deals...leather, scarves, clothing, trinkets....

A different side of Rome. We walked here to spend the evening here after a hectic afternoon visiting the Vatican. We really enjoyed our evening here sitting having a glass of wine before watching the world go by before having a nice bite to eat in one of the many restaurants.
We really enjoyed this area very informal and a perfect end to our day.

Good Neighbourhood. Stayed in a hotel here for 4 days. Is a lovely neighbourhood with everything really closeWe were told to get the metro to places we wanted to visit (Colosseum/Vatican) but these are surprisingly close so we walked.A few little shops close by just for buying a few bits and pieces. Plenty of restaurants and cafes to choose from and lots of gelatories too!Just be careful trying to cross roads!
Great community for a stroll. We walked through this section of Rome and really enjoyed the typical neighborhoods and daily activities going on, there are plenty of cafes to stop by for a beverage.

Great Area. Surprised by the quiet and almost separate feel this area of Rome has from the hustle and bustle of the classic area and the main attractions. You could be in a Garda lake town with the colourful buildings, small squares and pretty churches. Will come back here to explore further and provide some reflective contrast to the rest of a vibrant Rome

Beautiful, tacky, charming, touristy -- a fascinating mess!. First off, do not believe the Trastevere is "undiscovered." While certainly not as trampled as, say, Vatican City, this area is very, very touristy. But yes, it does feel remarkably like a small Italian town far, far outside Rome. Narrow streets, small buildings, and flashes of remarkable charm make up for the noise and the crowds. And look sharp-- small shops offering remarkable hand made goods can be found amid the souvenir stands. Art lovers: find the Church of Saint Cecilia and go beneath it to the crypt! Absolutely beautiful and you'll have it all to yourselves.

We always return to Trastevere.. We use an apartment in Trastevere when we visit Rome because either day or night it has a magical atmosphere all the time. It is clean and we feel safe wherever we are in the area.The Santa Maria Piazza is amazing and has entertainment most afternoons. I thought I was listening to Dire Straits one Saturday afternoon . There was a crowd of very happy people sitting in the cafes and around the fountain. Wonderful Rome!Shopping is great too.

Medieval streets, great cafes and restaurants. This is, among other things, Rome's answer to the Latin Quarter in Paris and Greenwich Village in New York. I've gotta say this: Rome wins. Trastevere is fascinating at any hour. It's a maze of narrow streets lined with medieval houses (some of which look like they were renovated very thoroughly in the 19th Century). The Romanesque church in the main square (okay, piazza) is very quaint. The locals are friendly and helpful, as are some of the tourists. If you really wish to be impressed from the start, cross over by way of the Ponte Sisto. Cross the quay, enter the little plaza, and turn left. It'll take your breath away.

Overadvertised. It's nice, yet one can find more impressive and authentic places in "mainland" Rome - quiet (or lively) curved streets, eateries of all kinds, churches, etc.It's a very "touristic" - once there I had a feeling that it was "created" for tourists. That said, there are probably more tourist traps there than in other parts of Rome.If you have several days in Rome, you should probably allocate your time for Trastevere (you'll possibly like it as most reviewers do), yet if you have just 1-2 days - don't waste it there.

Beautiful, narrow streets, nice reastaurants. This part of Rome is a nice area of true Italian style with narrow streets and places to eat and drink. Nice walking area with low or no traffic, moderately crowded (at least in May).

A beautiful and quaint city within a cort. After a day of sightseeing in the big city, we wondered along the water to Trastevere. The area is much more charming and interesting than the main core. Great little shops and restos everywhere and many great photo opportunities.
A buzzing atmosphere. Full of bars, restaurants and gelatarias. A good buzzing atmosphere. Great place to people watch. Market stalls and street performers are there during the day and night.

THE Trastevere. Trastevere is a quaint neighborhood of the city. If you cannot / do not want to stay here, certainly it worths a visit. At night, the concentration of people is mostly around Piazza di Santa Maria in Trastevere, where one can find plenty of options for restaurants, bakeries (hmmm!) and attractions. Isola Tiberina, Bocca della Verità are all close-by attractions. We have already visited Rome for two times and we stayed in this region. We even walked to the Colosseum from here. It is also easily accessible by public transport too. Besides having an ancient ambience made for tourists, there are a lot of Romans still living in, which make you feel you can live there too.
Great area for eating out. Lovely area to wander through, cheaper than elsewhere to eat. A busy spot during lunch and dinner in the evenings.
Great neighborhood. We really enjoyed walking through this area, it gives you a sense of daily life and many opportunities to try different restaurants and bars.

Just relax and get lost in streets of Trastevere. Forget the map and just wonder the streets and you will be surprised by warmth, happiness and diversity you can find here. If you don't like crowds the best time is any time before dark. Make a note that many shops and restaurants are not open on Sunday before noon if then.

Visit the Great Synagague. Love this area ! History , from a different perspective we visited the Synagague and it was sooooooo beautiful. The offered a perspective that included history from another vantage point.

Still charming. Although lots of tourists have found their way to the charming lanes of this old neighbourhood, they are still worth a stroll. Cute piazzas with friendly cafes and trattorias, busy markets and cosy second hand boutiques. Save a few hours of your visit to get lost in Trastevere.
Great restaurants. We love this area great restaurants. A must try is pasta with caccio e Pepe. Pasta with cheese and pepper. Delicious simply and great.
Best suburb for dining . Every little restaurant was excellent. So many choices. You will get lost in the laneways trying to choose a restaurant. There are also night market stalls in the laneways.
Beautiful area. A must visit for cool streets, nice restaurants, wine bars and general atmosphere. The area past the church in the centre is much more atmospheric.
Real Italy. A little bit of the real Italy where one can stroll or have a pleasant meal, at lunch or dinner. Not far from the centre, just the other side of the river

The best place to hang out in Rome. This is the best place in Rome to spend a day: very cultural, many restaurants and bars.
You can see a jazz band playing on the street, then see a mime artist in front of the fountain while having an ice cream and then go have dinner in the many places the Travestere has.
Old town. Shopping in narrow streets with interesting architecture, great market. Great mix of stores and some hustle and bustle in the afternoon.
Different Rome. This part of Rome is very different from other parts of the Rome. Narrow streets, smaller buildings,... Definitely suggest to visit church Santa Marian in Trastavere!
A nice afternoon walk.. Nice area but mostly for night. During the day/afternoon it is very quiet, but quite nice still if you are nearby

Wonderful area across the river.. We did the Rick Steve's walking tour through Trastevere. The area is very interesting and the audio walking tour made our visit much more interesting. The app and walking tours from Rick Steve's are free.

Great atmosphere. Stayed in this area with Airbnb. Great location with30 minute walk to colosseum and Vatican. Really nice restaurants and places to sit outside. Shame about the men trying to sell you selfie sticks and dancing 'sexy cat'

Was our favourite ..... We always visit here when in Rome for lunch
Beautiful quaint district - lovely restaurants
My only criticism is the local drunks that hang about the fountain and church being cruel to their dogs
Has put me right off ..

Beautiful Trastevere.. After a couple of days in Rome, where confusion, noise and traffic are non-stop, moving around Trastevere is like a breath of fresh air.
The architecture seems different, the noise is absent, and there is a clear calmness within the area.
Trastevere was definitely one of the highlights of being in Rome and is definitely worth a visit.

Rome's artistic and fun side. The Trastevere (or the other side of the Tiber) represents and ill-defined area on the western side of the Tiber. To the Northwest, it is limited by the Gianicolo, a large hill with the equestrian monument to Garibaldi at the top. To the east, it borders the Tiber and to the South, the emerging residential and commercial areas. The Trastevere is characterized by narrow, meandering streets, hundreds of restaurants, coffee shops, bars and artist dens. It is the area where Romans come to eat and have fun. Some of the best Roman dishes we've had in this area. Whenever we visit Rome, we walk through the Trastevere, visit shops and art galleries, stop for a coffee, a drink or a gelato. People watching is great at Piazza di Sta. Maria in Trastevere.

We will be back!. Really loved this particular part of Rome with its tiny streets and cobblestone alleyways. Great place to wander. It's a surprisingly large area and we only saw a small part, so will definitely be back.

Awesome Vibe. Such a lovely and lively place. Great markets, lots of nice restaurants and bars. We even visited the gardens which were serene however you have to pay and was quite prices for what it was. Will return to the area when next in Rome. Well worth the visit.

Tourists tourists tourists. The place is packed with tourists - including myself!!It's a pity that there were so many street vendors selling everything but Italian stuff. Scarves, hats and sunglasses, phone accessories gadgets and knickknacks. Only a few vendors were selling pictures of Rome as well as drawing and paintings. The shops only cater for tourists with tourist prices. Keep in mind that every single items is roughly 25% more expensive in Trastevere than anywhere else. It was still nice to walk around and see the old streets, old building and old church.

Favorite area of Rome. My favorite place to be in Roma. Just to stroll down and sit down at a lot of restaurants. Avoid the places on the main squares and don't fall in to the tourist trap if there is someone at the door to get you to sit down at there place. Walk by some restaurants and just sit down if it's busy with Italian people.Enjoy
Nice Neighbourhood!. if you like narrow streets, a lot of cafes outside and a different vibe than big cities then this is your place!

Attractive narrow streets with shops and stalls.. We came to see this area drawn by Basilica di Santa Maria. Sadly cars and scooters were still a constant hazard as we strolled along the narrow streets which can open into several piazzas. The area is distinctly different from other parts of Rome we visited and so worth the experience.

Way Cool Neighborhood. Trastevere is a place to stay not just to visit. The side streets, cafes, shops, and churches require time. It also takes a bit just to find your way around. Go out in the evenings and just walk around.

The best area of Roma to visit or stay. Just a very quaint feeling to visiting this part of Roma. Walk around, visit the shops, walk to the Tiber River, or stay at one of the local hotels. At night time, the place is full of tourists and locals walking and visiting. Outstanding restaurants that are moderately priced (most anyway). We stay in the area each visit.
Great neighborhood. We found everything we needed nearby our flat. Nice Italian restaurants, food shops, banking, gelato, etc. The flat we rented was modern, clean, luxurious and extremely quiet.
Interesting part of Rome . Slightly different feel to this part of old Rome. Lovely piazza, surrounded by restaurants. There are old streets to wander along and many churches to visit.

We walked to the Top. We walked through Trastevere ducking into some of the churches and many small stores. Our surprise church was Santa Maria Dell Orto we had the place to ourselves and were able to take in the beauty in quiet.

Lovely place to chill out. Went there a couple of time especially around piazza trilussa. Loved the small alleyways and bars there. Some amazing cocktail bars most of which have a free buffet.
A must for anyone visiting Rome especially in the early evening
Interesting neighborhood to visit. This area is accessible by bus and by tram. It is very interesting to walk it and stop for at a nice café.

Fabulous neighborhood. We spent an afternoon here just wandering around the little streets and shops. Excellent place- a lot of choices to eat and unique little shops. Felt like we got away from the hustle and bustle of the rest of Rome for a bit. The shops here also had very good prices, my friend and I bought three bags at one little place! Felt like a real place and not just touristy.

A fabulous day. We were in this area on a perfect sunny May Sunday afternoon. We hit a church, which was beautiful, and then wandered around piazzas and down narrow roads. It was beautiful and there were musicians. The atmosphere seemed so very Roman. People had told me that getting lost in Trastevere was a great experience and it was for us.
A posh version of a generic Magaluf night out.. Best avoided since it is a tourist trap and incredibly noisy. Head to Monti, Navona, Testaccio instead.

Trastevere. We went to the Trastevere because I love ancient and beautiful places with the idea of visiting the church of Santa Maria de Trastevere. We found it (we walked a lot from the Prati district). And when we entered they were playing Gregorian chant. How glorious, the sound and the beautiful church. I can still see it with my mind's eye and will never forget it.

not impressed. I've heard a lot about Trastevere but it didn't impress me at all. True, we get bored quite easily. We planned to take the tour as per Rick Steve's guide, but we didn't make it up to Basilica Santa Maria in Trastevere, as we decided there are definitely better places still to be seen. I expected a neighborhood with small streets, as ViaDelCorso backstreets, but found a pathetic suburb. Nevertheless we drank the most expensive beer in Rome, far more expensive than in proximity of Trevi or Vatican, in a SnackBar, not a restaurant. In my opinion, having only 4 days at disposal in Rome, Trastevere is not worth to see.

STAYED THERE. It is wonderfull at nite, lot of restaurantes. very silent at nite. I have been at the Santa Maria de Trastervere Hotel and I highly recomment same. Great attention and as it is a cloister very silent.

Beautiful churches and a great restaurant. Exceptional restaurant, TAVERNA INN on Via del Politeame. You can either sit outside which is very nice or inside which is beautiful. I would advise making reservations.
Wonderful area to live in. Plenty of choice for both historical sights and nice dining. Easy to get around, not overly noisy. Gives you a sense of old Rome.

Lovely place to relax from all the impressions. Lovely place to relax, to get away from the crowds of Rome's centre. Avoid the piazza's, go to one of the side alleys and enjoy yourself. Lovely shops and ofcourse, when well fed, visit Santa Maria di Travestere, a beautiful church.

Fun evening. We had a dinner tour (Eating Italy) through the city. We went to 6 stops having a different things each place. It was really great since all of the places were small family owned places that had been there for years (or generations). We learned the history of the region and of each place we visited.

Charming. This area of Rome is very popular and can be crowded but it certainly is fun. The shopping is delightful even if you don't purchase anything. The narrow streets are just asking to be photographed.
NIce walk. Was a nice walk on a lovely day. The Bernini in the local church was awesome. Great way to spend a Sunday morning

Lively, interesting part of town . A little bit off the path from most of Rome's historic sights, but just a short walk across the river Tiber. Many, many shops and restaurants and a very fun vibe. If you have the time, well worth a stroll one afternoon or evening.

One can get lost in these lanes!. This area of Rome is so beautiful. The narrow lanes all the way leaves an everlasting impression of how Rome was developed and functioned in an effective manner in first few centuries. The colour of buildings, the churches, the cat on a ramp, the fresh laundry hanging on a wire between lanes (one house to another), and an utopia kind of feeling that you came here before or you have lived here in past. My experience was unique as it reminded of a place that existed only in books and movies, but fortunately, it existed in Trastevere.

very nice quiet neighborhood. If you like wandering through small streets and getting surprised around every corner, this is an area you shouldnot skip if you visit Rome. Nice restaurants and small shops in this area on the other side of the Tiber river.

Not as expected. I was told Trastevere was now a popular area( even if before it was the poor part of Rome). Disappointed with the shops and restaurants. Only a few geletarias were in the area. A few places are nice as Piazza di Santa Maria in Trastevere where local musicians can show their talent. The parks in the north of Trastevere are really dirty, and really badly maintained. It is not the nicest park in Rome. Go to the Villa Borghese park or to the Roman Forum gardens, there you will be fully satisfied.

The place to stay in Rome. If you are planning to visit Rome then this is the place to stay. The Vatican and the Colosseum are only 15 minutes walk in either direction and after a hard day's sightseeing it's a great place to come back to. There are lots of narrow streets with shops but it's at night that the place comes alive. The place has a vibrant feel and there are lots of good restaurants (Grazie and Graziella was the best). After your meal it feels really safe to walk around and see the street performers in the piazza or stop at the numerous bars.

Tantalizing Trastavere. Loved Trastevere! We followed the walking tour highlighted in Rick Steves' Rome guidebook. Excellent! Loved St Cecilia church and the artisanal bakery. This is an area worth visiting.
Good for drinks and aperitivo. love this fantastic quartiere in Rome..especially for Aperitivo or after dinner drinks, full of young people.. A must seen in Rome!
Rome for Romans. Cucina Tipica Romana real food for those who want the taste of Roma. Sites to see. Nightlife for all.
found by accident. took metro to the bottom of trastevere and walked up, long way to get there but really enjoyed strolling around and people watching! good afternoon
Seems like THIS is the essence of Italy. I felt like I was transported to another era in time. the shops, vendors, bistros, all enchanting...very enjoyable

Beautiful. Simply stunning architecture everywhere you look Rome most certainly wasn't built in one day, and it will take several days to really appreciate the full beauty of this City and all it's amazing history

Traditional Rome.. Spent a lovely afternoon walking around this area of Rome. Accompanied by a Rick Steve audio guide I wandered and discovered little alleyways and streets that a lot of tourists just miss. I learnt that a few people who live in Trastevere have never crossed the river into Rome itself!
The energy!. I loved the little shops, as well as the cute restaurants around the area... The more you look around. the more you discover in Trastevere!
Do not miss!. Trastevere teams with great shopping, restaurants, people watching, music in the piazza and just about everything that one visits Rome for!

Was told this was a must see, but I am not sure why. We went out of our way to visit this neighborhood of Rome. To be honest, there are much nicer areas with great restaurants that were more centrally located, so I am not sure why this area was suggested. It did not appear to be more "authentic" or "traditional" than other areas of Rome. I do not think that this is worth going out of your way to see.

Vibrant and Full of Energy. We just stumbled upon this wonderful neighborhood after strolling across the river. It is such a fun, real, non-touristy place. Uncrowded streets and lots of local color. So many shops, a bakery to die for, restaurants, and street entertainment. The cathedral by the Piazza San Maria is one of the most magnificant in all of Italy. After dark the piazza is full of street performers. It was nice to get away from the crowds in the main part of the city. Next visit I may look for a hotel in this neighborhood.

Colourful and vibrant. This corner of Roma is quite an experience. Make sure that you visit, especially at night when several artists are performing illuminated manoeuvres on the piazza. Magnificent and at the top of my Rome list to experience.

Don't see the fuss. An average part of town with lots of cafés and reheated food. Regretting making the trip out! Head further out for traditional Italy, or find one good restaurant before hand. We came, we wandered and left disappointed.

Fabulous tour of Trastevere. We did the Trastevere tour with Jasmine who was so much fun, knowledgeable & personable.She took us to local food shops where we tasted wonderful local foods, & we met generations who owned the shops. We walked thru the oldest part & saw walls of an old synagogue dating back centuries ago. If in Rome be sure to book this tour!
Must see. Trastavere is a beauliful place in Rome, with it's own artistic soul. Walk the narrow alleys, enjoy some delicious gellato and buy some pieces of art.
The real Rome?. Trastevere, with its narrow winding cobbled streets and numerous piazzas is a great place to visit with lots of good places to eat.

Great neighborhood, worth exploring. This neighborhood is great, lots of cafes, bars, restaurants & little shops. Very quaint, small streets & alleys. Plenty of history to it. I highly recommend either doing a walking or a food tour through here or just spend time exploring on your own. Great area for foodies!

Beautiful neighbourhood, full of life and narrow streets. Went there late in the evening for some dinner. Very nice atmosphere. music in the streets, restaurants and street stalls. We should have stayed longer and will be there next time when in Rome.
Foodies part of town. Number of small restaurants, so you can find something that is not tourist trap. Not overcrowded, so it is a nice off the main track experience.

Old Italy...hidden gem. The place to go in Rome for authenticity - good gelato, great pizza and souvenir shopping. We went back twice because it was worth a second look for food and shops. If we had more time, we would have gone again!

Slice of local life. We walked through this neighbourhood, it was a welcome relief from the selfie stick and general tourist tat peddlars, with a liively feel. There were countless eateries that were popular with local people, interesting shops that sold the kind of things I might want to take home! When I come back to Rome I will seriously consider staying in this neighbourhood.
Nice Area with Many restaurants. There are many places to eat. You can stroll the back streets and there are many shops open. Slightly less busy than the other side of the river.

A slice of a luxury holiday. We were mostly backpacking through Rome and one evening spent in this part of the town with paved streets lined with quiet buildings and expensive restaurants makes it to one of my most romantic dinners had. Restaurants offering seating on the street with street musicians playing an instrument or two while you chat away on your holiday abroad. This is very dear to me as it made an expensive dinner worth it. P.S: Wine Bar was the restaurant we had dinner at and it was good.

Great buzz, great area. When visiting Rome you must visit Trastevere which is on the south of the river TIber. It's a vibrant district with tavernas, trattorias, bars and music and is full of life. Sunday evening was jumping. There are some great boutique hotels too. We stayed at Casa Mia. Found an amazing place to eat, drink and listen to live music which is on almost daily. If in Rome and you wish for something different get yourselves to Trastevere. On our first visit we stumbled upon this area on our last day. This visit we based around Trastevere.

beautiful area. A beautiful area, cobbled streets, lovely buildings. Many bars and restaurants. Piazza de Santa Maria with it's old church and fountain. The whole area is alive and vibrant at night and daytime a mix of locals and tourists.
Nice area to walk around and eat in.. After a visit to the Vatican - this is a great area to wander around get the atmosphere and try out the food. Also an easy walk back to the heart of Rome.
Love this district of Rome. This place is great during the day and a lot of fun at night. There is so much energy and places to choose to eat and drink. Worth visiting a few times.

Very historical place. we were in a hop and hop bus and the streets are uneven ...streets are narrow amazingly preserve...I had a few shots ...but we never had chance to do down and take pictures the hop hop bus doesnt give you much time to take pictures it will give you an idea what to see in that particular area but they wont actually bring you there you have to buy a different ticket for another trip ...

Relaxed atmosphere. Visited this part of Rome on a Sunday. The atmosphere is completely different from "down town"- very relaxed. We visited the Santa Maria in Trastevere church and were stunned by its beauty. Afterwards we sat down on the steps of the fountain in front of the church and enjoyed a sandwich in the sun while listening to the live music made by Niki la Rosa and his band. Trastevere is absolutely worth crossing the Tiber for! Isola Tiberina (which you need to get across from down town) is lovely too.
A truly fun neighborhood . Our group went to Trastevere twice specifically for the neighborhood. We had a lot of fun and loved all the love music and street performers! Will definitely go back!

A different experience. Watch out for the cars coming through the narrow cobbled streets. The streets are lovely and there are some very different, local shops selling everything from pastas, old books, tobacconists and beautiful clothes. There are some very good street restaurants and coffee bars, where you can sit and drink and eat outdoors as well as gelaterias, which are irresistible. All the piazzas have statues or fountains and they are all worth taking time to stop for a few minutes to enjoy the view.

A softer side of Rome. Trastevere is a non-touristy part of Rome. You will look around and notice things don't look as nice as they do in the central part of the city. The rugged feel and the graffiti everywhere give you that less ritzy more realistic feeling. I got lost and turns out I went to places that weren't on the map. Amongst all the tattered parts, you'll certainly find restaurants and gelaterias like in the main part of Rome, but I'm sure the prices will be cheaper. The streets will still be full of scooters and autos, but you'll feel totally different than you would towards the center. There's no metro nearby, but buses and taxis will still be present.

Great to get a different view of roman life. We walked there from our hotel on via nationale - this took about 40 minutes but it was a respite from the noise of the city. Lots of amazing artisan food places to explore.

My personal favorite part of Rome. First motivation for me to visit Rome again is Trastevere! Love to get lost in small streets with lord of great restaurants,cafe's and shops. Always good choice to be there and enjoy like locals.

A Fun place to roam. This is on the other side of the Tiber and a place to really have a chance to meet the working class of Rome. Lovely churches and restaurants. You cannot get lost and if you do you will always find a nice cafe or little place to sit.

An Italian home away from home.. This neighborhood will have you feeling as though you have come home to Rome. Whizzing scooters, strolling people and a charm at night that will keep you out til all hours.

Breath taking. Walk slow, take pictures, enjoy a drink or a meal at a local restaurant. Every corner you turn will be more beautiful than the last. We spent at least 12 hours a day walking the streets and seeing the sites, just amazing.
The cool Hip -area in Rome. Boosting of restaurants and bars in cosy and narrow streets Trastevere is a must while in Rome. Event meter than Monti area

Don't go between 3-7pm. We tried to squeeze in a self-guided "foodie walking tour" during the 3-7pm period. Mistake as most places were closed. Streets were vacant on a Wednesday. We felt safe walking around and found some great gelato. Not sure there is a need to go back though.
Get here in the evening!. Want to escape the typical tourist-y business of Rome? Get here (we walked from the First Luxury Art--whew!) for some great grub (Bir and Fud!) and cute shops.

Local Flair. We visited through a food tour provided by Eating Italy. It was great to see a more local piece of Rome - an area not often visited by tourists. The area has so much to offer. My partner and I discussed that the next time we visit Rome, we'll try to stay in or near Trastevere for a more local feel.

Excellent Place for a Variety of Foods and Views. The neighborhood was very busy when we were visiting. There were many food options and little shops that visitors could explore. We did all of our grocery shopping here during our stay. We had a great experience.

Interesting area of Rome, well worth a walk over the bridge.. Don't dive into the first ice cream shop that you see, walk further on and be rewarded with calmer quiter establishments with far better service.

Trastevere (it means) oltre tevere (beyond tevere ( side ). This is one of the most beatiful parts of Rome here you can see the real heart of Rome with the typical ancient store and also you can find the real roman cuisine like matriciana, carbonara, coda alla vaccinara and more. Here if you are lucky, during the night can hear an old melodie called "stornello" by a special singer to declare the love to the girlfriend !!! A great emotion trust me ! Just in one word here you can take a deep breathe of real Rome. Must try !!
Great area. Great area for chilling out and soaking up the atmosphere. Plenty of places to eat and drink and just sit and watch the world go by

A Dinner favourite. From central Rome, walk along the Tiber river and arrive in the neighborhood around 5 PM to have a slow stroll through it's cafe and restaurant filled streets, then have an aperatif until your belly starts to rumble (or you get a bit too merry) after which you head over to a restaurant for an Al fresco diner...don't take a cab back to your hotel, but walk along the Tiber again and see Rome lit up.

Traipsing Trastevere. There is nothing like this tight streeted hood. It was a roman holiday so no Noantri or Glass Osteria. But walking is the best with charming edifices shops and ambiance.and less crowds.

Our little Italy. We stayed in an airbnb in this area. It was perfect for transport, walking, bars, food, shops and sights. Its within walking distance of some of the main sights however we found the No 8 tram great to get us to Piazza Venecia which is a good place to start exploring. You can also pick up a Hop on Hop off bus at the Piazza Velencia to see the rest of the main sights.
