There is a church there onthe tour with an interesting history of use by an early Christian. We found a very popular restaurant with a 4 course dinner, frequented by a lot of tourists and Italians. It's just a quaint neighborhood across the bridge.

Small Group walking Tour. This one was set up as a food tour. It delivered on all counts. We were fortunate that there were only 3 of us plus the guide. She was excellent. Knew all the people at the various stops and had the history available.

Atmospheric. We have spent a few hours here both during the day and evening. During the day there is a bustling atmosphere and when we visited one Saturday evening it had a party feel. There are some very good bars and restaurants in the maze is streets, well worth a visit. An easy walk from central Rome.

Trendy, fun and good food. I made a couple of trips to Trastavere (pronounced Tras TEV a re). La Scala is a great restaurant for good food, reasonable prices and outdoor café. Charming to walk around the crowded streets looking at the eclectic shops and perfumeries.

Cute and pleasant to walk around, but.... Despite of being a picturesque place to enjoy a nice dinner and a walk around, the streets are dark, dirty, you can see rubble everywhere in the corners and you have to be very careful because there are dangerous holes everywhere on the pavement. In conclusion the maintenance is merely nonexistent which is a pity, but it is the same on the whole of Rome...

the best place to eat and drink. It's really pretty and full of all these tiny streets full of bars and eateries. I liked this neighborhood a lot and would love to come back and stay longer and eat more food.

Great nightlife in Rome. No trip to Rome would be complete without a visit to Trastevere, an evening in Piazza di Santa Maria is unforgettable, the fountain, the cobbled floors, the restaurants and bars. The side streets also have many small shops and cafes, you can go here early afternoon and walkabout discovering what Trastevere is all about and visit the Basilica di Santa Maria, before spending a relaxing evening in the square

Full of places to eat and drink!. Trastevere has many places to eat and drink on offer. Whilst not looking the best (most of Rome is covered with Graffiti to be fair!) the little side streets are full of life at meal times and the cafes are heaving! From little Pizzerias to larger restaurants, worth a visit!

Terrific Trastevere. Get there by tram from Piazza Venezia. Great nightspot.....plenty of pubs, clubs and restaurants. Buskers at Piazza St. Maria in Trastevere. Not far from here is the Villa Farnesina which exhibits some beautiful frescoes by Raphael.

The best place to eat and drink in Rome. This is where all the best cafes, bars and restaurants are located in Rome. A short walk from the city centre over the river Tiber via one of the many bridges will take you there.
lovely neighbourhood. We really enjoyed a stroll around this lovely area of narrow streets and little cafes and a visit to the lovely Santa Maria church made our day

You haven't "done Rome" if you have not included Trastavere!. It's hard to describe, but Trastavere has a completely different vibe than the rest of Rome. My friend and I ate at an Osteria there that had real wooden tables. I cannot remember the last time that I have been in a restaurant that had anything made of real wood! Our small table for two had hundreds--perhaps thousands--of names and initials carved into it. I learned upon arriving home that in Trastavere, there are people who still speak Latin! This surprised me as I had learned as a teen that Latin was a "dead language"; meaning that it was no longer spoken (excluding Latin Masses, of course). I wish I had known this fact prior to my trip as I attended a strict Catholic school that required us to learn to both pray and sing hymns in English, French, and Latin. It would have been fun to try out some of that Latin. I highly suggest going to Trastavere not only to see a different side of Rome, but because there is a great little information center there with lots of brochures. You will encounter it on your right-hand side almost immediately upon entering Trastavere. I wouldn't call it an actual building as it is more of a glass enclosure. You can't miss it!

A Perfect Area to Find Small Funny Cafes and Trattorias. When in Rom you have to visit Trastevere - it is a really, really nice law with small cafes, trattorias or restaurants around every corner. Evening visits recommended so you get the real Rome mood....

Authentic and charming!. Wondering where to eat out on our last night in Rome, I made a point of asking for a recommendation from the staff at our hotel. Simultaneously, they both enthused and recommended Trastevere. I asked why they were so passionate about it and their reply was that this is where all the locals go to. That type of recommendation is good enough for me and we were absolutely delighted with their choice. Trastevere is so authentic, oozing charm, full of small cobbled streets and a wonderful vibe. There are so many places to choose from to eat and we had a fantastic meal whilst listening to the street playing musicians. Would love to return and visit in the daytime but it was beautiful at night all lit up and we enjoyed a walk over the bridge across the river. This was just how I imagined Rome to be and I would definitely recommend it as part of your itinerary!

Loving place to stay . My family and I staying at Trastevere apartment during our trip to Rome, Italy. Unlike the busy city, this area is more quiet and feel more secure. We really enjoy our stay in Trastevere as by walking distance we can reach Ponte Sisto, one of the top attraction in Trastevere. During the walk you will pass by a lot of churches and you can see most of the great view in this town. There's transportation to get to the Piazza Venezia easily as well by just paying €1.50, once you get to the Piazza Venezia then you can easily found all the attraction spots in Rome (Colosseum, Pantheon, Trevi Fountain, Piazza di Spagna, etc).

This is the place to be in Rome. This is the place to be in Rome if you are fed up with all the sightseeing during the days. Trastevere is the nice artist area of Rome which you will find in every bigger city in Europe. Nice restaurants and nice shops.
Local not to busy area. Local not to buy area with a lot of small restaurants... And great atmosphere... Close to aal the sites u must see...must been there
A roam around the eat streets off Viale Trastevere. The eat streets are a must; best drinking and eating times 10:30-midnight. Remember you can walk around the streets with a beer in hand!

"Trastevere". About "Ponte Sisto", over the Tiber you arrive to Trastevere; All the year the tourist visit the very good restaurants from Trastevere, with guitar music etc; Very old streets as in the middle age, romantic atmospher; Very nice church are there, the wellknown Santa Maria in Trastevere with nice mosaics and a nice fountain Santa Maria, on her steps, it'syoung people place to meet; many bars and restaurants;Also I see the House of Fornarina, Casa delle Fornarina, she was a baker's daughterand Rafael's Love.

Quiet Elegance. It is like stepping into another city when you cross the river and enter Trastevere. The lovely Santa Maria in Trastevere was the lure but just walking the narrow charming streets was a welcome relief from the crush of people across the river.

A nice area to visit. We visited this area on our last day in Rome as we were looking for a more authentic experience. It is less touristy than central Rome. This area has a lot of great restaurants and cafes. It was about a 20 minute walk from the Piramide metro stop.
Wonderful walk. It is a specila charming place to walk in, where you can find plenty of reasonable good local restaurants
Lovely part of Rome. Wonderful walks in this area of Rome, next to the Tiber. Colorful with restaurants, places to stay, lots of personality.

Away from the crowds. Such a charming area, little side streets with some traffic so watch out for them scooters! Little shops, and cafes plus plenty of drinking fountains, don't buy bottled water, fill your own bottles from these delicious fountains. Find some great pastries and pizza, worth an afternoon stroll
BEAUTIFUL!. What a lovely place to walk and view the beautiful buildings and surroundings! We spent the day just strolling and shopping.
Lots of small side streets and an amazing church. This are feels less trampled by tourists than other areas, a little seedy at times. Walk up the hill for brilliant views of Rome

Fun neighborhood to meander through. We trekked over to Trastevere to gain a different perspective on the city. Was well worth the hike up the hill and to see a quieter, less crowded view of the city. Wish we had timed it better that we were hungry for lunch or a bite to eat.

Not sure what the fuss isabout. All the tour guides recommended the nightlife in Trastevere but despite a good English speaking taxi driver we didn't really see it. Reasonable pizza restaurant, then a walk back across the river.

Head here for food!. Sadly we only explored Trastevere on our last few days in Rome, due to it being a fair distance from our hotel and really only accessible by walking or buy bus. The winding streets are full of quirky stores and authentic restaurants, and tiny piazzas full of life! Buy a gelato and wander the streets getting lost!

Fantastic neighborhood. Ancient and still going strong. Fabulous eating. Definitely take a food tour if you can make it fit your schedule. Excellent gelato at Fatamorgana, Spirito DI Vino is not only an award winning restaurant but there wine cellar is an ancient synagogue.
old Rome. one the city's most charming neighborhood, loved by locals as well. Tiny streets, old houses, many good restaurants and a vibrant night life.
Beautiful place for a lovely evening. Just walk and get lost in the little streets of this lovely neighbourhood. During the evening it has an amazing atmosphere.

Beautiful area and great views. The Trastevere area is a beautiful spot just enough from the hustle of Rome to take a breath and take in the great views of the city below. We took cab up an all morning tour of the Vatican and explored at our own pace. Well worth the visit!

Sharp Contrast to the Lavishness of Ancient Rome. We visited Trastevere on our 5 day of walking and touring extensively so maybe we were very tired. This is definitely a bohemian area with some interesting sights. We started by crossing the Sixto Bridge over the Tiber and went to Villa Farnese, one of the homes of the famous family. We did not go inside. Behind the Villa are the Orte Botanico which, given more time, I would like to have visited. We then walked towards Piazza Sta Maria di Trastevere, stopping at one of the street cafes for coffee and people watching. The Church was closed and the piazza underwhelming. Crossed through the market place and east of Via di Trastevere to see 2 churches, St. Francis of Assisi (closed until 2pm) and Sta. Cecilia. This latter was the highlight of my visit to Trastevere. It is a small modest church. You pass into a courtyard of flowers and a fountain which is very peaceful and into the small chapel. Befitting her reputation as the patron saint of music, there were a group of nuns on the altar chanting their prayers. We sat for awhile to take it in and then headed back along the Tiber to the Vatican. Maybe Trastevere is an evening venue for young people and restaurants but it failed to "wow" us. It was very much a middle class residential neighbour much as we could find at home.

Heart and Soul of Rome. Trastevere is the place to stay in when in Rome. Walking distance from most Roman sight and the Vatican. It also is the centres of Roman night life, rich in pubs, restaurants, and clubs. It is the home to some of Rome’s most iconic Trattoria and Osterias
Spend as much time in this neighborhood as you can!. A fantastic colorful neighborhood loaded with history, restaurants, shops. Wander for hours through the cobblestone streets soaking it in.

wonderful medieval area. We were in Rome for two days and visited the Trastevere twice. the first time, we took city bus #23 from near the Vatican (Via Leone IV) to Tiber Island area, walked over the Ponte Cestio and into the Jewish Ghetto, then back across the bridge and wandered around Trastevere before walking back to our hotel. The second time we focused on the area around Santa Maria in Trastevere. The church itself is marvelous with a coffered ceiling and beautiful marble mosaic floor. While not without its tourists, this area is a far cry from the hustle and bustle of much of Rome and was my favorite area to stroll. The Forum is historic Rome, and the baroque is so proudly Rome, but Trastevere is medieval Rome with all its unique charm and beauty.

What a great neighborhood. Deciding to visit Rome for six weeks, I elected to rent an apartment in Trastevere. What a joy! This neighborhood offers excellent restaurants of all types from quick take-away to fine dining. The area is lively and remarkable for all it offers.
Going out area. Always full of people. Nice area for going out. Bars open late. Nice restaurants in Trastevere. Easy reachable from city center

Great neighborhood. Funny that tripadvisor lets you review a neighborhood?
Anyway this was one of our favorite parts of Rome. A different sort of more urban tourist, not their to see the big sites. Nice shops, good restaurants, a slower pace. Fun to wander around, meander. I would be tempted to stay here is I come back to Rome.
Fantastic. I loved this area. Great restaurants.the best food in Rome in general. Fun to walk around lots of interesting small streets

Nice to Stay. I stayed in Trastevere for 5 days during my Rome trip. It is very close to the heart of Rome. You can walk anywhere you want. Besides this place is awsome with the narrow streets, musicians, restaurants. It is so easy to go anywhere with the public transport. I advice you to stay in Trastevere if you are in Rome.
Best square in Rome. No doubts about it. A magical place, it's amazing to walk thru' those ancient streets. Lovely bars all around there.

Close to everything, away from tourists.. I was recommended to stay in Trastevere and it was perfect. As the title suggests, not so many tourists like in the thick of Rome, so was definitely a more authentic feel. Also meant it was a fair bit cheaper. But still walking distance from everywhere you'd want to visit. I will always be staying there when I return from here on.

Lovely!!. This part of Rome is fantastic! We rented a room in a bed and breakfast here so we spent most of the evenings here. Lots of restaurants, bars and nice little streets - perfect for a slowly walk to enjoy the atmosphere. It is not far from centro storico - just over the river, but if you dont want to walk tram number 8 goes from piazza Venezia. Stay here or just come for a dinner - you wont be disapointed.
A LOT OF RESTAURANTS. We had a great Italian meal in this area. This is becoming a popular spot for good eating establishments. A nice area to stroll around.

Consider a taxi to the top. Finished our stay in Rome by visiting the look out at Trastavere - and we have no regrets. Fantastic view over the city and a green, breezey change from the streets. An easy walk to the street level and transport options, but we indulged in a taxi for the trip up.

Grungy and Overrated - I Don't Get the Appeal. It seems like it's cool to recommend Trastevere as a slightly off the beaten path destination in Rome, but I didn't like it at all. It was littered with graffiti, the cobblestone streets were an absolute mess, and there wasn't much of note to see there. There were lots of panhandlers around, including a gypsy holding an infant and pretty much blowing cigarette smoke in its face. Not my cup of tea, and definitely not recommended for families with young children like mine.

Quaint and Charming. A great sub-area of Rome. We loved it! We stayed here for 4 nights but very walkable to most all the sites. The restaurants are quaint, good and most reasonable we found in Rome. Loved the sidewalk cafes and small cobblestone streets. Friendly people.

My favourite part of Rome. We had spent a lot of time walking around Central Rome, going to restaurants on tourist squares and kept getting caught out with nice views but below average service at above average prices. We went to Trastevere hoping for a Camden type, neighbourhood district feel and we got exactly that! It's a great part of town to kill time people watching, browsing quirky market stalls (1 guy was selling postcards from a collection over the last 50-70 years that had actually been sent to him and others!) and for finding a much truer feel to what it might be like to live in Rome these days. It's still touristy but way less stressful. I bought some local Limoncello and had a fantastic lunch with the best service we had in Italy across 5 cities. Cannot recommend enough! Go here, wander and explore. Great photo opportunities too ;) Ps. we walked from the Pantheon over a nearby bridge and it took us about 30 minutes. We walk everywhere and so should you (if you can!)

What a Lovely Neighborhood!. For our 25th anniversary, my husband and I rented an apartment in Trastevere. We were just one block from the Tiber River and a quick walk to St. Peter's Square and the Vatican Museum.There were SO many small restaurants and artsy shops in this neighborhood, as their history will tell you! We did not have a bad meal in this area. There is also a "quickie/mini mart" on the edge of the "centre", good for getting snacks and beverages for the apartment.If you are looking for a "real" neighborhood, this is it! There were not gobs of tourists as there are near the Coliseum or elsewhere in Rome. But, that does not mean there are no people here ~ with the old city feel with narrow alleys, there are definitely people here! Especially on Friday-Sunday nights. Don't let that keep you away! Enjoy yourself and visit here!
Must visit place. Its a must visit if you are in Rome. Just cross the river and you are in a different world altogether. Far from the crowd, a peaceful place with some good locations.
Cultured left bank. the cobbled streets are full of galleries , cafes and restaurants and the maze of streets and great squares form a good place to chill out for a while

Adorable neighborhood. Steps away from the hustle and bustle, Trastevere is an adorable enclave that provides an authentic Italian experience...the food, the people and the buildings are photo-worthy...and worth the time to explore!

Bohemian Neighbourhood. This is a great neighbourhood to go explore to get away from the tourist areas on the other side of the Tiber. It bubbles with energy, full of quirky boutiques and fun places to get food and drinks. Definitely worth the walk over.

Across the Tiber. We started our day in Trastevere with a guide at the top of the Janiculum hill, with a beautiful view of Rome on one side and St. Peters off another side. We walked downhill were treated to many more city views, fountains, churches, and quiet little streets. Quite a different feel on this side of the Tiber. Recommend good walking shoes!

Great place to eat.. We were advised to eat there while on a tour of the Colloseum & Palatine Hill; this proved good advice as we were able to walk there ( from near Trajan's column). We ate there on successive nights (Fri/Sat) without booking and found the food, service and cost excellent. Lovely area to stroll around while finding a place to eat. Book if you are in a hurry of course.
Fun area. very nice area with a lot of restaurants, bars, cafes. Busy area with great atmosphere with both locals and tourists.

The best restaurants..... The loveliest and most appealing neighbourhood in Roma. Lots of good restaurants around every corner and excellent cheap eateries to delight. Craft stalls mixed with music playing everywhere. Very likely after dark!!!!
great area...we stayed here as a home base. loved this part of town...close enough yet away from the hustle and bustle. great restaurants, good shopping, great wines and food. walkable to all points.
Hipster Rome. I love this area, great shops and vibrant atmosphere at night with good bars and restaurants, dig deeper to find some real underground style bars and concepts.

Food heaven. . So many little restaurants and little shops to get yourself lost in. Plenty to see and do. More a student and residential area but quite nice and quite compared to the rest off rome. Great place to set yourself up for a stay
Nice place to have diner. Just walk through the streets and see all kinds of good eating places. It's very nice and lively. We spend a few night here with a lot of fun.

Cosy Rome evenings. At mornings this area is a quiet neighbourhood with sleepy cats in the sun and clothes drying in the cosy narrow alleys. This changes at nights - shops and restaurants pops out of nowhere. The streets come alive crowded with both native Romans and tourists along. Clearly the most cosy place in Rome.

Rome at its best. Enjoy the narrow streets of this Roman neighborhood, eat a pizza in one of its many reataurants and go for an Italian. ice cream as dessert. At sunset enjoy the effects of the sun on the façade of Santa Maria in Trastevere (don't forget to visit the basilica!)Not far from Trastevere is Gianicolo, the best place to enjoy a view of Rome. Here you can also find the equestrian statue of General Garibaldi.

Loved it,felt real!. Enjoyed walking around the narrow streets, lovely meal in restaurant called Bruno alla lungaretta! Small shops, warm friendly people. Less busy so more enjoyable.Visit Santa Maria transtevere church and San Frances's a ripa church. Berninis ecstasy.
Cozy tight streets. Cozy tight streets, and restaurants, but nothing special. It is worth to take a walk there and have a drink.
Very nice area to find quite places. Trastevere is the perfect place in roma to find quite places like small restaurant, bar....A lot of small street with small chops..Our favorite place in roma
Interesting part of Rome. We thought it was quite Bohemian and enjoyed walking the narrow pedestrian streets lined with restaurants and cafes. There re lots of interesting shops also.

A wonderful not to be missed experience. We headed over the bridge I to Trastevere as dusk was setting in. There was a feel of the place starting to come to life as we strolled through the narrow streets. Quirky stores and an array of really good and reasonably rice places to eat; coupled with amazing street entertainers in the piazzas, and some wonderful buildings to see, made this definitely a great place to visit on a lovely evening. We then walked along the river towards Castel Sant Angelo which was an amazing sight when illuminated. We took the walk round to St. Peter's Square and saw that at night too. Definitely another must do for a trip to Rome. Simply an amazing evening.

Charming . Take some long walks in this area, the alleys are mesmerizing specially in the lights of the night. The charming little restaurants are most likely full in the evenings, but you have many options.
The "happening" area of Rome ...... The "happening" area of Rome, home to the arts and to late-night activity, we have found a few good hotels and many fine

Bohemian Rhapsody at its best!. Enjoy the beautiful cobblestone streets, restaurants where locals dine, and its unique and interesting shopping. Find the shop, find the lady who makes the most amazing handmade sandals in Rome!

Lovely area of Rome. Nice to wander slowly through the narrow streets and linked piazzas.By day take in the simple architecture and churches.By night spend time at a street cafe or bar and people watch.Lots of cafes and restaurants, some much better than others.
Wow,great area really comes to life at night. Fab ,really changes in evening when everything is open and the lights and smells and sounds transport you to another world do not miss this
Worth taking a day to discover. A gem in Rome, the Trastevere area is well worth of spending a day. Its home to many cafe's restaurants and the beautiful Church Santa Maria in Trastevere
Over rated.. Everyone kept recommending it but truly nothing out of this world. The authenticity of a Roman neighborhood was definitely its best feature but could have skipped the neighborhood.

Beautiful. I've been traveling to Rome for the last ten years, including family and solo vacations and study abroad in nearby John Cabot University. Now I live in this area and it is an amazing place to live and visit. You can find quiet streets that no tourists go to, great restaurants (my favorite is Osteria Ponte Sisto), cute clothing stores, bars, pubs, everything!

Be aware of tourist traps but enjoy the atmosphere.. Don't think you will be the first tourist in what the guides recommend as a very vivid city part where foreigners always landed first. Everywhere you'll find vendors with 'original' African or South-American artifacts, all kinds of jewelry or funny stuff to play with. The restaurants are very tourist-orientated as well. Still, the atmosphere is friendly, open, humorous and vivid. Sometimes one needs it and doesn't mind to pay a little more for it.

Did we miss something?. We were here in the afternoon. Saw Saint Maria Church and the environs. We did not find this neighborhood to be anything special. I was disappointed since so many reviews rave about it and Rick Steves says to go here.

Engaging, informative tour. The tour guide was remarkable and led us on an evening tour of the Trastevere and Jewish Ghetto. She was quite knowledgable as well as personable. These were "roads less traveled" and she brought the to life.
Quaint and not too toursity. Beautiful area offering more quiet streets if you are tired of the busy tourist attractions. Lovely shops and coffee shops. Laid back and relaxed, and really beautiful.
Dinner here. Came here for dinner. Walked around a little in a very touristy area with people selling the usual junk. I think the quieter areas may be prettier. Lively to come and have a drink.

Hidden jewl of Rome. To be precise, it is not so hidden, but it is a bit detached from the centre and not on the agenda of most tours.Howevere, definitely worth visiting - just cross any of the many Tevere bridges in the southwest and you are there in a few minutes.Dozens of small narrow streets, shops, cafes, tavernas, piazzetas, fountains and what not. It retained the spirit of old, charming, bohemian city.
Get away from the husle of Rome. Lovely little alley ways ,quirky shops,plenty of good restaurants at reasonable prices. Relatively quiet after Rome city
VERY nice area. Go walk a bit, beautiful buildings, and quite a few small cafes and resteraunts. very recommended...
Wonderful Place to Wander, Shop and Eat. There are so many small businesses and streets to check out. This is a beautiful area and the people are very nice. Spend the day you will be glad you did.

Vibrant heart of Rome, the artist community over the river from the coleseum. I can't say enough about this neighborhood(s), it's a great concentration of restaurants and artist stores that give you a great feel for the vibrant, real Rome. I have come back multiple times and what I like most is that you almost can't go wrong with food choices in this district. It definitely feels more lived in than some of the other Tourist attractions in the city.

A Great Break from the Crowds in Rome. Trastevere is a great way to escape the city hustle & bustle and enjoy a more quaint, quiet, and neighborhoody side of Rome. It's a bit of a walk, but just follow the Tiber River. Make sure to take time to stop for a more authentic meal while you're there.

Lovely area. My Brother lived in Trastevere many years ago, before it was "trendy" and so he encouraged us to visit on our recent trip. We walked over the bridge onto the island and crossed the Tiber. What a lovely place, I guess the centre of Rome was similar to this area many years ago. I is well worth a wander through the little streets with cafes and restaurants.

Lovely area to wander. No sights as such, just a quieter neighbourhood with lots of cafes and restaurants and little boutiques. We enjoyed wandering around for a couple of hours, and I particularly enjoyed the green market although I didn't need to buy anything.

lovely to wander the cobbled street in the evenings. Go here for a wander in the evening and have dinner. Its trendy during the week end. There was a fabulous band playing in the street in the open air for free to watch. Many stalls selling gifts for just a few euros.

The place is buzzing. Nice place to visit during the day but in the evening it really opens up. Lots of restaurant and bar that cover every taste .Visited 3 times during our visit to Rome and it never disappoints

Rome at a slower pace. Went to Trastevere to find a place to eat - much quieter than other parts of Rome, much less traffic, much slower pace to life, lots of places to eat, mostly a range of traditional Italian fare, but caters to a range of budgets. We had lunch al fresco at Enoteca, a modern wine bar/restaurant, good food, especially the fresh salads. Lots of shops and market stalls to browse.

Locals live here but touristy now. I dont know why I whinge about things being so touristy these days as I am a tourist. Everyone that visits a place away from home is in effect a tourist. But in the guide books they say to visit here as its where the Rome residents live but of course we have all read this now and it is touristy, but I dont care it was so charming and much quieter and there are many cafes and trattorias and churches, and of course the locals, so much to love, enjoy.

Lovely, day and night!. Trastevere is great! Such a lively part of Rome. There's lots to see and it's lovely to take a stroll down the streets. When we were here in the evening there was a lot of stalls with quite unique things to buy. There's plenty of places to grab a bite. Do not skip this neighbourhood!

the classy part of town. Trastevere is in the south west part of Rome. it's a quite place with relaxing atmosphere and narrow streets ,there are some nice cafes there. deserve a look if you have time to spare

Another side of Rome. This is our 2nd visit in Rome, so instead of the Colosseum, Pantheon and other top tourist attractions, we decided to explore this neighborhood by joining a Segway tour (please see my other review on Rex Tours). This is an unique experience, the Trastevere is not as busy, there are many restaurants, local shops, churches and piazza. This is a good experience to see another side of Rome.

Nice, but touristic. If your hotel receptionist tells you that Trastevere is more local and less touristic, don't believe him. It's a nice area, but certainly not less touristic than e.g. Campo dé Fiori area.

old italian atmosphere. Small cars, old italian village atmosphere, nice restaurants..perfect place to visit to see more traditional Italian streets in Rome. There are so many good restaurants for dinner. We went there for lunch, we found all of them are open but restaurants dont serve any food bero 7p.m. We luckily found a bar to eat some pizza. Trastevere becomes more crowded at nights.

My husband and I had a private walking tour through here and we had a wonderful time.. We strolled through Trastevere which is a quiet and more authentic neighbord experience than we've had say, by the Spanish Steps. We had a great lunch which was very inexpensive and some fantastic Gelato.
Fun and crazy...in a good way!. We stayed in an apartment for 5 days. Everything is available to you and easy access to downtown Rome.
Saw the area on a segway tour. The winding streets with all the little bistros make this an interesting and classic Roman district worth visiting.

Excellent place to visit or stay. Last year i stayed in Spanish Steps. This time i chose the other side in Trastevere. Very nice small alleys with plenty of good choices to eat and drink. As everywhere in Rome its tourist infected by you can find some very good places if you look hard. Very nice atmosphere in the night where many locals and tourists are walking. When in Rome, you should definetely visit this unique area.

Trastevere. This is a beautiful area of Rome full of excellent, affordable restaurants and shops, surrounded by Roman antiquities. There is a public marketplace in the center offering fresh produce and other local items.
Quirky neighbourhood. Lively and interesting part of Rome. Use the Rick Steves podcast tour (no affiliation) then hang around for the evening to people watch and have a leisurely dinner.
nice to wander. Nice to wander around but it really is a tourist area designed with shops and cafe which are overpriced and expensive for what you get so beware
Woderful part of Rome. This is amazing. You cannot imagine, without going there. It's like a town in a town. Nice and good restaurants.

Trastavere. We had a guide with us from TourByLocals .com - well worth using their expertise to enjoy the whole area as it is the history that makes it so interesting and where to walk is also important.

Romantic stroll in quintessential Rome. Our B&B hosts recommended the Bohemian Trastevere quarter to us as the perfect place for a quintessential Rome dining experience... think pavement cafes with chequered table cloths, street musicians and artisans selling their wares from the kerbs. We spent a lovely evening, people watching over a bottle of Chianti and pasta. Lots of great little bars with good house wine and deals on beers and spirits to finish off the night.

Lovely walking area - terrible restaurants nearby. This is a terrific area for walking and browsing, stepping into small churches, a little shopping (although very tourist oriented) and general relaxing. Try no to be there at meal time, however, because all the restaurants are tourist traps.

Getting lost in Rome. Trastevere is a really nice Roman quarter with lots of restaurants and shops. There are lots of beautiful little streets and piazzas and a true authentic roman-atmosphere. I’ll definitely recommend spending a few hours here … just getting lost in the little streets … and perhaps stopping for a coffee, an ice cream or dinner in a local restaurant a bit away from the bridges.

Lovely. Used a self guided walking tour on the internet. Very interesting and worthwhile to make the trip across the Tiber. Had drinks in a lovely square as we watched the locals go about their Saturday routine.

Neat Neighborhood. This is a really neat neighborhood, and I know there are great places to eat everywhere. We took a recommendation for a place to eat and was actually unimpressed, but would try somewhere else in the neighborhood.

Eating Italy Daylight Trastevere Food Tour Walk. This was a pre-booked 4 hour tour September 2015. Wonderful food & history walk starting from a small Trastevere café. Our first taste was at a Pasticceria shop - scrumptious. We then walked to 3 different family shops to taste melt in your mouth porchetti & other pork products; a cheese shop and later a biscotti shop and bakery. All have been in existence for more than 25 years and well patronized. The biscotti were such a lovely assortment it was hard not to buy a little of a number of them. We also went to lunch at a restaurant which was tucked away down a small street. It had the four walls of a 2000 year old synagogue but was built out by surrounding buildings. We had a very good pasta lunch with a an accompanying wine - red or white. Very enjoyable. Afterwards we were taken to the basement to see the many layers of civilization to be seen in the walls - truly astounding and such a find! Romans through the ages kept building on top of the previous civilisations. Loved it all. The walking tour lead was excellent & shared her knowledge freely.
A very pleasant night visit. I visited the area several nights. Very good restaurants. Pleasant atmosphere with a lot of people. Convenient to dinner in the streets.

A beautiful rione to get lost in. We hopped off the bus and crossed the river on the Ponte Sisto. Wandering around the tiny streets was near one of my favourite parts of our holiday. Getting lost in the narrow streets, passing by many restaurants and eateries with outdoor seating, following winding paths and cobbled streets, it felt as if we were finally getting a taste of the real Rome.Would fully recommend a visit to this region of Rome. Bring a map, and then ignore it until you want to return.

Lovely Old Neighbourhood. We visited Trastevere on the recommendation of our Airbnb hosts. We found a lovely old part of the neighbourhood which had narrow cobblestoned streets lined with lovely restaurants and bars, colorful buildings and vendors selling jewelry and crafts. We enjoyed some bruschetta and drinks at an outdoor table in the sun and watched the passers by while we enjoyed our meal. A lovely place to visit.

Authentic Rome. We have stayed in Trastevere on two different occasions and would not stay anywhere else while in Rome. The food, the shopping, the attractions, the nightlife are second to none in all Rome. Visit Monte Gianicolo for an awesome view of Rome. Meander in and out on the streets around Piazza Santa Maria. Get lost on the beautiful narrow, old streets of the most authentic part of Rome that you will find.

The heart of the true Rome. Lovely narrow streets, plenty of restaurants and pizzerias, small shops and craft stalls. Not to mention the stunning churches and that unique feeling of art surrounding you for the whole visit. A must!
Best place in Rome?. Really nice Rome-Quarter with lots of restaurants and shops. Beautiful little streets and authentic roman-atmosphere. To recommend!!!
Heart of Rome. Location Location Location...best area to stay in Rome...walking distance to almost everywhere..fantastic restaurants and bars

Colourful place. Trastevere is the most beautiful neighbor of the town by far! Full of colourful buildings, less expensive food, alternative stores and a more vivid nightlife. I believe it is ideal for someone to book in Trastevere because it is very close to the downtown of Rome.

A great neighborhood of Rome to explore. We had been told by a friend to make this a destination on our recent trip to Rome. We have been to Rome before and didn't want to visit the typical tourist areas. We wanted something more local. This neighborhood was it. Lots of very interesting shops, restaurants and bars. A good mix of locals and tourists. Didn't feel overwhelmed by crowds. We found a couple of spots to enjoy a glass of wine and people watch. We also found a great place for dinner along the way (Taverna della Scala); I love it when you discover a place on your own.

Wonderful neighbourhood...away from the tourist traps. We spent quite a lot of time in Trastevere during our 4th stay in the city, and it will be the first place we go back to next time. Authentic, away from the tourist traps...and some lovely narrow winding streets to lose yourself in for an afternoon! Try and take in mass on Sunday morning at Santa Maria church. Wonderful.
<3. It was my first time in Italy and I totally fall in love with this place. It is romantic, it is alive, it is Rome!
Discover a nicer part of Rome. This part of Rome is really cosy and you can walk the small streets (with almost no cars) and enjoy a little authentic atmosphere . . .

Nice go for it and Enjoy it a Vintage area. This district and it's Holly Road it's a really beautiful it has shorted my friend and I went there and I went there and back by myself and Has restaurants some of them are expensive so they are not expensive just go and explore enjoy itTrastévere es un barrio muy guay de Roma en calidad perfecta hay restaurantes caros y otros baratos en este barrio recomienda es bonito es algo así como el Malasaña de Roma disfrutarlo

Lovely Trastevere. Lovely place with a lot of restaurants and bars, where I tried the most delicious pasta in Rome. I recommend you to as locals about places to eat, they will always give you good advise.
Rome's best kept secret!. Lots of little streets opening on to unexpected squares. Many small family restaurants will friendly and welcoming staff.

Don't miss when visiting Rome. My third visit to Rome but first time to Trastevere. Oh, what I have been missing. Slower by 50 years than the Rome across the river. Narrow streets, quaint shops and quite restaurants. Be sure to visit your next visit to Rome
Only 3 stops by tram from Piazza Venezia or walk. The churches are stunning - and good pizzas to be found too. The area is a maze of small streets, all charming. Ignore the tat sellers.

worth an exploraton on foot!. a colorful and iconic Roman neighborhood. The small alleys were a delight to explore, especially by night when the vendors were out, and some street entertainers. A lively spot. So much that was visually intriguing
don't think go and see. great streets and squares. you can find many pubs restaurants coffee shops and more. you can see also historical churches.

Go to Trastevere for the Views from Giancolo Hill. So, everyone in Rome pretty much tells you - eat in Trastevere. So, we had some time to spare and had read about the best place for sunset views on the top of Giancolo Hill (in Trastevere). We ended up having drinks in one of the church square piazza's in Trastevere, then headed up to the top of Giancolo Hill (the Janiculum). It was worth going to Trastevere in order to combine food/drinks with this view of the city.
Lovely area of Rome. Well worth a visit, this area of Rome is old and quaint, with cafes, shops, alleyways, and a lovely piazza to people watch.
Old Town Rome. This area has the narrow winding streets that you expect of the old town areas of Europe, along with restaurants serving authentic Italian food.
Great restaurants and bars. Sleepy and a bit of a run down appearance during the day, amazing by night. My fave hood in Rome. Great place to stay if you enjoy a busy but not rowdy night life.

One of My Favorite Neighborhoods. I'm food obsessed, so naturally I could eat myself into a coma within a block radius here on a daily basis and never be sick of it. The narrow winding streets have a lot of character, there are so many nice cheap spots to have a drink or indulge in aperitivo,and some of my happiest memories are picking through the the Porta Portese market on Sunday mornings with my dad. Plus walking through the area up Gianicolo takes one from a very lively, active vibe, to a peaceful, almost non-urban atmosphere and the view & fountain at the top are absolutely one of the most spectacular in Rome. Don't miss this area!

Tonnes of action here!. Edgy and great nightlife - make sure you arrive off the bus from Termini in the north of Trastevere now down in the bowels its a long walk up to the action! Great at night we loved the bars and restaurants here - heaving with people and atmosphere!

Beautiful Old Town. Fabulous streets, architecture and food. If you want to see a true Italian town visit here as this is where the locals go, oh and this is where the oldest Roman church resides! It was simply beautiful!

Historic, educational and entertaining. I went to Trastevere as part of a food and wine tasting tour. The place has many hidden secrets that would normally not be visible to the visitor. There are many historic restaurants and bars in this area. I visited a stunning 2000 year old wine cellar in this area. This area is full of gems if you are a food lover.
Nice Neighborhood Visit. Nice neighborhood, photo worthy. Unfortunately, too commercial for my tastes. I have found other neighborhoods nicer to walk through
A must see. If you go anywhere in Rome, come here, very authentic Roman away form tourist traps, no peddlers, great Tavernas, history especially in Jewish Ghetto

Hopping, hugely already-discovered part of Rome. Yes, it is quite filled with tourists. And yes, it is very, very busy. But Trastevere is filled with restaurants, shopping and excellent people watching. If you spent any time in Rome, you almost certainly will be visiting here. It is accessible by the tram and buses. The heart of Trastevere is probably a 20 to 30 minute walk at most from the Coliseum.
Day trip. Loved being in this part of Italy. Lots of great restaurants and locals. Fun place to hang out for the day. Must try the Casci e Pepe dish native to Rome (spagetti with pepper and cheese)!

Trastevere. A great place to wander through the small cobbled streets. Visited this area 3 times while in Rome. Food was excellent. Many waiters and cafe owners can speak English. Very lovely place to visit.

Lots of fun here!. We stayed in Trastevere by Ipolito Nievo and Trastevere "Street". We walked to the restaurant district by the Tiber River. It was fun and charming. Check out Baccanale Pub!!! It was so much fun! I wish we knew the waitress's name. She was so good to us tourists.

The place to go from the afternoon and night. Just wonderful!!!!!!. You have to immerse in the magic of Trastevere. The little restaurants and bars, the streets, the people, the place is just wonderful, just get lost. There's always a great band playing music in the middle of the street. This was out favorite area in rome and we just regret that we did not have more time to enjoy it. If we return to Rome we will staying neat Trastevere.

A great area to stay in Rome. We stayed in the Trastevere area of Rome for four nights. We had a fabulous time. Whatever time of day or night there was something to see or do, eat or drink, or simply sit and relax. The winding streets are full of character and it's easy (and well worth) getting lost while you wander around - you'll always find some amazing bar or restaurant to stop off at.

visit this Roman neighborhood. This is a refreshing neighborhood across the Tiber River a bit away from the hustle and bustle of downtown Rome. After the ruins and all the walking we were delighted to find a spot that was comfortable just to walk and sit for a drink. It looked different and felt different and had a different sort of charm all its own. There are plenty of restaurants and shops here as anywhere in Rome.

Just wonderful!!. We actually rented a flat here for the past week and it was just terrific. The restaurants are great and there are huge crowds everywhere. Plenty of small boutiques and great pizza shops. If you're in Roma, make sure you spend a few hours here in Trastevere. It's awesome!!

Take your time and enjoy the neighborhood!!!. This area will give you an immense feel for what it would be like to leave in an apartment in this area. We stayed at a BNB right in the heart of Trastevere and ate at several of the top eating establishments in Rome. The food is incredible, the people watching incredible and the gelato will roll your eyeballs back in your head!!! Wear good shoes as the cobblestone streets can be tricky sand we saw an elderly lady fall and a wonderful Italian gentleman run to her rescue.

trastevere worth a walk. We loved walking this area.we walked down to the oldest bridge on the Tiber,across to the island then back to the cetre via Trastvere,its just so different to the busy centre,the buildings are amazing and the atmosphere is wonderful

A lovely part of Rome to visit.. This is a great place to visit..loads of lovely restaurants and some of the best Pizza in Rome can be found here. On a sunday there is a great Flea Market where you will find loads of bargains, it's a really big market so allow plenty of time to look around. Lots of leather goods at very cheap prices. Shoes prices from €3, great ladies fashions at half the price of the shops.

Fun Neighbourhood for an Evening Visit. Great area to visit early in the evening, have an aperitif and early buffet which is a must do custom. Try an Aperol Spritz ( the orange coloured beverage everyone drinks) for the price of your drink and a couple more euros you can have unlimited access to the tapas buffet on the bars. This area of narrow streets also has great rustic photo ops as you wander around the alleys and small boutique shops. When night falls there is usually a crowd and a band to stomp your feet too in the square.

Smell of Spain, hidden in Rome. I loved that neighbour in Rome. It was a smell of Spain, hidden in the Rome. Amazing, warm, causy bars, smiley, young and flirty people. Next time in Rome, I will definitely find a hotel nearby.
great spot to photoshot. very great venue to have photoshot, many arthistic buildings along the road, very ideal to be your honeymoon destination.
Nightlife. Excellent place to finish your day in Rome. It is a very charming neighborhood full of restaurants and bars. Definitely worth taking a walk and having dinner in the area.

Worth the trip to visit. What a fun day we had :-) It took a little time to get here from where we started but well worth the trip. The landscape is amazing. I loved wandering around looking at all the details.

Trastevere. A fun hip area for an evening in a different part of town. Lots of restaurants. Lots of locals. We ate at Osteria da Z'Umberto. Indoor and outdoor seating. . Good food at very reasonable prices!
Nice neighborhood! . Beautiful place to enjoy walking and discovering nice places! Cute restaurants and shops. Very near from Vatican City. Nice place to have great views of the Tiber river.
Trastevere. A lively old neighbourhood in Rome with plenty of restaurants. Good for walking as well. Other than that not many things to do.
The most beautiful place! . A must see, must stay in location in Rome. This part of town is fabulous for exploring, dining and shopping. A beautiful blend of old and new.
great place to stay for a young couple. great neighborhood in rome for nightlife and restaurants. very lively. looks very old and authentically Roman.

Simply charming. Spent 4 days in a flat in Trastevere and fell in love with this district. It is very lively with hundreds of restaurants and tons of terraces. Wandering in the evening in the small streets is simply magic. It is only a 30 minutes walk to the Vatican of to the RomanA perfect place to stay to live Rome differently.

Restaurants and ambient so good. Its like no rome. As i didnt like the huge rome this place i loved it. The life is so easy down here. The restaurant are so like ''italian''. Narrow streets and tiny shops are very cool. Its a touristic place also.
Nice place to anchor from. Close to major sites and great bus transporatation throughout the city. Many good places to eat and a lot of attractions to see.

Oldest Rome neighborhood. Across the Tevere River is Rome's "other" neighborhood- narrow, twisty streets small shops, Osterias, craft shops very charming kind of Rome's bohemian district - several beautiful ancient churches, St Francis Ripa Grande, etc. Worth a few hours - walk over Sisto Bridge or the bridge from the Ghetto section or take H bus from the termini

Great area of Rome. We were lucky enough to rent an apartment here for 3 nights. Great food nearby and the Colloseum was only about a 20 minute walk across the river. I would definitely stay in this neighborhood our next time in Rome.

Nice area to wander. We visited the Church of Santa Cecilia (reviewed separately) and then strolled around and found somewhere for dinner. Lots of quaint little streets and lots of atmosphere, I'm very glad we went

There are better places to visit in Rome !. We had read various review raving about this part of Rome....unfortunately we were left feeling more than underwhelmed, after wandering for over an hour though what was described as funky, bohemian and interesting streets with lots of independent retail spaces.....we found it all a little dull...don't waste your time making the trip !

Old but good. Good food, some shopping and nightlife, do not dine in restaurants aimed at tourists: you will miss the essence of Trastevere. Ask the concierge for advise. If we are in Rome, we camp here. It is centrally located, just a stroll to the Vatican, Campo De Fiori and Piazza di Spagna shops.

four day birthday stay. visited here with the husband for his 40th birthday wanted to do something different, was an amazing four days, stayed in hotel san francesco in trastevere, which i`ve already reviewed, there is so many streets that all look the same whilst walking around, there are lots of bars and restaurants to visit depending on what you like to eat, we ate at a place called Antica osteria food was very nice the waitress was great and dealt with use asap it was a very busy evening but most evening in there seamed busy , we found a pub/caffe called big hilda that was very nice and the staff were very friendly, a nice little town with plenty of shops and on an evening they had little stalls selling trinkets and jewelry items, however i did find many places to be graffitied on around trastevere that spoilt the look of the place.

Great spot. Brilliant area for our first visit to Rome. Winding streets, cafes bars and shops, we walked our socks off. Street entertainment in the Piazza's, ice cream galore. Surely a good introduction everyone should find some aspect they'd enjoy, tourist's well catered for.

Buzzing at Night. Taken there to sample a local speciality of "Pesce Alla Romana". Fish and chips to me, but very enjoyable. the Trastevere area is buzzing with night life and is well worth the visit.
Very Nice area! . A must visit when you are in Rome! Nice places to eat, cute little streets and friendly people. A very relext vibe in this part of town!

Fun lively area. It is sooo lively at night, full of bars,restaurant and small boutiques. Little alleys , beautiful architectures, colors, painting , small fountains, a fun area to go around and eat and drink. Very touristic too, so not all the restaurants are good.

Great nightlife in Rome. We went to G-Bar where the beer Heineken pint just cost 3.5euros. I had 3 pints before walking back to paola terminal. Apart from that the place also selling a lot of things on the street.

Get a feel of Rome!. I just walked around the place. It was good. Got a nice experience of one of the happening parts of the city. The place also serves some of the best pizza and drinks in Rome. Don't miss out on that.

Must Visit Neighborhood in Rome. All of my friends' recommendations for Rome including going to Trastevere at night. I'm so glad I went! Especially at night, this area is lively with all of the restaurants, artists, and people walking around. It reminded me a bit of South Beach meets Italy. Highly recommend getting dinner/drinks here for at least one night. I also came during the day on a bike tour and that was fun as well.
Don't forget Trastevere. so nice to visit and also during the evening with all the small restaurants and little shops. That is the living part of Rome.There is music, expensive and cheap restaurants.
Best Neighborhood. The best town in Rome! I lived here for half a year-- and the food and drinks are by far the best in the entire city. You can't go wrong going out in this part of town.

Rome via Florance, Pizza and Lake Garda.. Had a 3 week driving trip through Italy, stayed in Rome for 4 days, wonderful!! Words cannot describe the vibe here, just have a glass of wine, some local food and soak it up!!!

Eating in Trastevere. This area was recommended to us by friends who have visited and even stayed in the area. We found the best eateries which were not expensive but served great food. Walking round after dinner was great, we loved the atmosphere of the whole area. You'll find the good eateries have people standing around waiting for tables to become available, always a good sign.

Slowly becoming a tourist trap.. The Trastevere quarter is charming, narrow streets, mostly 2-4 story buildings and pirroresque squares.Trastevere used to be a hidden gem, with lots of small restaurants and little shops.During the past years however, the number of tourists in Trastevere increased dramatically.Prices (of most bars and restaurants) went up and are now comparable with for instance the Campo dei Fiori at the other side of the Tiber river.If you've got plenty of time in Rome, you can visit Trastevere. If you are in a hurry, forget it and concentrate on Rome's major attractions.

Charming area with great restaurants and interesting street vendors. We went to Trastevere on the recommendation of an Italian friend of mine prior to leaving home. We had a lovely evening walking down the narrow streets, browsing the wares of the street vendors and eating at Ristorante Pizzeria. I bought a lovely unique necklace at one of the vendors (they are willing to negotiate price). For dinner we had an authentic pizza dinner accompanied with a salad and a bottle of prosecco for a very reasonable price (the bottle of prosecco was only 12 Euros). Definitely worth a visit...best to go in the evening as it is vibrant and lively.
Turn and turn. This is a wonderful back alley area. You can shop and eat and just enjoy the city here. It faces the water and has tons of little places for example Bacco in Trastevere.
So beautiful. . Trastevere is the part of Rome I liked most. It seems to be a little less touristisized than what seems to be the bigger part of Rome.The people here are more friendly and open.

Charming and quiet. Great area for a relaxing walk with plenty to see, have a nice meal, get lost in the little streets and maybe a meet grumpy local shop owner. Genuine piece of Italy, away from huge tourist groups.

Didn't love Trastevere - good for a short visit but not to stay here~. Not my favorite! Perhaps its because we usually stay in the Via Veneto area, which is probably just as opposite as you can get, but, this last may we rented a little condo and thought it would be fun to stay in Trastevere. Its fun for a few hours, but having been to Rome over 25 times, I can't say that I loved the area. Maybe if your in your 20's and its all you're use to, its great, but I did feel it was dirtier, a bit tacky, great restaurants though, but overall - won't stay in this area again.

Really Roman. If I ever got yo live Rome, this is where I would end up. Classic Roman living and unbelievable restaurants far away from the tourist traps of central Rome. Find the hidden restaurants and taste differences in the detail of the Roman chef.

Rent of apartment at Vicolo Del Bologna 15, trastevere, by Owner Signorita Annarita Caselli. We rented a quite nice little apartment on the 3. floor of Vicolo del Bologna 15 in Trastevere, Rome. But, over severel days, there were problems with the shower - the water ran down to the neighbor below, so we could not shower for a period of severel days. Thats not funny in Rome in the middle of the summer. After plummers finally have fixed the shower, the toilet stopped. The owner Signorita Anna was nice, but did not offer us another place to stay. Maybe she did not have any other free apartment ( she has 3 on rent basis ), but what should we do ? We were called home because of an emergency 3 days before the ordinary travel home, and the call came in fact very convenince, regarding the bad pipes in the apartment, pipes which the last day delivered a very bad smell of toilet all over the apartment. It was not suitable to eat, sleep or stay in at all. The owner offered a refund of 100 euro, which we found was to little for 3-4 days of distress. Not been able to shower or use the toilet is not a relaxed vacation. The plummers couldnt take care of before 2 days after, at one time. The owner didnt even answer my calls the first many hours after the toilet stopped, and the shower was appartly connected to the same pipes as the shower, so there was something i cant mention here also in the shower...Thats not good enough.

Interesting, Calmer Neighborhood in Rome. Neighborhoods like Trastevere are much more interesting to me (especially during high-tourist mob season) than the iconic monument sites in any major tourist-destination city. Neighborhoods like this are much quieter, the restaurants are more typical (and cheaper) and food quality is better, too. This is a great neighborhood for wandering any time of day and late into the evening. It is very much a residential neighborhood, but there are lots of shops and restaurants as well. I never figured-out the bus system in Rome, so I walked everywhere. Rome is not big on benches to rest your weary feet, so wear comfortable shoes! Be sure to use the restroom when you stop in a café for water or coffee or food. Public restrooms are non-existent.

True Rome. It easily reach Trastevere and go very hard, because fall in love it. The food, beer and ice cream are everywhere. You will find street musicians and bands. If you come from the Colosseum, do not miss, Boca della Verita.
My favourite evening destination. My favourite place to hang around in the evenings, self-consciously cool area with lots of cafes and restos (and ice cream shops). Pleasant place for dinner.

Love this area!. Quaint bars, ivy on walls, artist's selling their wares, musicians playing, people eating at many outdoor cafe's... There is such a charm to this area and it was my favorite place to visit!

Sublime Italy!. This is the real Rome! yes the Spanish Steps etc are amazing, but this working class neighbourhood has an amazing atmosphere, with winding shady cobbled streets breaking out into courtyards and squares.Overflowing with restaurants and bars, you could spend a couple of days here and still not know it all. Cross the Tevere by the pedestrianised Ponte Sisto bridge and go left or right from there and you will find colour, greenery and the real Rome. There are street sellers of jewellery, a number of clothing, leather shops. Some amaxong quirky designs in Carlo Cecchino not far from the road along the river.....the list is endless and the atmosphere amazing, night or day.
A different Rome. Trastevere is really different from the center with it's small streets and the living atmosphere. It is a city in the city. Just walk around and discover this part of the city.

Hip Area in prior Working Quarters.... Hip Trastevere is Rome's hot area to live for the locals, and to visit by we tourists alike. Just across the Tiber from SW Rome & key areas. Lots of restaurants & shops, plus easy scenic walking. Enjoy...

The best part of Rome!. I loved the Trastevere area. This would be reason enough to come back to Rome. The old, quaintness of the streets and buildings are so lovely! And not to mention the bars and nightlife there too! I highly recommended spending a lot of time here.

Home away from home. Trastevere is a lovely place that makes you feel home away from home. The vibe is very relaxed and every single street is beautiful. Here you can absorb the Italian lifestyle when it comes to enjoy dinner or a drink. There are many restaurants which serve fantastic food and hospitality. We've had dinner here every day of our stay and I recommend this to anyone who wants to experience la dolce vita!

Great neighborhood to explore. This is a great neighborhood to explore! It's close enough to the city center that you can walk but far enough away to feel like you're in another world. Sit in a cafe, enjoy a meal or wander around and take in the architecture of the homes and businesses. There's plenty to see and explore and is a nice change of pace from the busy tourist attractions and hustle and bustle of the city.

Great Area to Eat, Shop and Wander. Its a great place to get lost and find the little shops and bars. Its full of people in the evenings and great for the evening walk. Though take note do not walk after midnight on some bridges as bands of robbers are known to attack and rob you. My son was told not to go on this one particular bridge after midnight but seeing there were 100's of people on it thought it was safe. He and his friend were attacked (not hurt thankfully) by a group of 10 non Italians and his necklace was ripped off his neck.
Nice area to explore. Good alternative area to explore in Rome, not as busy as some parts of tourist Rome but I would say it will catch up.

Restaurants and Pubs plus a little history. Located across the Tiber river from ancient Rome....Many fine restaurants, pubs and clubs, night life reside over in Trastevere. Also within the area is the church and piazza Santa Maria in Trastevere.

Dr Jekill and Mr Hide. Empty during the day (or is it just calm after the visit of the monuments on the other side of the river?), this neighborhood turns to be the best one at night with dozens of options to drink and/or eat. With the public market on the river sides, you got some more animations if needed. We came back three times during our week in Roma!

Charming.. Charming. Full of lovely architectural buildings. Pizzerias outdoor cafés full of character.Easily assemble com the hotel by walking down a few flights if steps or in a can for a few Euros.

Grazie & Graziella Motto- Free smiles from Trastevere!. This area of Rome was introduced to us on our first evening as we took a Rome by Night Tour. This is where the locals go. Cobbled winding streets bustling with fabulous restaurants, outside on the streets and inside too. We were so impressed we ate there all 3 nights of our stay, at different ones but the best by far was Grazia & Graziella. The owner chatted with us as we waited for our table, it was bustling,supplying us with samples of his family's Prosecco from their vineyard. The food was fabulous, the service excellent! we stayed all night, as it was our last. This is definitely Italian cuisine at its best. Ace value for money! Atmosphere awesome.

The young life district in Rome!. This is definitely the best place for spending an afternoon walking around narrow streets, finding small but great places for dinner, coffee or a drink!
Don't miss a gelatto!
The bridge view is great for watching the sunset.
You can have also a good experience having lunch in the tents at the river level.
The place to dine. If you want to dine authentically while you're in Rome, this is were you need to go. Vibrant and full of bars, restaurants, etc

Lovely wander through old Rome. Great time wandering through the old streets of this lovely part of Rome. Great bars and cafes, gelato shops and fountains with plenty of charm. Will have to return to spend longer appreciating it all...
Great neighborhood with excellent restaurants. Great neighborhood with excellent restaurants and lots of local culture. Off the beaten path so there are less tourists!

Great in the evening. A short stroll across the Ponte Sisto from the Centro Storico, Trastevere lies on the west side of the Tiber (Tevere - hence the name). Lots of restaurants and bars in cobbled streets and many piazzas. Summer time bars and restaurants along the river bank too. A few good churches if you're looking for sights, but more of a place to wander and soak up the atmosphere.
Nice and cool area!. Very charming area of the city. Lots of small cafes and restaurants to enjoy some time at. Walk around, get lost and find your way again!

Trastevere - Charming district in Rome. Trastevere District is a lovely area of Rome to visit. Located on the west side of the Tiber River southeast of the Vatican and Janiculum, Trastevere is where you can find many narrow, sleepy streets and smaller piazzas lined with cafes, bars and picturesque homes In addition to the attractive setting of Trastevere, there is a nice collection of churches to visit here as well. San Francesco a Ripa Grande houses a Bernini masterpiece sculpture, while Santa Maria Cecilia and Basilica di Santa Maria in Trastevere make for beautiful church visits. Many enjoy staying in Trastevere based hotels but you can also conveniently visit this area of Rome, via the bridges that link to Campo de Fiori and Aventine areas of the city centre. Overall, we really like spending time in Trastevere district of Rome. What the area lacks in high impact attractions, it makes up for in charm and leisurely passing of time. It is a neat area of Rome that is worth checking out during visits.

The coolest area of Rome. Trastevere is definitely the coolest area of Rome. You'll find a lot of nice restaurants, winebars, shops, colorfull buildings and tiny streets. It's nice to walk around here and feel like your'e in a Bertolli commercial ;)
Lovely neighbourhood!. Bohemian neighborhood, music everywhere, loads of stalls with fake stuff for sale, loads of restaurants and bars.Lovely place to walk around in the night time.
Quaint neighborhood. I walked around this neighborhood all day admiring the local shops and how the Romans lived. The church and small squares are a must see!
NICE NEIGHBORHOOD. Trastevere is the spirit of Rome, with a lot of places and churches to visit. The restaurants and coffe places are amazing !!!

Roman Holiday. We loved staying in this spacious 1 bedroom! On a wonderful side street right in the heart of Trastevere, you are close to the action but not to the noise. Great places to eat and little markets close by. Delicious gelato right around the corner. A 5 minute walk and you are across the bridge and into another old Roman neighborhood - close to Piazza Navona. We even walked home (30 min) from Vatican City along the river. Wonderful! You really feel like you are living the Roman life.

Cool, hipster and beautiful Trastevere. This area is young, fun and has a cool hipster vibe! There are tons of restaurants to choose from, alot of which only serve real Italian food, not just the food aimed at tourists. Most places did gluten free pizzas which is a bonus! The area is clean and safe and they are really strong on recycling. Just 20 minutes from the Vatican City and about 30 from Rome center and the bus line is very regular. A perfect place to dray while in Rome!

One of my favourite neighbourhoods in Rome!. I LOVE Trastevere... it is exactly what you imagine when you imagine Rome.. Tiny cobblestone streets, little cafes and winebars, hanging vines and flowers in the windows.. it almost looks like you are walking around the set of a film. There are great restaurants and it's an amazing place to people watch!

If you're looking for 'la vera Italia'. If what you're looking for during your trip is to feel like you're in an italian movie you MUST go to Trastevere in Rome. By far my favorite part of this historical city. Amuse yourself with the colorful buildings and the street art in the walls and eat while you eat a huge gelato to cool off
Must see. Very nice part of the city. you can feel Roman spirit there. There are many restaurants and cafes in which you can try traditional Roman food.

A must when in Rome. Many Restaurants to choose from, some of the best. Its just across the bridge from Campo di Fiori. They also have white tents set up every night under the bridge with many more places to eat , play games, etc. Fun to walk thru.

Beautiful neighbourhood. What a brilliant neighbourhood!I thoroughly recommend paying a visit to this neighbourhood, situated in the south west of the city. Narrow, cobbled streets sets a beautiful scene with plenty of restaurants to choose from with amazing food and drink.Also recommend the slightly arduous climb up Gianicolo hill that provides amazing views over Rome.

must see part of rome. We were there 2 times in different years.. every time it was exciting for us.. very old part with excellent but a little bit overpriced restaurants.. tips: on the last part of trastevere you should take a tram to Piazza del Republicca

Reasonable for Rome. Perfect area to stay in when visiting Rome. The tram is a 5 minute ride from the heart of Rome and it has everything you need. Lots of shops and restaurants and the accommodation is a lot more reasonably priced!

Narrow Italian streets. Beautiful area to stay, when in Rome, narrow old streets with nice restaurants, close to everything in Rome. We went everywhere on foot and our accomodation at BB Danilo was excellent. This was real Rome experience

nice.. really nice... It is a nice place to visit. If you go there in the evening you can walk by the river and enjoy the atmosphere.If you dont like flies get some repellers with you.I prefered inside landnmark part.I recomend tyo to walk around at first.I prefered mid parts as the strreet singers and activities are mostly occurd in the mid parts.I loved appetisers.Deluxe potatoes with cheese salt and pepper. spagetti and piszza is also nice.If you love drinking you should look for small pub -bar types.If you have a limited budget try happy hour times. about 15 30-17 00 look for happy hours for lots of food:)bio gelateria was my favorite clean and delicious..try to spend as many time as you can durung the evening...

A wonderful place to see, listen, feel, smell and taste... Oh, how I would love to be there again! The place is amazing with its alleys and paved streets, haunting smells coming from the trattorias and the flowers all around and its houses full of tales.

Lovers rendez-vous. A beautiful and always nostalgic place to find pure Roman atmosphereAt first, it is calm and very nice pace but little by little you will find it warm and active face.It is recommended to pass hours there taking coffee or dinner.Do not miss the opportunity of hanging out with other tourists or local person.

Great Place to Stay for Young People. My 2 daughters and I spent 10 days in a rented apartment at the heart of Trastevere in the Summer of 2014. It was simply a great area from which to explore the city. Great little restaurants were nearby, as were coffee shops, grocery stores, museums, churches, the night market by the Tiber, and many more attractions. I would return in the blink of an eye. The fact that on weekends the area was popular until thee wee hours of the morning with young folks on scooters did not bother us a bit. Comes with being trendy. :-)

Great area with great restaurants. Despite the fact that it was raining for a while when we went to Trastevere it is a very nice area filled with great restaurants we tried 3 of these restaurants.. Recommended!!
Night walk. While the Tiber river lazily meanders thousands of lights twinkling walkers who let the relaxed atmosphere of small cafes and convenience store ... perfect night out.

A must see when you are in Rome. Very nice area, very relaxed atmosphere, narrow streets and small bats and restaurants, no rush and ver nice to hang around and explore the area. it looks like a small village within the crowded city of Rome

Touring Trastevere and tasting the delicious local foods and restaurants in the neighborhood. I love walking around Rome and trying all the local foods. One of my favorite spots to visit is the Trastevere and trying the many food venues there is amazing. Here are some of the highlights of my visit there including some wonderful food stops http://travelphotodiscovery.com/trastevere-tasting-specialty-and-local-foods/

Beautiful, magical, romantic. Be there on Friday night, all the little restaurants open, are very cheap()!, and there is plenty of vegan and gluten free food, good wine, artists are playing music all the time, and craftsmen sell their jewelry in little stalls. It is the most romantic place in Rome.

Best place to stay in Rome if you don't want to feel like a tourist. We stayed in Trastevere for seven days and felt so completely at home in this beautiful area of Rome. By day you'll find good coffee shops and some great shopping boutiques down Via di S. Francesco a Ripa. At night the area comes alive with masses of people descending on the major thoroughfare Viale Trastevere. Yes, there are lots of bars and restaurants around here but beware, along Viale Trastevere and also Via della Lungaretta, there is also a lot of places that cater to tourists who are visiting the area briefly (except Pizzaria Ai Marmi which does amazing Roman pizzas with slightly offhand service). Generally, you'll do much better on the quieter side of Trastevere i.e. go the opposite direction to the Viale Trastevere crowd. A number of the really highly rated Trastevere restaurants are in this quieter section of Trastevere up near Santa Cecilia. During the day you can wonder the narrow cobblestone streets and feel like you are a local away from the tourist mayhem of Rome. You can also take in a number of very historical churches - Santa Maria of Trastevere is one of the oldest churches in Rome and has beautiful mosaics. The area has a number of touching local things that you don't see everywhere in Rome - like the little gold stars on the footpath outside a house where a Jewish family was removed during the Second World War - outside the house there is one star for each family member that died during the Holocaust, just something the community did to remember them. That's Trastevere for me, rather than the raucous nightlife of Viale Trastevere.

A must-see neighborhood in Rome. Easily accessible by bus, a bustling, quirky neighborhood with bright orange lights, cobbled streets, lots of food options, art stalls, souvenir shops and random bursts of street activity. We saw a funny magician in one of the piazzas AND we ate at a delicious restaurant!

Great way to end each say. We stayed at the Hotel Ponte Sisto and just walked across the bridge each night. Wonderful sights, sounds and food can be found everywhere. We ate dinner three nights in a row, at different places each night. All very good. Prices did vary so choose the right spot for you. We enjoyed beautiful streets, and doyen gelato and pastries as well. Easy and calm away from the hustle and bustle. Well worth a stroll or three.

Wow, drinking!!!!. We were here 3 nights in a row. Perfect for nightlife, pubs, bars, restaurants, late night good, anything you might want..there is something for everyone. This summer there were also alot of bars and restaurants by the river, never ending!!! Definitely the best place to go for a night out.

Summer Night Markets. Perfectly picturesque...imagine the cool River Tiber running past on a stuffy hot night, and finding a white canopied world under the arches of the bridges on the waters edge. Yes, the market stalls aren't bargains, reflected in the touristy tat mixed in with locals playing arcade games, and the left side of the stalls were definitely better than those to the right of the bridge, BUT, it is still worthwhile going down for a break from "Above ground Rome." The food tends to be more eclectic with Mexican, kebab and American food, catering to both tourists and locals every evening. The food isn't excellent, this isn't the Gourmet pop ups we had expected. We ate at a Mexican/American restaurant which looked amazing. Imagine the white canopied tents, couches, white painted furniture to match the picket fences with planters hanging over the waters edge filled with pink flowers, who could resist?! To be honest, we should of! Between the four of us, we had 2 Margareitas, 2 soft drinks, and 4 main courses. One was a portion of Nachos, unfortunately full of mince to a rather miffed Vegetarian, 2 had the Vegetarian Quesdillas, which weren't the flat dry fried versions we are acustomed to at home, but more like microwaved rolled up wraps bursting with stringy Mozerella, and poorly chopped and unevenly distributed jalapeños! I had chicken fajitas. Chicken was moist, but it was drenched in sauce, and you only had one wrap. So the rest was like eating a tomatoey curry with the remaining rice and salad.
