Happening and fun, see where younger Romans congregate. Restauants, happy faces and wonderful, fun shops. Steps and walking will provide you with a peek inside where the youth go.
THIS PLACE ROCKS!. I just love this area it has the most beautiful streets in all of Rome filled with pubs,restaurants pizzerias , wine bars it is the equivalent to new yorks soho. filled with life!

Arrive, Unpack and soak up the Atmosphere.. Amazing part of Rome which we stayed at, on our first ever visit to the city.Bars. Restaurants, Botanical Gardens, Aperetivo, Bakeries, more Bars. Heaven.Went to all parts of Rome on our visit but i would not have wanted to stay anywhere different. Lots of my reviews on the places we visited in seperate entries.Just go, you will love it.
A must see. Everything is amazing in this part of Rome, people, food, atmosphere!!! The real Rome is here, definitely my favourite area!
Bring good shoes. Lots of fun little bars and restaurants. Lots of neat shops...Lots of steps. People are lovely and lively.

Cheap and youthful!. We took a trip over on a Sunday night as we didn't have a bus ticket pre bought on the Saturday. The area was quiet and not many people about but went we did find a strip of restaurants and bars they seemed to be a lot of American Students.I wouldn't make make the trip over again if I returned to Rome as there are plenty more places and nicer restaurants closer to the city Centre. The place we decided to eat in was busy and cheap but the overall service was poor and unwelcoming.
A must to walk through . Full of great little hidden shops and lots of places/choices to eat. This place is even better at night. True roman experience.
Must go to when in Rome!. Put your walking shoes on for an incredible experience! People, atmosphere, food, all fabulous. One of my favorite places.

Not convinced it's the "real" Rome any more.. Trastevere is a pleasant part of the city, and larger than I expected. A lot is made of it being the "real" Rome - while it is undoubtedly more representative of how the city used to be a good while ago, I think claiming this makes it the real rome is misleading. The sudden appearance of flashing neon signs (pharmacies, etc.) does somewhat spoil the old feeling when exploring. That said, it is an interesting place to wander around - lots of old housing, interspersed with pleasant churches, small Piazzas and a rather large school (avoid the end of the school day!). There are restaurants that appear out of nowhere, some of them quite good, others more touristy. Try ones a little away from the main attractions (Santa Maria, for example) and you should do better. There are lots of little streets here that can be a little disorientating at first, but nowhere is too far from the main streets either side and the river, so it is easy to locate yourself with a few minutes walk.
Beautiful area. Such a beautiful area to just walk around and see the real Rome. Not too touristy and a lot of really good restaurants.
for the night!!. we spent 5 nights in rome and all 5 we had them spent in trastevere!!!great for drinks and food and walks!!!the best place to enjoy the italian nights!!!

The real Rome. Historic neighbourhood, a formerly working-class district. Let yourself get lost in a maze of narrow, cobbled lanes flanked by tables and bikes, casually parked in front of the ivy clad façades. Charming and vibrant quarter with the beautiful Santa Maria in Trastevere on the lively piazza, and a wealth of romantic restaurants and cosy cafés. A truly enjoyable experience.

Great place to stay. Just over the river from the historical sites which are an easy walk or tram ride. Full of narrow streets with a huge range of shops, restaurants and bars. Very lively with a lot of pedestrian streets so you can avoid the roar of the traffic of the main part of the city.
Authentic. The best area to get a real feel of Rome. Lots of restaurants and lovely little back streets with bars/cafes.

Kind of bohemian place with great restaurants and nice looking streets. This neighbourhood in Rome is wonderful for a weekend walk, with no stress and some time to get lost around the small streets, visiting stores and trying new restaurants. Very nice place to photograph and close to the Vatican, so you can visit the St Pieters Square after lunch.

How Romans Really Live. We visited all of the ancient history sites all over Rome, but to get a taste of what Rome is today you really need to visit Trastevere. This is where the true Romans live... great food and shopping!
My wife loved it..... Trastavere is a quaint little neighborhood on the other side of the Tiber, and was one of my wife's favorite stops. It's great to walk around in the evening.
Trastevere. The Trastevere area is a must see for anyone traveling to Rome. Many excellent restaurants and interesting attractions. Highly Recommended!

Excellent place to stay on holidays. We made Trastevere home for 4 days whilst on holiday and could easily stay longer. The streets are filled with shops, restaurants and bars and vehicle traffic is minimal. It can be noisy at night if you decide to stay in Trastevere, but it is so conveniently located, around 30 minutes walk to all of the major sites, we were very happy with our choice.

Fun, Cute Neighborhood. We spent a full day here checking out the shops, restaurants, churches, outdoor market, etc. This little neighborhood has a nice vibe....not fancy, not too touristy, a bit more laid back (at least in the winter). Lots of good little restaurants and food shops. Would be especially nice on an uncrowded spring day when you can eat outside. If you are looking for a rowdy party area or lots of excitement, I'd go somewhere else. Seems like a good area to be based if you want to rent an apartment and stay a week or two and still be close to all the main attractions.

A pretty nice neighborhood. While in Rome and looking for something characteristic, I would like to strongly suggest a walk in Trastevere. The best time is in the afternoon of a sunny day. You can do shopping on the streets and at dinner time enjoy the popular food from the many small restaurants there. Later on before leaving why do not stop on a bar and take the true Italian coffee or a tasty ice cream before closing a beautiful day in Rome.

Best typical place for drinks in Rome. We were told to go here by our hotel staff the Hotel Giolli in Rome. Trastevere turned out to be very full of international people, cheap drinks, good music and a great vibe.! One of the best nights I had in Rome.!

A nice vibe . Just come back from a lovely stroll around. Nice to get slightly Out if the city and enjoy a new place/part of town. Food and drink prices are cheaper and there are very restaurants and bars to enjoy and try.

Not worth the time, go Trilusa instead!. Visited Trastevere at a saturday night. Not that lively, neither has fancy restaurants. Absolutely poor experience. Walk a minute or two to Trilusa for a much lively and quality neightborhood.

Must go. beautiful place to go for a walk next to the river, it has many streets and all them are beautiful. I got lost but actually i'm glad to got lost cause it awesome to see that place. A lot of restaurants and small stores to visit. Great

Lovely buildings. Lovely photographic buildings, quiet streets lined with cafes and restaurants. Interesting walk, and fantastic panificio we found with every delectable delight for a little cost. Bit boring for teenagers to wander around though.

Do it like the Romans do. Really nice place to go out and enjoy your evenings with good food and bars. Just start your evening there and do it like the Romans do. Enjoy your meal, drink a good vine, watch the street artists and meet lots of nice people there. Also very nice for couples to enjoy time together.

Best neighbourhood in Rome!. Neighbourhood frozen in time...out of main tourist routes...with plenty nice places to eat pizza, gelato,...
Neighbourhood for meditational wanderings...
Best neighbourhood in Rome!
Great . Transtereve is a small neighbourhood away from the city center. You'll find here a bohemian vibe: tiny streets, nice cafes and bars, souvenir shops.

good for a day of exploration (at least). Stayed in this neighborhood I'd not visited on my two previous trips to Rome. But now that I've seen most of the typical Rome highlights, it was time to investigate new places. Numerous lovely churches here and interesting, narrow streets to walk.

when in rome..... Live like a local. We were lucky to stay with our daughter who lives in Trastevere and showed us her Rome. This area is the genuine lifestyle of a modern Roman. Great bars and cafes, fantastic food at real prices. The buildings are like a postcard. Walking through the main area at night is lovely.Don't drive in Rome, they're crazy. The public transport will not totally reliable will get you there for a good price. Embrace the culture and live like a local.Drink your coffee standing up at the bar, espresso only.Use as much Italian as you can, they do appreciate the attempt, and will reply in English.Its not bad to eat pizza every day really, it is that good.Walk everywhere and take the time to look around, you are in Rome!
Buzzing atmosphere. Really good place to go for dinner and drinks. Great atmosphere in most places. Good buzz in general

Great ambience. Nice neighbourhood away from touristic places. Still feels like authentic Roma or at least what I imagine it to be. Full of life with restaurants, bars, musicians, students & Romans outside till late at night. Perfect for staying here and visiting the city most important sites during the day. You still find some very good restaurants as well.

Walking around the true Rome. Everytime I am in Rome I can't resist the temptation to lost in this traditional part of this wonderful city. Discovering churches, old buildings and last but not least very good trattorie. I just sugget you walking around, taking pictures and sitting in a cafè drinking a cappuccino with some pastry. Several interesting museums are in this area. In the evening the atmosphere is very nice, plenty of people, music, and if you want to savor typical roman cuisine you should make a reservation cause could be difficult to find a place.

Great little neighborhood just outside the city center. In deciding where to stay, we struggled with staying in the middle of the city center where everything is at, or just outside, but still walking distance. We are so happy with went with the Trastavere neighborhood - quieter, hardly any traffic, GREAT restaurants, a little nightlife in the Piazza Santa Maria Trastavere. It is a bit of a walk though...probably 30 minutes up to Villa Borghese & Spanish Steps area (about 2 miles), moving at a decent pace. And it was probably 30 minutes to the Colosseum. Vatican was much closer since it is also on the west side of the river. If you stay out here, get a map and go to the church at the top of the hill, then keep going up another 10 minutes to the lookout. Great exercise, and great views.If I return, I would stay in this neighborhood again because the I just don't care for the crazy traffic in the main area. And did I mention GREAT restaurants???

Must do in Rome. Ok this isn't exactly a particular site in Rome, it's more like a alternate side of Rome which has the best food and laidback feeling. While rest of main Rome is hustle and bustle, Trastevere is more of people friendly section with some of the most iconic beautiful alleys that Rome has to offer. Pro-tip: See the big sites of Rome then get a taxi to Trastevere for a relaxing stroll through the alleys then pick a restaurant with a menu only in Italian if possible, we all know what spaghetti, or what a margherita pizza is. So a menu in only Italian suggest a good restaurant FOR local Italians! Avoid tourist traps with menus in 4 different languages! Try the delicious "Suppli" if possible, it's a fried ball of rice, with mozzarella cheese inside. You'll thank me later!

Great Neighborhood, Excellent Food. This is my second time to Rome. I visited Trestevere the first trip and knew I wanted to stay here the second. The locals are very friendly and helpful, and the food is excellent. I have not had a bad meal anywhere in this city, and especially Trestevere. It is definitely a "must see".

Very Quaint. It was our last day in Rome and we wanted to just explore. A friend had mentioned the Trastevere area so we walked from our hotel - 30minutes from the Trevi area. It was truly adorable, and a hidden treasure. MUCH quieter and much less crowded than the city center. Small cobble stone streets, restaurants, and shops. The music only added to the ambience!
Worth a visit. Brilliant to walk around to get some real Roman culture. Great for food and restaurants away from the tourist areas.

Must visit. Was recommended to visit Trastevere by a friend who had been in Rome before. We went on our last night and wish we had visited before! Lovely pedestrian place, lots of cobbled streets with boutique shops and restaurants and unique bars. We didn't have any plan, just wandered round and went to a lovely restaurant called Coja and goja. Would be nice area in the day time too.

Trastevere is a family's paradise to visit. We took the kids to Trastevere at dusk yesterday for some relaxation and dinner. The cobblestone medieval streets filled in local Italian artisans and music everywhere was magical. My kids loved getting necklaces made in front of them by a talented jewelry maker and it was 10E for the masterpiece. The church of Santa Maria was also fascinating with its mismatched columns stolen from Roman sites. Had a prefix dinner (where it is appetizer, first course, second course and dessert for one price) at a local restaurant for 15E and it was a great meal.Down side- more Americans per capita than anywhere else in Rome with their Rick Steves books in tow.

Lovely area. We were undecided on what to do for our last day in Rome and decided to just take off and explore this area. We had read a little bit on-line, but didn't know much at all about it. It is a hidden treasure indeed! A step back in time....very small cobble stone roads, fun little restaurants, and many open areas/squares at the end of roads where there is open air shops and entertainment. Highly recommended!
AMAZING FEELING!. We had a lovely walk and we felt like the time machine had turned us back in time! Atmosphere very warm , beautiful Italian sounds everywhere. We must return!

Must visit. One of hidden treasures of Rome, so much to see and do, great places to eat.If you visit during the Summer make sure you go to the Lungo Tevere festival, all along the riverbank you will find wine bars restaurants, craft stalls, artist, a real flavour of Italy.

Make the time. This area is full of life. Small streets full with nice shops, tasty restaurants and lively bars. Young people fill the streets. Also make so time to go into the Santa Maria di Trastevere. It is all worth it.

Such a nice area. If you want to get out of the busy crowded city center of Rome, this is the place you should go. Nice streets, nice shops, nice restaurants and terraces. Also a beautiful church to visit (1 of the 900 in this town but this one is worth the visit): Santa Maria in Trastevere.

exciting and engaging. I recommend everyone to visit and, if possible, "to live" this part of Rome, it is great to see how people live today and imagine what life was like in the past, it is a very central and easily reached on foot, full of great restaurants and night-clubs.

unique romantic experience. church choir at time we visited--little streets with pubs and restaurants. Many stalls selling things you can bargain and fortune tellers on every corner. Exciting.
Some characters there were kind of dodgy and creepy-some drunks and the area around trastevere very poor and not clean.Stick to the touristy-local busy areas of trastevere.

Lovely area full of atmosphere. The Santa Maria in Trastavere is beautiful and well worth a trip across the Tiber. It is a remarkably short walk any way although we took the confusing buses. Finding the right one going the right way was a problem and few bus drivers speak English so it was an adventure but worth it. The pallazio near the Church is a lovely place to sit and contemplate with a glass of wine. The restaurants in Trastavere are much cheaper and more atmospheric.

Great neighborhood to wander around. This old neighborhood is wonderful to wander around. Great restaurants. Narrow streets. Feels like you are in an old part of Rome that real Romans live in. I always recommend friends to go here at night to walk around and grab dinner.

The real Rome way of life in nowdays.. This part of the city shows how is to live in Rome now-days, but looking like in 1900's. This part of the city has a unique charm that you need to see with no rush.

Amazing. This is a must when in Rome. It is a lively warm area where u find loads of people and restaurants. You just stroll in the area and enjoy the delicious food in one of the thousand restaurants there, don't miss it
A great place to have lunch, dinner or to go out for a drink!. Especially nice to have dinner or a drink at night! Lots of restaurants and bars and a great atmosphere..

The best for food!. Trastevere is the place you should go for a nice lunch or a lovely evening in Rome. There is lots of affordable restaurants and bars. The neighbourhood itself has its little charm with cute boutiques and people selling boho handmade jewellery ... you will not be disappointed!!!

Away from the maddening crowd. We thought that it was about time to see something over the river from the city.We thought that Trastevere was very charming. More like a village than a suburb of the Eternal City. There are numerous cafes and some tourist traps for lunch, a charming church or two as well as some narrow medieval streets to wander.Return to the city over the island and see some more ruins that have been utilised by enterprising builders over the centuries.Well worth the walk.

A Roman Gem. We arrived in Trastevere in the late afternoon after sightseeing in Rome all day. I was nice but it took on a comfortable more romantic feeling in the evening as the sun set and the orange glow of the lights softly light the streets. There were street musicians and performers in the Piazza setting the mood for a great dinner. When I return I will definitely visit Trastevere again.

It hasit all. Trastevere is a place you want to be after your sightseeing day. Many lovely restaurants, be careful with tourist traps offering super cheap menus though....otherwise the atmosphere on the square is unforgettable.

A dream! 😍. Trastevere is definitely the place in which you want to hang out every night while you're in Rome! Filled with charming restaurants and bars, it holds an enchanting mood. You can eat some of the best pizza you have ever had and buy something from artesians from all over the world, it's a very articstic neighborhood with tiny boutiques to shop until you drop! You'll find it one of the most wonderful places in Rome. Definitely a most!

If you have run out of things to do in Rome. If you are near Piazza Venezia, cross the Tiber and enter Trastevere. Less touristy, a bit seedy with a different feel. From there, take the bus to the top of Gianicolo for a view of Rome.
Must go. Residential area just across the Tiber. Less tourists, wonderful places to eat and many important monuments and churches.
Love it. Beautiful town, lovely restaurants (particularly ivo de trastevere on Francesca a ripa), brilliant atmosphere. All round great place to stay

living Rome. If you want to see true Rome, go to Trastevere! Hanging laundry lines, old and colorful buildings, welcoming people- they are all part of the amazing Trastevere. I’ve even spotted an open air vegetable market…hard to find one in Rome! Besides this, prices are better.
Great Option for Dinners. Loved the overall atmosphere in this are. Lovely choice for outdoor seating and great food. A lot of options in one place, and the walk around is really wonderful.

A lovely Italian area not to miss. We crossed one of Rome's oldest bridges (by foot only) to Trastevere. What a lovely area to sit and people watch. It took us away from the typical, touristy areas for a relaxing cup of cappuccino and pastry. A must do for a delightful break in the busy tourist schedule

Bohemian Trastevere. Bohemian and stylish neighborhood across the Tiber river. Very quiet suburb during the daytime, a good alternative to busy city center. You can find a variety of Italian trattoria, cafes and quirky shops. A feelgood local flavor with hanging laundry lines, terracotta buildings and winding cobble- stoned streets.

WALKING TRASTEVERE. On my first visit to Rome in April 2014 I had the good fortune to be taken by my host, around Trastevere, where we spent the day eating, walking and doing what Iike most, taking photographs. Yes a great place to visit and yes you have to do it!
Wonderful place. This was a surprising region in Rome we were unaware of - greas narrow streets with many bars & restaurants and small shops & stalls - worth a few hours

we love trastevere!. My husband and I loved Trastevere! Especially the food! It was sooooo much better there rather than in the heart of rome! And much cheaper!
My blog has more info about our experience in Trastevere
https://danielle-greco-b8tb.squarespace.com/travel/

Be Prepared Before You Go. Since my husband and I aren't touristy tourists, we knew we wanted to explore and have dinner in Trastevere (rather than the center of Rome) but forgot to bring recommended addresses with us before walking there (and we didn't want to walk all the way back to our lodging to get the info). That was a huge mistake as we walked up and down streets in this neighborhood attempting to find a suitable restaurant. (We always look for the TripAdvisor sign.) A noticeable difference in Rome is the street hawkers to get you into their restaurant. This was also true in Trastevere. It is a charming area and doesn't have the large mobs of tourists in the heart of Rome but we did not make the most of our time there not knowing exactly where to go. (We ended up at a restaurant on a small street, facing walls of graffiti during dinner.) Unless you have a bounty of energy and unsore feet, I would not recommend "winging it," and just hoping to find something suitable without having some addresses and a map of the streets.
Pubs and Restaurants. Best area in Rome for eating and drinking at reasonable prices .Baccanale for great food and. Excellent customer service

Trastevere Twilight food and wine tour.... Terrific fun. Great food, great company and our leader Jasmine did a wonderful job, we laughed, we ate and ate and drank wonderful wine.Great introduction to this part of Rome. Highly recommended. This part of Rome is like the Greenwich village of New York. Great way to see another side of Rome…and a good introduction to this city.

The rule is:. Don´t leave Rome without hang out in Trastevere.Cool people, amazing pasta, wine, and a lot of pubs with cheap (and good) italian beer.The night in Trastevere is... the night in Trastevere. Just there.

Off the Rome grid. When you get tired of seeing yet another Madonna and child in the many Roman museums, cross the river and go to Trastevere, a neighborhood of Rome that few tourists visit. In addition to great cafés and restaurants, there is also great shopping. The pace is laid back and easy. There is a pizza restaurant there that is rumored to have the best in Rome. There is no sign outside so inquire with locals while you are walking around. You will be happy you did!

Old fashioned Rome - Where are the tourists ?. During the day you can wander around this area of Rome without being in crowds of tourists, There are a lot of quiet churches to visit and a hidden gem in one of them. nice friendly people.We found a lovely restaurant to eat and a small ice cream parlour opposite another church.If you walk up to the view point where there is a statue to Garibaldi you can also get a different view of the Vatican.

Real Rome. This was the Rome I was looking for, narrow streets with tall buildings all weaving on and out of each other. The people full of character and living life to the full, good basic food with so much flavour you can't believe what you have put up with before. Grab lunch from one of the small cafes and eat it round the steps of a fountain or outside one of the churches, wander the streets just soaking up the atmosphere and watching people go about their daily lives.

Gritty, lovely and lively.. When in Rome do cross the river in to this lively, lovely neighbourhood. Great little alleyways, great cafes and a feeling of the real Rome. We loved visiting here and will again should we return to Rome.

Lovely small Italian town. Trastevere is a lovely classic Italian small neighbourhood. Lots and lots of authentic restuarants and bars with friendly atmosphere that made us feel comfortable and pleasant. Nice to walk along the small cobblestoned roads surrounding the unique houses and the Piazza di Santa Maria especially in the early morning when it is still quiet. The morning market near the Piazza has lots of fresh and delicious fruits: grapes, plums, prunes, bananas, apricot, all of these that we enjoyed very much.
Great spot!. Character filled area, a maze of streets that reveal hidden delights. If you are even slightly fit you are in walking distance of all the major sights! Loved staying here!

Authentic Rome neighbourhood. off the beaten track but worth the time if you want to connect with the real Romans. Authentic restaurants, friendly atmosphere, nice streets to take a stroll. A few words of Italian will get you further.

A long walk. my wife and I took a long walk on a beautiful Sunday afternoon ,strolled down cobblestone streets , stopped in little shops bakeries cafes it was everything I thought Rome was going to be .

Party Central. Trastevere is a neighborhood of winding medieval streets, shops, restaurants, bars, with the beautiful Piazza Santa Maria and its church. The neighborhood is ever changing. Mornings start slowly with clean up from the previous night's revelry, and gradually by 10 things open up with coffee and cornetti. The market in the main piazza is open from 7 until 1:30 or so. By 1:30 the restaurants are in full swing, tables on the streets and in the piazza. But by 3, the neighborhood is quiet again and many places are closed. At 6 or 7 is when things really get going: tables lining all the streets, bars open, music, performers, hawkers, and the streets packed with people, the occasional car or motorbike squeezing through. We stayed in Trastevere in September and the party in the streets happened 7 nights a week, always until about 2 AM. It's a fun and colorful place to visit. La Boticella and Pianostrada Laboratoriodicucina were our favorite restaurants. One word of caution: The streets are very noisy until 2 every night. If you are staying in this area, you most likely will listen to the racket until the wee hours. And it can get loud with strolling accordion players, drummers. crowds singing in bars, music thumping. Not for light sleepers!

A fun area!. We decided to stay in this little part of Rome. It is a sorta " funky" part. Wonderful restaurants,wonderful. As is all over Italy,they are plentiful! Easy walking,evening fun activities and or happenings in the Piazza. A great Market by he Piazza. Lots of fresh fruits and vegetables . Opens erly am and seems to close about 1:30 week days. Great fresh cut meats,just every thing and great friendly folks operate them each. The real Italian smallish neighborhood section. They are very patient with my bad Italian language usage.A great variation from main part of Rome

A fab area for a night out with the locals. This is a great area for restaurants. Loads of little places to have good food and enjoy the local atmosphere. Prices are reasonable and the food is excellent. We ate in 3 different restaurants during our stay and each one was as good as the last. All fresh pasta, great pizzas and nice touches such as little shooters of liqueur on the house after your meal. Must be one of the best places in Rome to go to for food.

The way local Romans live. Great neighborhood, removed from the hustle and bustle of the main attractions.Peaceful restaurants that are priced for the locals. Quite cobblestone alleyways and tree lined streets.Great finds down every small street.We rented a apartment from VRBO and it was perfect, close to the main railroad that takes you to the cruise port in Cittavecchia. Also close to the tram that takes you to the main plaza area, near the Pantheon and Trevi Fountain.

Wonderful part of the city just to the South-West. Came here in the evening and wondered through the small street with its market stalls, street performers and many cafes and restaurants.Wonderful atmosphere...

Wonderful area with lot of atmosphere!. We walked around this area late afternoon and evening and found lots of interesting small alleys and piazzas, lovely bars and restaurants. Well worth a visit to this pretty area!

Trastevere Food Tour. We did the Eating Italy food tour in Trastevere and it could not have been better. Our tour guide, Jonathan, was wonderful. He provided us with history on the town, wine, and food as we went to 10 different locations. He even took us to the oldest pharmacy in Europe, which looked like something from Harry Potter (which I consider to be a good thing).
Lively area. A really nice district in Rome with a lot of character. Narrow streets, medieval houses and a lot of restaurants and bars.

Real Italy. Beautiful area of Rome - well worth a visit. The restaurants down the end nearest the botanical gardens are a good few euros cheaper than the ones in the centre. The ice cream places are all delicious. There is real charm to this place in the daytime, even though there is a buzzing night life, it is a great escape from the tour groups during the day.

Great neighborhood to explore.. There is very little car traffic, which makes this a much more pleasant area than other parts of Rome. The main plaza is a great place for people watching. There is some outstanding shopping opportunities, particularly for trendy clothes and shoes. There are also awesome gelaterias, coffee bars and restaurants of all sizes. It is easy to get to on the tram and is a very walkable neighborhood. The only drawback is that you are more likely to see tourists than locals and some of the eating establishments which cater to tourists are pretty mediocre. Do your restaurant research before you go to avoid being disappointed.
Must visit. An area that really makes you feel very cosy and gives you lots of choices to enjoy. You can drink your aperol spritz while you watch happy people walking in the colorfoul roads!

Cute neighbourhood on the other side of the river, Rome!. I actually really enjoyed walking across the river and wondering through the Trastevere neighbourhood... It was so calm and peaceful, compared hustle and bustle of touristy Rome on the other side of the river. If you don't have many days here, you don't really have to include it on your list of top things to do, but if you have at least 4 days, put in on your list of Top 10. There are a lot of local shops and restaurants on the little side streets that are more off-the beaten track and not as touristy as in the center of Rome. My husband and I like to walk a lot, so we had a really nice time walking around here.Enjoy this cute neighbourhood as we did!

A great place to stay….. We stayed in Trastevere during our recent visit to Rome and felt happy with our choice. Although its across the river from the main attractions it is walkable to most tourist locations. The area was a little more "touristy" than we had expected but lively and full of shops and restaurants, winding narrow streets, lovely piazzas and a true neighborhood atmosphere. The area is very safe even at night.

A Real Local Feel. We stayed in Trastevere during our visit and I am so glad we did. Although it is on the other side of the river from the tourist attractions, it was still only a short 15 minute walk from just about any of them. We absolutely LOVED staying in Trastevere. Its winding narrow streets of small shops and restaurants were exactly what we were looking for to experience Rome. At night, the streets were filled with people laughing, having a drink, or just walking quietly with each other. There were more more restauarants than I could count and we never found a single one we didn't love. The neighborhood is very safe, even late at night. You could spend numerous nights just walking around looking at all the people and scenery. It was a perfect end to each day after seeing the sights!

A true taste of Rome!. Trastevere was just across the Ponte Sisto bridge from our hotel and became our favorite place to walk and experience a tranquil, quaint area of Rome. As you wander through the lanes and piazzas, you feel that you have traveled back in time. A true neighborhood feeling, with family-run restaurants full of charm.

Authentic Rome. We loved this neighborhood for its architecture and local atmosphere. This is where we indulged in the arts, food and drinks. Hands down our favorite neighborhood in Rome! We had the best pizza yet at Bir & Fud as well as craft beers on tap across the way at Ma Che Siete Venuti A Fà. All you need in one neighborhood. If we get a chance to be in Rome again, we'll definitely spend most of our time in Trastevere.

Great neighborhood. This is the best place in Rome to get away from the touristy areas. Great restaurants (Tony's) and many others. Check out the river walk during the summer. Will go back and stay longer in this area.

I loved this neighborhood!. I was there in April and the word "magical" doesn't begin to describe how fun, delicious and exciting this area is. I stayed at the Donna Camilla Hotel (the former nunnery turned hotel) and we walked into the main area every evening for dinner and shopping and people watching beyond compare. The square featured street artists, groups of Asian travelers agog at the splendor of the place, a way too many students on holiday, and I loved it so much that I am going back in the dead of winter for my daughter's 25ht birthday. We were able to walk to the Vatican along the river, cross several bridges and have lovely antipasti and wine in several places.

Go there if you want to experience the real Rome. This is my favourite neighbourhood in Rome. It offers a slice of the most authentic Roman life. The restaurants serve authentic Roman fare at very reasonable prices. People speak Romano not Italian, which I love and also happen to understand!!! In the evening it's very lively. I just loved it! Don't you dare miss it!!
Nothing like it. One of the best places in Rome, long narrow streets, everyone is friendly! Many restaurants all with reasonable prices and great variety. U'll be lucky to find a table by the river.

When in Rome..... Last time we were in Rome we stayed on the other side of the Tiber, near the Spanish Steps. This time we wanted to get as close to the 'old' Roma as possible and we have achieved exactly that in Trastevere. This area just feels right... Old narrow cobbled streets, restaurants a'plenty, street buskers, noise and colour - and our hotel is smack in the middle of it. This area has an atmosphere that makes everyone feel happy, visitors, vendors and restaurant staff alike.

Beautiful Cobbled Old Roma!. Went there after an Italian guy in our flight to Rome said it was one of the best place to eat without being caught on a tourist trap. He was soo right! Lots of local compared to other places in Rome and are much more friendlier too.Beautiful narrow cobbled streets, boutique shops and nice trattorias with delicious authentic food ..that too reasonably prized. Great for an espresso/dessert or for lunch & dinner. take your pick. Also the walk to Trastevere is quite nice as you walk across the bridge over the Tiber river..spent the whole day and thought should have stayed in this lovely area.. Great lively neighborhood area and a must to visit if you are in Rome!!

Our real Rome. For me and my boyfriend Rome will always mean Trastevere. Long narrow streets, flowers at every window and corned anr small little cafes perfect for an espresso and tiramisu. If you're lucky like we were you'll catch a street musician playing his saxophone or a ballerina dancing with fire. Take a look at the street vendors and craftsmen, maybe you'll find your favorite ring like i did. It's made of jade - the stone of hope ;)

could it be more authentic?. Trastevere... You can smell, feel, taste the atmosphere there! The people are more friendly and authentic than the centre of Rome. At least we felt that. Lots of nice small restaurants and trattorias with excellent food and very friendly staff!

Best place in Rome. This is how we were expecting all of Rome to be. Best place to spend an afternoon+ evening, take a romantic walk, eat and drink (there are many affordable and delicious options). It was the only place in Rome where we could disconnect and actually enjoy ourselves (less crowded, stressful, without immigrants trying to sell us fake bags, without improvised 'bazaars' in the middle of the street) and it is the only place where we found that Italian atmosphere (romantic and joyful) we were looking for in Rome. The narrow streets and the colorful houses make a beautiful setting for photos.Tip: rent a scooter from Trastevere and go up to Gianicolo Hill for a wonderful panoramic view of Rome

An escape from the 'madness' of central Rome. We loved our self-guided walking tour through Trastevere. What a delightful neighbourhood with very few tourists. Great coffee places and small restaurants to grab a bite, some interesting churches and museums and just great streets for those of us that like urban walks and discoveries. If the metro was closer, I'd even prefer to stay in this area. We were there for a full day and felt energized after our walking tour. Noname Caffe was a great discovery for coffee and sandwiches. Our only disappointment was that the Villa Farnesina closes daily at 1 p.m. so we missed the unique collections there. Start at Tiber Island, where you can have the best gelati in all of Rome, and then wander around Trastevere.

My favorite place in Rome. This is a brief of a fresh air after crowded touristic places of Rome, full of cozy restaurants, bars, fun of the nightlife. There you can find nice unique shops. There is just that relaxed atmosphere.
Authentic area in Rome. If you're looking for a less touristic and more authentic aerea in Rome - go to Trastevere! You'll find wonderful restaurants, bars, little shops and even small markets there.

The Real Rome. A great place to wander the streets, eat at small cafes, check out some fine small shops and don't miss the church in the square. Surprisingly beautiful inside. Spent 2 of our 5 nights there while in Rome.

Authentic Rome. If you're looking for a less touristic and more authentic aerea in Rome - go to Trastevere! You'll find wonderful restaurants, bars, little shops and even small markets there.
It is - compared to the rest - less touristy and more "italian" there.
Trastevere - the alternative part of Rome :-)

Italian Neighborhood Feeling. I knew I had to spend at least one day visiting this area. I enjoyed walking the streets. Hanging with locals. People watching, it gave me the true Italian feel I desired on my vacation. I walked the alleys in search of several small businesses for the items I wanted to take home. I ate at KMZERO a true like of mine...the food was to die for organic and made by hand loved all of that experience. I enjoyed shooting the area I have many many photo's of the colors of this Neighborhood, It is my desire to turn this into a book. Take a day and get to know the area of TRASTEVERE you will love it!

Best place for a late evening walk. Crowded, but hey, this is central Rome! Some of the best and cheapest "tourist" restos with some hidden gems, of course. Avoid the most crowded streets and get lost in the narrow streets labyrinth all around the area. Wouldn't recommend any restaurant in particular, because it's about the taste and the budget, yet I strongly advise against the cheapest ones, as they tend to prepare "traditional" food with supermarket ingredients. Also, not a place to chose for your hotel... The noise is never ending.
Great. A very charming neighbour hood in Rome, full of life and fun. I recommend this area as a base where to stay as it's so beautiful and very close to the city center too.

What a let down.. and we live here for two weeks !!!!.... We feel sure that your anticipations of Trastevere are, that it is going to be a bit like a Parisian arty type area with lots to see from past ages plus the night life that it is now famous for.. Well, our impression is that it is full of self opinionated craft salespeople and overpriced eateries ,with that lingering pervasive street smell of stale vomit from the previous night's party-goers. Go there of course and it may appeal to you; but for us it was a severe disappointment and we wish that we had selected another area to live in during our stay. [ the fact that the Roman Transport had decided to cease tram movements for a week did not help, as the place is a bit of a transport bottleneck ] No there are better areas.

A Gem of a Neighborhood. I had a wonderful afternoon in this neighborhood. It was an easy walk from the central piazzas and boasted cute shops and restaurants. It felt a little more authentic than being in the some of the more touristy piazzas. I would highly recommend this neighborhood for a couple hours one afternoon during your trip.

A new taste of Rome. We loved staying on this side of the river in Rome. We found some great restaurants and bars, and the people watching was always fun! Some nice shops and beautiful churches too. I recommend the Rick Steves walking tour of the area which gave us great insight into many of the things we would have otherwise walked right past. We'll be back!

Nice evening at Trastevere. If you want to have a drink and dinner, go hereIts a nice place for young people to have a good timeGood place for couples and young peopleSit at a crowded dinner place which has music. Order house wine and local food.Enjoy the evening later with a gelato from the crowded shops that sell it for 2euro each

Just like your local hood. We recently came back from a 2 week vacation to Italy, which included Tuscany and Rome. It is our first visit to Rome and once I read the reviews and spoke to a few people, we made the decision to stay in Trastevere. Our accommodation was at a bed and breakfast. The streets, and restaurants are very "local" and neighborhoody, with folks all knowing each other and congregating at times to have dinner or drinks or chat in the street. Unfortunately prices did not convert too well in dollars because of the low value of dollar to euro. but overall the neighborhood is easily accessible from the neaby walking bridge you cross and is very easy to find your way in and out of the city center where all the touristy areas are. We ate almost every night in the area of Trastevere where the evening offered many opportunities for great wine and dine. Be careful, there a ton of homeless and beggers around the area, even sleeping in the nearby park. We got hassled by this homeless woman that followed us and woudln't leave us alone. yikes. Just be vigilant and go where the crowds are -

Beautyfull. Trastevere its not far from city centre. you can take the bus to go there.. There are plenty of restaurants if you want to eat or bars if you want to have a drink or shops if you want to buy a souvenir. Its very beautyfull especially at night, you can get lost in the beautyfull alleys. Dont forget to visit piazza Santa Maria. I think is the better choice if you want to escape from city centre and have a great time.

A great place to stay and explore. We are recently returned from our first visit to Rome and are very glad we made the decision to stay in Trastevere. Our accommodation at Relais le Clarrisse was of a very high standard and the surrounding area was charming. We found many good restaurants at reasonable prices and a stroll along the river in the evening offers many opportunities to eat and drink whilst admiring the beautiful scenery while the sun goes down. The rest of the city is easy to access and we managed to catch the tram and bus easily to all major attractions. Even so the city is an easy walk across the bridge. We even found a fairly large supermarket for all our supplies throughout our stay.
market. went to the sunday market, so many stalls great place for interesting things and local people will definatly go again

Romance in the air. This charming neighborhood, is a delight to walk through, hand-in-hand with your partner. The cobbled streets, picturesque bars, good service, and profusion of street performers make it a must-visit!

Favorite spot in Rome. One of my favorite spots in Rome. The streets are lovely and a lot of good places to eat. At the end of the afternoon there was a street performer in the main square that was able to get everyone's attention for 20 mins.
Trastevere. Extremely different from the crowded city centre. Peaceful and pretty, well worth a visit to chill and relax
Wonderful district. Make sure you spend at least one evening in this area, full of restaurants and lovely alleyways with great atmosphere. A must-see, especially in the evenings.

Ok, not tourist free but better than.... We really liked staying in the Trastevere on this trip to Rome. Yes, it has become somewhat touristy but no where near the level of the rest of the city. In addition, there are a number of wonderful restaurants that are not only excellent but much less expensive. We were lucky to stay at the Hotel Santa Maria and there is not a thing we would have changed. Other than the ballet at Caracalla, we walked everywhere including the Forum, Pantheon, Castel Sant'Angelo and other sites. But, coming back to Trastevere was like crossing the bridge from Boston to Cambridge...less intense and more relaxed and real. If we were to go back to Rome (this was our third trip), we would definitely stay in this neighborhood!

A "don't miss" experience. Once you've seen the basic sights in Rome, head over to Trastevere. It takes you out of the tourist mainstream and gives you a glimpse of Italian life in a fun, beautiful neighborhood. Nice shops to explore and great cafés and bars. We enjoyed the Italian version of "happy hour" in the evening hours where you pay one price for a drink (in our case it was 8 Euro) and were able to have a one-plate pass through the appetizer buffet. It made for a great light dinner. The later it gets the more the locals come out to enjoy the evening. Also, along that section of the Tevere river, a summertime festival runs along the riverbank for several kilometers with tents. There are temporary bars, clubs, shops and entertainment. It doesn't open until the evening. Well worth a stroll.

The most beautiful part of Rome. I went there after an Italian guy in our flight to Rome said it was the best place to eat without being caught on a tourist trap. But it is much more than this! Yes, all restaurants seemed delicious, we tried 2 of them that were just perfect. The area itself has a small town feeling, with its narrow streets and short buildings with beautifully decorated balconies. Lots of trees and flowers everywhere. It is just a bridge away from busy Rome, so it is definitely worth the visit!

Highlight of the trip. We stayed in this neighborhood and so glad we did. Not only was it walking distance to everything you would want to see in Rome (though some things, like Villa Borghese were a bit of a hike!) it was the best part of the trip. We rented a VRBO apartment and would set out in the morning for a cup of coffee and pastry, then return after exploring the Colosseum or the Vatican, and head out for the passeggiata and dinner. Lots of restaurants, bars, stores and amazing people watching. Lots of options for cocktails and gelato and you can sit in the middle of the square and enjoy a beer- no open container laws!

Fell in love with this area. My wife and I stayed in Trastevere in June. While there are may tourists in all of Rome, this area leaves you with a good mix of local and visitors. The wide range of restaurants & bars with close access to the river make it a great spot. There was also a festival on the water every night we were there with restaurants and vendors making for great evenings.

Yummy. there were 8 of us went on this tour, we went to 10 different venue's to sample some beautiful tasty food&vine,,,yummy yummy...it lasted for about 4hours so we were well fed by the end of tour, our guide Anna was really helpful and she answered all our questions, it really was a lovely tour would reccomend anybody to try it, it was really good and we meet some wonderful hard working people,
walking around the area. lots of people lots of noise lots of dirty air and lots of things to look at for example people and more people! lol

Great place to base yourself.. We spent 6 nights in Rome and stayed in an apartment in Trastevere. What a fabulous location! In Piazza S. Cosimato there is a market from around 8am to 1pm most days and 2 supermarkets just a little further down a street from the Piazza. Restaurants, enotecas, bars, gelaterias etc... are everywhere you look in this location. The streets are so inviting as you happily 'get lost' walking around and exploring.All the major sights can easily be walked to, but if walking isn't your thing a tram line close by as well as buses which can easily whizz you into the heart of Rome. There are so many lovely streets to get lost in throughout Trastevere. At night the place is abuzz and it takes on a whole new look/feel from the day.We'll certainly stay here when we next visit Bella Italia.

Best time in Rome. My wife and 2 friends and I just completed the twilight food walk tour. We have been in Rome for 3 days only. We have been on a Colosseum tour and the Vatican tour. All visitors to Rome must do these tours. But.. the highlight of our time in Rome was most definitely the Food walk tour. It was such good fun. We laughed, we eat good food, we drank good wine and learnt a lot of history of the Trastevere area. Thank you Sarah and Francesca for looking after us. All 4 of us agreed that it was the highlight of our time in Rome. We will certainly be recommending this tour to our friends.

It was my favourite. After lots of reading on here and other places we decided to stay in this part of Rome. That was a good call, the area feels like a traditional Italian village amongst a large city. It was a great escape in the evenings away from the hustle and bustle. There are plenty of bars and places to eat. If you don't get to stay there then try and visit and get lost on the narrow streets for a day.

Trastevere Twilight Food Tour. We stayed in Rome for five nights in an apt in the heart of Trastevere and thought this food tour would be a great way to get to know the neighborhood. It was fun, but the food wasn't all that memorable. We started the tour at the Isola Tiberina and our first stop was Da Enzo for prosecco, melon and prosciutto and buffalo mozzarella - yummy. We then had some delicious Casalare wine in the ancient cellar of Santo Spirito. The cookies (especially the "ugly" ones) were amazing at Innocenti. We saw pizza and bread being made but it wasn't very good. We had three amazing pasta dishes at Osteria del Belli. The fried rice ball from a local street shop was eh. The final stop for gelato was a sweet way to end the night. My favorite stop wasn't food related. We went to a "secret" farmacia in an old church - very cool. Overall, we enjoyed the food but for $220/couple thought we'd get more local history, not just someone taking us from one food stop to another.

Good for an afternoon of wandering. If you find yourself with some free time or just want something thats a little calmer take a stroll around the Trastevere area. Plenty of boutique shops and cafes to occupy a lazy afternoon, especially of the sun is out.

Best neighbourhood in Rome. A great area and a must to visit if you are in Rome. There are plenty of restaurants and bars to try. My wife and I went there three times on our recent trip to Rome. I highly recommend going to Tastevere kmzero, which is a tiny little shop offering local produce including wine and beer. On our visit the owner made us a taster board, which he decides and includes breads, cheeses and hams (simply amazing). This was washed down with local beer and wine. In addition, I also recommend going to San calisto bar for cheap drinks with the locals and a restaurant called Gino for a great lunch. In the evening Trastevere is a great place with an excellent vibe and if I could my wife and I would love to own an apartment there.

For Young Travellers. Trastevere its the bohemian low cost style neighborhood of Rome. It has narrow streets full of shops and small restaurants that would offer cheap meals and drinks in an area that its famous as a gathering point for the young travelers and the Romans adolescents. As an attraction there is not much to see. Yes, its a nice area and a convenient place to stay or eat if you are in a budget but its not something to plan around it. If you are young, as an experience it would be a really fun time but for adults its just a place for a cheap meal mostly.

Just the right neighbourhood for travel or living. Trastevere is not a new place in Rome. The streets are narrow, the houses are old but the character of the neighbourhood is something that would be difficult to find somewhere else. The houses are colorful with lots of history, the restaurants are vibrant and night life is amazing. I stayed at Via Dandolo for 10 days at a stretch and was mesmerized by what it can offer.

A very nice and different spot in Rome. Trastevere is an old area of Rome famous for the Santa Maria Church but also for its beautiful small streets, shops and nice restaurants. The English School is located there and so that area deals well with english speakers very calmly. Also if you are a movie fan and cannot stay away from movie theaters there you will find movies without being doubled in italian.

Lovely Experience. I read about Trastevere online and read some nice things so I thought I'd check it out. It's lovely. There's lots of nice churches, cafes and eateries to check out. I had a really nice authentic Italian dinner on the evening. It was great because it's not busy with tourists. The walk to Trastevere is very nice too, as you walk across a bridge over the Tiber river. For a nice quiet evening with good, I'd definitely recommend it.

Janiculum Hill. Breathtaking views, however it's quite hard to find. If you're looking at a map or asking people for directions, i would probably recommend asking where the monument to Garibaldi is. For some reason, Janiculum Hill is nowhere to be found. Nevertheless, it's worth the hassle as the views are magnificent.

Rubbish issue. A beautiful place but rubbish collection with no bins means daily spilt rubbish on the streets and very loud noise early every morning as the rats and birds fight over it. As we left early in the morning for the airport after a week of sleepless nights, we were confronted by birds pecking away at a pile of vomit, of which there is plenty following Friday and Saturday nights. I hope the authorities sort this out as the area is wonderful in every other way.

A fun part of Rome. We did not stay in this area but walked there for dinner. Lots of choices of cheap eats, also lots of tourists! Interesting markets and street stalls but think I prefer more traditional Roman restaurants than tourist inspired ones with lots of French Fries. A great experience - would I rush back? No probably not.

A lovely part of Rome. We stayed at the hotel Santa Maria (see my seperate review) in Trastevere for 2 nights prior to a cruise. It is a lovely part of the city with narrow, cobbled streets. At night the area comes alive. there are numerous bars and restaurants where you can enjoy a drink or a meal (or both as in our case!) whilst watching the entertainers in the piazza's.We loved it so much we will return.

Lots of Nightlife. I stayed about 5 minutes from this area and loved the variety of bars and restaurants. It certainly comes alive at night with various musicians and buskers performing through the streets. Although I did not partake in the club scene it seemed to become extra crowded with young people after 11pm. Lots of shops and docal delis are great finds.

Tram ride. Went one stop on the No 8 tram at trastereve heading towards the city... Rushing for tram, it was early crowded and lost my purse and phone to a pickpocket whilst validating my ticket..I suggest do no not trust tram driver who I think helped the criminal by jerking a tram that was overcrowded and ensured we where all grabbing something to keep upright and not our bags...it was 1030 on June 1st 2014 T Roma Bernaudi Feltre....I am still trying to report the tram driver as I am sure he caused enough chaos to help a thief...

Great evening. We spent the evening in the neighborhood of Trastevere. It is across the bridge but well worth visiting. The area seems to be experiencing a renewal. There are restaurants, street vendors and entertainers to help pass the evening. It was very safe and we reached it by the H bus from the Roma Termini.

Great atmosphere. We visited Trastevere for supper one evening and were not disappointed. Immediately after leaving the main road by the Tiber river, we entered a enchanted world of restaurants and street entertainers. The atmosphere can only be described as electric. Well worth a visit if you are on the right side of the city.

Authentic. The Trastevere neighbourhood, full of lovely little streets, makes this a great place to wander around for the afternoon. There are many restaurants, cafés, and bakeries making simple but really good authentic food. Don't miss it!

Better than anywhere else.. If you are a wealthy tourist looking for a Hilton, this is not the place for you. But if you are looking for friendly Romans, TONS of restaurants and a virtual hive of activity, you need o be in Trastevere. We actually hired an apartment there for just over two weeks, and every day an night were filled with something exciting, good food and friendly people. Living there meant we really felt part of the situation, and once we turned up more than two or three times at any spot, the locals knew and greeted us. A never-to-be-forgotten lifetime experience, not just a visit.

Most beautiful neighbourhood. This was a wonderful surprise. Trastevere is a quiet little neighbourhood south of the river, with lovely little streets and restaurants. There are many trees and the fresh shade is like a breath of air in the hussle that reigns in Rome. Nice cafes, too, a great place for a quiet afternoon walk and perhaps a nice cup of coffee enjoying the views of the river. Don´t miss it!

Trastevere view of Rome. We wandered through Trastevere which is a quaint area of Rome. We ended up walking up this road that led us to the top of a large hill with a park there. The view of the city of Rome from up there is just spectacular!!!! You can see the whole city from up there and the mountains and towns in the distance. Well worth the walk!!

The ultimate romantic, quaint and fun part of Rome!. Heaven on earth for restaurants, bars and boutique shopping. We discovered the greatest pizza and most fabulous Chianti,great sushi and sake (Take Sushi) and I found the most exquisite little shop in Via della Lungaretta (right off Via Trastevere) where I got the 2 pairs of sandals I had looked all over Rome for. My husband dragged me out before I could do any further damage to the credit card :-) A must go!

Traditional Authentic Area. This is a 'must visit' location to see  if visiting Rome. The narrow streets, bars and restaurants  make it ideal to spend sometime to relax.  Some of the restaurants and bars looked  traditionally & authentically Italian, many were nearly full of customers. We enjoyed walking through the narrow streets which invariably led to a square then we'd exit into another set of narrow streets. There is lots to see.We found a small bar where we  sat outside and soaked up the sunshine. There are  numerous stalls selling touristy gifts, as were shops within the narrow streets. Would love to have returned here at night to walk around and have a meal, but did not have the time.

We loved this part of Rome. We stayed in this part of Rome and really liked it. By using the bridge over the Tiber you are in the center of Rome quite quick. There are lots of restaurants and bars, independent shops, etc.
Really nice!

A must, but also very touristy. The Trastevere neighborhood in Rome is a must on a trip to Rome, because of the cosy little streets and squares and a few remarkably interesting churches.The area was once considered for "lower classes" and thus avoided by the well-to-do Romans. Now it is a very frequented area both tourist but also by locals, lots of little restaurants/bars with good drinks and appetizers (some as low as 8 or 10 Euros total for one drink and free choice of appetizers as much as you can eat). Streetfenders and many visitors can make passages through narrow streets difficult at busy days (week-ends).

Early morning/late evening walk down the bits of real Rome. This is where you can catch bits of real Rome... Especially early in the morning or late evening. In Trastavere area Romans go out so nights will be crowded... But mornings... mmm... People going to work, opening their shops, being loud, smiling, drinking coffee.... Make sure to walk around the area next to the John Cabot University building... Lovely lovely and lovely! :) In the coffee/sandwich bar a bit before entrance of the John Cabot University (coffee shop is on left if you are coming from the Basilica Santa Maria in Trastavere direction before big wall or gate, while University is on right, just after) you will find smiling and service oriented staff :) Can't recall the name, it's in the stree Via della Lungara. Try their moccacino, it's closest to what everyone else, except Italians, perceives as macciatto. Especially if you are coming from the Balkan or Middle East :) Also, just before this cafe, in the street on right (again from the Basilica Santa Maria in Trastavere direction), there is a Pizza place where you are buying pizza on grams!!! How cool is that! It also tastes great! They have nice selection of different combinations. After you have had your coffee and pizza, it's time for gellato/ ice-cream ;) A famous place is just in this area. Via Benedetta 6. Try their pistaccio, definitely worth trying. Other "famous" ice-cream bars, are just touristic scam...

One of my favorites in Rome. Just walk and walk.... and stop for a nice meal in one of many little tratorias. You will love it. And it's a must climbing up-hill to Piazza Garibaldi, Gianicolo, and the promenade (if you are not able to climb take a cab but don't miss it), one of the highest hills in Roma if not "the" and enjoy the most amaizing views of Roma.

favorite neighborhood in Rome. It took a second trip to Rome for me to get over to the Trastevere neighborhood. My first visit to Rome I had a long list of top things to see/do in Rome, and it was great. The second time, however, we slowed down a bit, enjoyed less touristy Rome, and fell in love with Trastevere. The beautiful ivy growing all over the buildings, the best restaurants, the families walking along carrying groceries, and the quaint feeling sets it apart from other neighborhoods. We've decided that we'll most definitely stay in this neighborhood for all future trips to Rome. Don't let it take you several trips to Rome to finally go here- go your first time!

Loved this neighborhood in Rome!. Over the river from the hustle and bustle, but still walking distance to most roman sites... a wonderful neighborhood with sleepy little streets, quaint coffee shops, amazing restaurants, and best of all a warm fuzzy feeling. Loved it!

Great Roman neighbourhood. Trastevere is a short cab ride or a nice walk from St. Peter's, the Pantheon, Piazza Navona and other more popular locales.By day, the neighbourhood is full of hustle, bustle and children playing. By night, it shows itself as a mecca for great food, strolling and other romantic pursuits. The central focus is the big square in front of Santa Maria church. The church itself is a marvel of mosaics and it's worthwhile visiting for its artistic as well as religious significance. Yes, the neighbourhood is becoming more gentrified. But there are still plenty of locals-- many of whom own and run the excellent local restaurants found in this little community. When I'm in Rome, I try to visit both during the day and at night. The photographic possibilities are endless.

Love love loved it!!!. Completely authentically Rome!! Gorgeous streets and wonderful atmosphere, especially at night. The square was a complete surprise with lovely cafés, bistros and pizzerias. The fountain was great for photos and the church of santa Maria is one of the best in the whole of Rome. We also chose to eat every night in Trastevere (along the main road) and were not disappointed. One night, at the nearest end to the bridge, we entered a very inconspicuous church and had the most amazing intimate experience. We were asked to write down our prayers and wishes and were then guided by an Italian lady to the front of the church to place them on the alter. We then said a prayer and walked back through the singing and clapping, small congregation, noticing an embalmed bishop/priest on display in a small chapel off to the side. Very strange but amazing and one if the most incredible memories! Having seen Rome, read reviews and hoping to return soon there is no doubt I would only stay in Trastevere. (We stayed at the Ripa Hotel, review is on here, would definitely recommend)

The left bank is better in a number of ways. Thoroughly enjoyed our lodging location in Trastevere will visiting Rome for the first time. Good bus trans across the river to all the sights.Close enough to walk.Trastevere seems less crowded, noisy, touristy, etc. Than central Rome.We had an Untours apartment and I recommend them to all.We spent a week here. It was not long enough.A trip of a lifetime.

Great place to experience rome.. We spent 5 nights in an apartment in trastevere. It is an excellent base from which to explore the city, only 15 minutes walk from the main sites.Great bars, restaurants and atmosphere.This is not authentic, if authentic means no tourists, only Italians. But an area with no tourists is probably not worth visiting. There are tourists of course, and many of them, there is just not tourist bus tourists. There also lots of American students due to the universities in the area.The area has much graffiti, a bit noise at night and Of course it also has Bangladeshi hawkers, but so does every where else. But it has an edge and vibe that is not evident in the other areas of town.The graffitied rollers come up at night to reveal great places to drink and eat.

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE!. If you have the opportunity, you have to do this food tour. It was definitely a highlight for me. Sarah was our tour guide and was extremely knowledgeable, friendly and fun! I discovered one of my new favorite dishes discovered on this tour (fried artichoke) which I will definitely be enjoying at home and reminiscing of my time in Rome. I just loved this experience and I'm sure you will too!

Kind of overrated. I don't know. It was quaint, but maybe we did not walk the entire district. I wanted to see more laundry hanging out of the windows. Doesn't seem as authentically local Italian as I thought it would be. I think a lot of expats and well to do people have moved into the area along with tourists renting apartments. I was expecting lower to middle class Italians out and about and like I mentioned loads of clothes hanging from balconies the way I have seen in videos and photos. I did not see this. It looks sort of like what Old Town Alexandria in Virginia looks like, a mix of touristy cafes and well to do residents living there. I know it was the middle of the day, but I was expecting a more middle class village. NOT. A lot of tourists like me walking along with the gelato shops and Bangladesh street vendors hawking their wares. I was sort of teed off because we spent 2 hours walking from the Vatican area looking for this place and getting lost! But they do have cheap tourist cafes to rest and eat from!

Away from the crowds.... Trastevere is away from the crowds of central Rome and has lots to see and do. On Sunday the Porta Portese flea market is where lots of locals can be found rummaging for bargains. It has everything from clothes, to household goods, antiques and books. It's a real slice of traditional Italian life.Stopping off for drinks in Piazza Santa Maria was really fun. There are lots of cafes overlooking the church and the fountain. There are also some street musicians who entertained the crowd too. A great way to spend a lazy Sunday morning; Italian style.

Away from tour groups, but great expat favorite. This neighborhood across the river isn't crowded with tour bus, but you can still meet lots of foreigners and it's cafés and bars. Small shops and museums can be found between the numerous patios. Good atmosphere. Great place for a date or to meet up with friends over a mojito pitcher.

Do as the Romans do.... We were tipped off about Trastevere by a family member - and what a tip it was! Just a 15-20 minute stroll from the Piazza Venezia and across the Tiber you will find this wonderful suburb of Rome. Authentic, enchanting and charming.We strolled across during the day and found plenty of bars and restaurants, just tucked away from the main piazza, offering excellent value food and drink (TIP - Stick to the house wine, it is delicious and can be as cheap as €8!).We loved Trastevere we returned not just once, but every night to sample the cuisine! A three course meal, with coffee for just €13 per person was not to be sniffed at!Following our meals, we would take a stroll to the Blue Ice gelato shop (Snickers is AMAZING!) for a cheap dessert and then take a stroll along the Tiber back towards the centre of town.Trastevere; one of Rome's best-kept secrets!

A secret hideout across the river. We strolled around and crossed the river into Trastevere and had a drink or two and soaked up the sun in the snack bar and geletaria in the piazza. Having read the previous review about being shouted at by a crazy lady we didn't experience anything similar and quite the opposite, this was a calm and lovely little spot in the warm April sunshine and a joyous experience. The older waiter was pleasant and funny - overall a nice little spot and secret hideout across the Tiber.
Best eating places in Rome. If you are Rome make the effort to visit trastevere for a wealth of good authentic Italian restaurants, lovely piazzas with many restaurants to tickle the taste buds.

Quaint and peaceful. Trastevere was such a pleasant part of Rome that I almost forgot about the hustle and bustle of the main tourist attractions! It was great to walk down small alleys that opened up to reveal a beautiful church. Both Santa Cecilia in Trastevere and Santa Maria in Trastevere are not to be missed!

Lucky those who visit it. After spending a few hours in this unexpected Roman gift, I was grateful to my friend Fabrizzio who had opened my eyes about it. The atmosphere in this quaint Roman neighbourhood is authentically "historical" but also lively and elegant. The restaurants and shops are worth-visiting by any tourist; but, above all, don't miss the exquisite church of Santa Maria di Trastevere! Perhaps the oldest church in the Italian capital, its Byzantine mosaics are breath-taking. I was lucky to approach a group of British students and listen to their professor 's sophisticated description and respectful evaluation. But any good guidebook will be sufficient to prepare you for this rare aesthetic, if not also religious, experience.

Pure Italy. One of the best parts of the city. True italian air and sun. It's all different there. And a romantic mood suddenly shows up and won't leave you until you are far away from Trastevere. Many cute restaurants and sightseeings that welcome you with pure italian warmth. This is one of "musts" in Rome.

Lovely place. I really loved this place but more at nights. Some of the restaurants are so great. Try to walk in the different sides just watch the houses and little boutiques you can find new places every visit.
Lovely. I love it here, all the little lanes, the endless bars, restaurants and shops. I could spend all day here. If you come on a Sunday there is a huuuge market that seemed to go on for ever

My favourite part of rome. This was my favourite district in Rome by FAR. Loads to see and lots of quaint little shops and cafes as opposed to overfilled, overpriced shops where you pay too much for rubbish coffee and no serve, here it is the opposite you are embarrassed as some things are so reasonably priced. Not a far walk from the main part of the city but much nicer to have lunch in. We ate in a pizzeria down a side street and it was my best meal in Rome. We then sat in the main square which is also beautiful and listened to the people playing music after visiting the best ice-cream shop or gelateria Ive ever been to - 'Blue Ice' (snickers is a must try). There are lots of trash vendors as in ALL parts of the city and some real tourist trap restaurants where they try to coax you in. If you go down the narrow streets off the main piazza or square you will find much better places to eat filled with locals. This area was recommended to us as the best place for food and drinks in rome by the girl working in our hostel.

nice place. don't run anywhere , just try to be lost in it's narrow streets, enjoy every building you pass, have time at quiet places and drink coffee (or wine )...feel yourself real Italian who can enjoy life... it's nice part of real Rome and if you have no enough time better don't go there...

Beautiful streets hidden behind so many illegal vendors, 'touristified' restaurants.. Trastevere has been thoroughly touristified. Every single street is lined with vendors selling the most unlikely of things (scarves, shoes, rubber toys, and so on). The restaurants are now at "tourist price" often with unlisted surcharges and at night the area is crawling with pickpockets.I would say that it's a place to see as it's really lovely, but don't spend too much time there. Keep an eye on your bags at all times specially since bag snatchers know their way around and can disappear here faster than they can along a major road in Rome. And make sure you know what you're getting into when choosing a place to eat--- you may end up paying a 30% surcharge as 'tip'.
Ok, bit of tourist trap?. People said to visit here, but it just seemed full of tourists and tourist eateries? So I don't get why it has this reputation for decent and honest food.

MUST VISIT in Rome- lovely and romantic at night.. Beautiful part of the city- not too far from the centre. Feels more authentic and less touristy despite the large number of Americans. Great cathedral. Intimate part of the city with lots of eateries. Plenty of character. Even if you only had a few days in Rome, I can't recommend this place enough!

Top Antique Area to Visit so Don't Miss it. So many beautiful Antique Alleys, So many pretty Piazzas (Squares), So many awesome Italian Restaurants, I just love this Area, Walking randomly in Trastevere is simply awesome, you won't even need a guide, alleys are just pretty, they are so Tiny and antique, You might get lost during doing your own walking tour but you would love it as well cause everything you would see during that time is just amazing so don't forget to bring your camera. at NIGHT during weekend there's a hangout area basically all locals and tourists/Students go there, its called Piazza Trilussa, you would love it there, There's a couple of pubs there as well some of them are kinda huge and fun to hangout with friends, like "Birreria Trilussa and Nylon and Friends" are famous there, there're all near "Piazza Trilussa" There's PARK in far west of the area, you might wanna go there and relax for some time, Make sure you find it on the map before heading to the Park :) A famous CHURCH called "Santa Maria" is actually worth visiting, its just in the heart of the area :)I suggest this area to everyone coming to Rome, I personally consider it as a Top Place area that must visit. and of course there're so many things to explore there, so take your time :)

A characterful area of the city with lots of good eateries!. This area in the city is situated just back from the river. It is full of character and away from the traffic madness in the rest of the city. This area is in comparison like a tranquil haven - think cobbled narrow lanes with washing hanging out above them, beautiful churches and villa's hidden behind every corner, and great little cafe's to eat at or simply to just sit outside and sip a glass of chianti! You can also find an interesting range of quality shops if you look carefully, and can pick up something very special if your budget will go that far. This is an area away from the madness where you will not be bothered by the pedlars selling their tacky merchandise.

the most awesome place to visit. It has this special atmosphere... So just buy an ice-cream and wander around.Narrow streets, warm colors, small restaurants, lots of flowers.If you need to use a bathroom, just walk into some cafe. If you feel embarrassed, just buy a cup of coffee.

If you want to experience Rome the right way, you need to rent an apartment here. Awesome area! Honeymooned here and rented an apartment/penthouse through airbnb. Best experience ever!! We were a short walk from everything and got to feel what it was like to live as a Roman for 9 days. The Tiber was in view out our window and the bridge was a blast every night. Lots of people, lots of culture and the Trevi was a 10 min walk. To get to the Trevi, it took 1 turn. Cross the bridge, and turn at the pantheon. The best at night time, still active, but a lot less tourist in the way. Just watch out for all the Indians trying to sell you elastic neon flying helicopters and dancing cats, they mean well and provided a lot of memories. Awesome atmosphere and happy people. Food, bars and shops at their best. Greatest pastries in Rome. Music from the fellow travelers all night was great in the back ground and fun to be around. There was a river walk that edged the Tiber. We had supper close enough I could have stuck my foot in the water. The shop owners in the area remembered who we were and a couple began giving us discounts each time we went in. When we go back, we will be doing the same thing again, no place else will do.
