Exactly what I wanted Rome to be!. Please, please, please....if you're traveling to Rome go to Trastevere for dinner or late drinks. The piazza comes alive at night and it is magical. We sat out on a patio for dinner and when it got dark, the crowd around the fountain began to grow and soon there was dancing, violin playing, singing and then a woman who brought her own portable CD player started dancing in front of the fountain with lanterns and flame throwers. A-mazing. (this entertainment is all for tips, of course!) Friendly crowd, lots of locals, very fun place to spend a day (and late night!) in Rome.

Best part of Rome, quaint, great food, village feel. A few years ago we stayed in central Rome near the Spanish steps. We crossed over the river for lunch in Trastevere and fell in love with the place!! we vowed that we'd stay there next time in Rome.Trastevere is a quaint and charming old neighborhood that feels very much like a village, yet is part of Rome and right across several pedestrian (or car) bridges.Cobblestone narrow little streets, great square around the Santa Maria church, fantastic food at low prices, tons of bars cafes and nightlife.If you don't stay here, you need to go for dinner or lunch and a stroll. Also, walking distance to the Vatican.

Nice Roman part of Rome. from piazza Navona go to the Tiber river and crossing the bridge you are in Trastevere. Nice church of Santa Maria in Trastevere. A lot of cute, not at all expencive ristorantes for a lunch. REMEMBER - if you go in restaurant after 1pm, you might not find a place. From there do not be lazy and climb to the hill of Gannicolo. Amazing view of Rome and continue to Vatican. lot of walking but it is worth to do.

A unique quarter.... Start your day in the Trastevere market. You'll find everyting, from cheap and fancy clothes, antiques, replicas, second hand, a world of offers. Then, start to walk towards the Tibre River, crossing the Trastevere quarter. It' lovely, quiet, beautifull houses, lovely restaurants. Make a stop in a Trattoria, take a seat in a table outside, listen to the romantic Italian spoken aroun you, and let yourself get lost in the surrounding atmosphere.

Wander aimlessly!. Trastevere is meant to be explored at random, if not a guided walk. You'll be pleased to discover so many hidden gems. At night, if you come out of this area closer to the Tiber river, you'll have a great opportunity for a night shot of Ponte Sisto bridge.
Really good food and ambient. Is the second time I eat in the Trastevere. I would recommend you to choose a place to eat in the streets behind, not in the main touristic one. Enjoy!!!

High energy. I've stayed in many locations in Rome but keep returning to Trastevere. The area has an authentic feel as a place where people really live. The area is fueled by the energy of all the young people who live there or frequent the shops and bars. It is an easy walk to many of the cities' attractions if you can detach yourself from the romance of Trastevere.

Most realistic and charming section for a true taste of Rome. I loved the quiet, small little streets with the locals at flower shops, gelato shops, restaurants that greet you as you come inside....we plan to stay in this area on a return visit to enjoy more of this delightful original city and the people

The nicest area in Rome. If you can just visit one area in Rome I would suggest that this is the one. Perhaps you'll not find the greatest of art here but it's absolutely the nicest area with very narrow streets, small boutiqes and bars and restaurants everywhere. Stroll at night with a partner and you're bound to have romantic evening whatever you do or choose to go. A bit expensive since it's that many tourists here... But going a bit outside the oldest part you'll find some cheaper pizzerias etc. Go visit!

Loved it!. After having read the reviews about this Rome area on Tripadvisor, I decided to give it a visit. I wish i could have visited this area a bit longer. We only walked around for half an hour (family, eh?). Great place. Some nice shops. Nice atmosphere.

Drink in the wonder of it all. My husband and I had both been to Rome and done all the tourist stuff so we wanted to just enjoy the Italian culture and everyday life. We research it before we went and decided on Trastavere as a typical Italian neighborhood. We took a taxi to Piazza di Santa Maria and was in the center of it all. Picked out a restaurant, Caffe Marzio, and sat and had lunch and enjoyed the afternoon. The cafes in Italy are great as they never hurry you and we sat for a long time and took it all in. Well worth the trip but not far from the center of Rome.

Rome by night!. Great place for a walk at night. Perfect for a drink at a bar, a slice of pizza or an ice cream. It feels homey and loci and just reminds you of the hospitality of the Romans. It is definitely a don't miss!

Roman Home. Absolutely fabulous area of Rome to stay in. Romans are generally pleasant friendly and kind, but you can ratchet that up by a notch or two in Trastevere. One of my favourite places on the planet alongside West Village NY, Cape May NJ and Essaouira, Morocco.

"Our neighbourhood". In September, after several months of planning, my sister and I came to Rome for two weeks. We had booked a room in Trastevere for the entire (save one night) stay, and we did not regret that decision for one minute. Trastevere is a real neighbourhood full of character and characters that still manages to feel homey and safe, yet is only a twenty minute walk to the major sites of Rome, including the Jewish Ghetto! We felt we had the best of both worlds, and, after trekking all over the eternal city (including one visit via underground to Cinecitta), we could leave the hubbub of the rest of Rome and go to our (comparatively) quiet, yet lively, neighbourhood. There is much to see just in Trastevere, as we discovered every day. The lovely piazzas alone are fun just to hang out in. On our last day, we bought porchetta panino, and took a bus up to the top of Gianicolo (Janiculum) to eat our picnic lunch and have a look over Rome, before walking back down hill. What a lovely experience! We did quite a bit of shopping in Trastevere, including some food shopping at a beautiful shop on via Natale, Innocenzi, a throwback to a more gentle and genteel time. Would we go back? You bet we will! My sister wants to buy an apartment there, should she win the lottery!

Great strolling. If you're near Campo de Fiore, this is just across the river and an easy walk across a pedestrian bridge. The streets wind around each other with colorful buildings, gardens, and people. There's a sense that people live and work here with restaurants, bakeries, and shops. A great place for photos.

Wander the streets... This is one of Rome's busy eclectic areas..whether it having a drink at one of the numerous bars, grabbing a pizza slice or gelato it is a wonderful place to explore day or night.A plethora of eating establishments….look for those full of Italians and not tourists (as we all try to do!).In my two weeks in Rome, I often found myself just wandering around and there was always something to do…watch and eat !

Neighborhood in Rome comparable to the Village in NYC - good for visit or to stay in apt. ** If this review was useful to you please click the "helpful" button at the bottom - thanks!We rented an apt in Trastevere while on a 4 day trip in Rome. We used the neighborhood as a home base. It was a GREAT neighborhood for local nightlife and great local restaurants (not touristy and decent prices. I didn't see too many hotel's in this neighborhood, but it's easy to find an apt to let online. I'd suggest this neighborhood to visit or stay if you like areas similar to the Village in NYC. Artsy, fun shops, great local food and restaurants - all kinds from cafe's to nice sit down. If you head to the main square in Trastevere on a Fri or Sat night, there will be tons of people in the street late night, and usually bands playing, street music, etc. We LOVed staying here, but I'd say that it's not super convenient to all of the major tourist attractions (thus the 4 instead of 5 stars). You can catch a tram (#2 I believe) from the main st. in Trastevere that will take you right down to the main area near the Forum and Colleseum (About 5 tram stops and a few blocks walk). If you don't mind public transportation, and a little walking, and want to stay in a fun, happening town (probably one of the more authentic with locals in rome)... visit or stay in Trastevere!

One of the most charming sections of Rome. Although no longer a hidden gem, Trastevere is still one of the most charming sections of Rome. Beautiful vine-covered buildings with rich colors, windy little streets, lovely churches, and tons of little restaurants and bars. A perfect place to explore and wander. A must-see when visiting the Eternal City.

Great neighborhood enclave for food, fun and history. This is a cool neighborhood across the river and a short walk from downtown. It is served by the tram and buses. The locals flock to its restaurants and bars at night. It hosts the oldest church in Rome which is not to be missed (and I'm not much of a sightseer). I prefered it over St Peter's as a experience. Of course you have to go to the Vatican but its a factory and it is hard to be intimate with the history. The streets of Trastevere are narrow and often blocked to traffic so only pedestrians can enter (walking around? watch for those stone traffic blocks you can easily trip over them) If you are staying here get an upper floor room so you have some insulation from the noise at night. Its mostly the noise of people talking at bars and restaurants, not auto noise, but it is a big crowd so it is loud. If you need to close the windows to silence the din you'd better have A/C in all but the coolest months. If you can find your way to a rooftop veranda (our AirBNB apt had one) you will love the view overlooking Trastevere and Rome beyond.
Excellent. Found this restaurant very popular. Booked a table at 9 saturday evening for two. The waitress called Giulia did our evening completed. She was serviceminded and fulfilled our requests.
Great area in Rome. Nice area of Rome to visit. Take the time to visit, as this is a historical area and walking around for hours discovering new side streets.

Real Neighborhood Experience. Walking around the Trastevere neighborhood takes you into the lives of the Italian people who live in Rome instead of among the tourists. This area represents authentic Rome. The adventure lies in exploring the cobblestone alleys and boutiques. I bought some lovely purses here at a small shop on Via Della Scala (Acquisto?) with competitive prices and a very helpful shop owner. Like the rest of Rome, the streets are a spiderweb so it was not easy to navigate. While we had a map, it was more functional to just wander. We had the best lunch at The MIrror Pizza. This would be a fantastic area to come for dinner - great food at bargain prices. Our $15 euro lunch included a salad with Gorgonzola cheese, pears, and walnuts, pastry with vegetables inside, drinks, and the most amazing bruschetta. I don't know what made this so good but it was a standout! This is not an area to go if you are looking for major tourist attractions, but if you are done with those and looking for a relaxing afternoon with some authentic Italian food and shopping, this is a great spot. Don't expect to find designer row here. It's more like a hidden boutique shopping adventure.

Nothing much to do. Despite the numerous feedback on how Trastevere was so different from most of Rome, we found it otherwise - it looked just like Rome. After a while we got quite bored and just stayed in a cafe to read and use our mobile devices.

Lovely atmosphere!. This is a lovely area of Rome, so good we went back for a couple of nights on the row. Recommended by a friend and also a barman we were chatting to, I would recommend this place for a nice meal, nice atmosphere and just to people watch. Feel free to get a bottle of wine and sit drinking it on the steps of the fountains, it's what everyone seems to do. Never been happier just sat there watching the world go by.

Unusual and interesting. This was our fist time in Trastevere and hopefully not our last. It has a very different vibe although it is just as old as most of Rome and perhaps that is partly because of how haphazardly the streets meander and everything seems a bit uneven, unplanned. There is a cosy village atmosphere where ancient villas are next to humble houses and pedestrians are comfortable walking the narrow streets as there are very few cars around. I wish I had set aside more time to spend there as one afternoon was not enough for us.

Beautiful part of the city with a really nice atmosphere. I ended up in this part of Rome while walking around the city. The atmosphere is just amazing. Narrow streets, nice restaurants, traditional italian houses and everything that makes it a nice italian experience. Go for a walk through Trastevere at day or night, it doesn't matter because it will be great at all times of the day.

Trastevere at night is a must!. My girlfriend and I walked from our hotel down into Trastevere the 2nd night we were in Rome and had an excellent time. Lots of little shops, artists, amazing food, and just overall a nice atmosphere and one of the more unique areas in the city. We made a point of coming back again to explore some more!

Absolute experience. Spent a lovely evening in this neighborhood, on the other side of Tiber, across the touristy Rome. We crossed Ponte Sisto to walk up the Gianicolo for city view at sunset. On way down, we pocketed our maps and just let ourselves wander the beautiful lanes. Its so refreshingly different from the streets full of DSLR totting tourists around the usual spots and even the not so muted Campo de Fiori eateries. The cobbled streets, overgrowing vines, small cafes and absence of souvenir shops make it a pleasant experience. Enjoyed a good meal at Da Otello, on Vicolo del Bologna, and would totally recommend that. Piazza Di Santa Maria was buzzing with street performers and lots more eating options. Definitely not to be missed, even if you are in the city for couple of days!

Twilight Trastevere Food Tour. Ok - So if you find yourself in Rome with a desire to do something different - do this! The Twilight In Trastevere Food Tour takes you to 8 different places, where you enjoy unique specialties from buratta and local melon, to a wine cellar built before the Colosseum, to a gelato "fairy" and then some.Anna, our tour guide, was friendly and knowledgeable and clearly in love with what she does. She took our small group (6 people) to a biscotti factory that has been in business for three generations, a restaurant in a former synagogue, a gelateria, a salumeria (with amazing proscuitto) and more. Three and a half hours later, full of fine food and fine wine, we ambled back to our hotels happy and feeling truly connected to Rome.Do this! If you appreciate good food, you won't regret it!

Nice place for pizzerias very characteristic of the terrioty. amazing spot in the roman centre, few steps from piazza venezia and very close to the place I stayed is this magnificent piazza where I had one of the best pizzas of my life. Very roman character of the neighborrhod definetely a must see

Interesting neighbourhood. We enjoyed a walk through this interesting neighbourhood with a 'Rick Steves' audioguide app. Our tour went from St. Cecilia, whose story we knew from a visit to the catacombs, through the streets of Trastevere, to St. Mary, the first church dedicated to the virgin.

Trastevere. Trastevere is one of my favourite places to go in Rome. Not your typical tourist attraction, you find a lot of Roman locals mingling with the tourists. Trastevere is an excellent place to eat out as prices are significantly cheaper than the major tourist areas of Rome, and the quality of the food is better. I have been to Rome many times and have done all of the tourist attractions before, and on my last trip to Rome back in September I spent a lot more time people-watching and a lot less time rushing from attraction to attraction. Trastevere is the perfect place to people-watch!

The neighborhood to visit in Rome. We rambled through Trastevere two evenings while in Rome. Best food we had there. It felt like a small town. Kids actually played in the piazza at Santa Maria de Scalla. We had drinks at a small place on the piazza and they brought out complimentary hors d'oeuvres. We had hors d'oeuvres another night at a new restaurant we stumbled upon--wonderful!

ok, but many better places. we walked quite a way and over the Tiber to reach this area, it was quite nice but not really what I expected. I would say piazza navona was much better. We were there during the day so maybe it is a better atmosphere in the evening.

Very disappointed. I didn't make many requests as to what to do and where to go on our trip to Italy, but I read about Trastevere and how it was supposed to be one of the most beautiful neighborhoods in Rome. I wanted to see something that wasn't a major tourist attraction. After a long day of sightseeing, we stopped at Trattoria Trastevere to rest and have a light snack before wandering the streets and settling on someplace for dinner. It was a good thing we ended up eating enough to count as dinner as after a 30-45 minute walk, we couldn't find anything that qualified as a beautiful neighborhood. We were very disappointed.

Authentic. Thankfully, we spent one whole week in Rome, so we had enough time to explore the area on the other side of Tiber, beautiful old part of the city called Trastevere. Yes, it is Rome, but in some areas you almost feel like it is a different town. Everything here is old and has that beautiful layer of history that gives it some special charm. Narrow streets, small shops, domestic restaurants and caffees… It feels good to spend one half of a day here and escape from the busy and noisy streets of the city centre.

Romantic and vibrating at the same time. I think bohemian would be the better term for this part of the city. There are numerous restaurants, cafes, small shops and street performers, along with people all ages, but mostly young. It really comes alive at night, in a very byronistic kind of vibe. Joye de vivre. Have dinner with the twinkling lights and breath in the romance. I would definetely recommend it!

Where it is at in Roma. We tried to find this area on the second night we were in Rome, nut truned the wrong way and ended up in the quiet part, thank goodness we did a Rome by Night tour which ended in a dinner in the happening part of Trastevere. We ate at Da Otello Pizzeria which was yum! Via Della Pelliccia and Vicolo del Cinque. Best place to be for nightime dinning with the locals and good prices.

Amazing Markets. Visited Trastevere markets which sold everything from tourist kitsch, clothing, shoes to antiques! This markets goes for miles and miles down the cobblestone streets of Trastevere. Very crowded and hot (it was August) but an amazing experience and well worth the effort! Food also available in cosy restaurants and cafes. Definitely recommended for those who love markets and bargains!!!

I just found my favorite neighborhood in Rome.. Medieval. Unhurried A bit Bohemian. Artsy. Casual. Great food. Cute. Inexpensive. Classy. Wow. Don't tell anyone. Tell the Via Veneto and the Via Condotti crowd to stay where they are. Next time I'll be in Rome, I'll be staying here.

Rent an apartment in Trastevere !. This is one of the greatest areas of Rome, after a long day of touring in the city, you come back to the place were everybody goes to have fun at nights. Romantic Restaurants, great bars, lost of young people, open stores, streets stands, music and small magic alleys. There are hotels in this neighbourhood but I really recommend to rent an apartment in here, it gives you the option to really feel the life in amazing beautiful Trastevre :)

Not to be missed. Make sure you fit in Trastevere, we found many authentic restaurants there. Plus, at night under the bridge are hundreds of white tents lit up with food vendors and gift vendors galore, a fun experience.

Away from the madding crowd. Trastevere is such a gem in Rome, with manic crowds of tourists. The quaint buildings and roads add character to the place. Take time to wander and get lost here. It's very romantic and a far cry from the macho Colesseum or Palatine Hill across the River. But shhhhh...don't tell everyone or the place will lose its magic ;)
Trastevere is simply Trastevere. Trastevere or beyond the Tiber, is a lovely place when you can spend many hours from lunch till coffee break time, or Passing a Soirée till the sun dawn..

Trestavre in the evening/night. Superb if you want a cultured experience!. This is an incredible area. Very quiet early in the day with most shops and restaurants closed. Lovely to walk around and take in the labrynth of streets and beautiful architecture. In the evening find yourself emerged in a mix of restaurants (select accordingly there's plenty for advanced palates and those who "think" they know good food). Buskers, gypsies, locals, wealthy, and tourists of all varietiea. It's really for everyone if you know how to take it. Not to be missed!!! Frankly, it was the best part of each day; coming back from all that Rome offers.

Just perfect for a pleasant walk. Nice, narrow streets, lots of restaurants and small shops- a great place for a stroll! You feel as if you were in a different place than Rome, it's more like old good Roma :) I combined it with visiting Aventine Hill :)

Lovely streets to walk!!!. Oh Trastevere... lovely streets to walk through, get lost and enjoy the roman life style. Sit and enjoy a drink for apperitivo and if you're lucky you get a free full buffet with lovely italian cuisine!!!MUST visit neighborhood, romantic and very chick!!

A Roman Must. Trastevere is a great place! A little neighbourhood of winding roads and paths full of colourful and traditional Roman buildings. Loads of romantic restaurants and fantastic quirky bars with live music and a great atmosphere without a stampede of tourists. Restaurants range in prices - we went to a fairly classy restaurant which was reasonably priced! You can easily get there by bus from the central station or a taxi for roughly 10 Euros. Would strongly recommended to anyone!

Loved exploring here. Walking through the neighborhoods of Trastevere was a highlight. It was nice to escape the tourist areas and have a closer look into the neighborhoods. I especially liked my walk along Viale Glorioso to the top of the hill for great views, then down Via Garibaldi. Stop for a cappuccino, live music and good food in the evenings, or try the Sunday market at Porta Portese. The market is hot and crowded, with lots of junk, but still fun to walk through. The Rick Steves audio tour of Trastevere can be downloaded for free on itunes. I would consider staying in Trastevere on my next visit.
Great. Really a great place to see.Old and colourfull buildings full of flowers.You can find great food and wine.And also you can see the view of Tiber.

The Heart of Rome. The Trastevere is an essential stop for anybody visiting Rome and an excellent place to base yourself. There are many restaurants and boutique shops within a short stroll. San Petro is a 25 minute walk down the banks of the Tiber and the Colosseum and Pantheon a short walk over the river. The Gianicolo is a steepish hike up the Via Garibaldi (or a short bus ride). There are many fascinating buildings and you could spend a couple of days exploring in the Trastevere itself. We stayed in an inexpensive apartment in the Via Dei Riari, three minutes walk through the Porta Settimiana. Every night brought another surprise, buskers in the Piazzas, festival concerts and even an impromptu invitation from strangers to join a private birthday party, where the wine flowed and the songs went on into the early hours of the morning.

Trastevere. A lovely little suburb across the Tiber River! Or shall I say a lovely place which I found very appealing to all the hustle going on in Rome. If you love quiet streets with beautiful buildings and small shops this place is for you! In addition, the food! The food was very delicious and appealing to the palate. The pricing was also very inexpensive but the food was top drawer! I loved this little area so much that I was happy to find out about it in You Tube through Walter. He was right! Anyone going to Rome explore this area, I recommend it from my heart!

Night life the Italian way. Be it a night out with friends or a stroll with your family this is a lovely place to be. We went there for dinner and it happened to the the feast la Madonna di Noantri for which they held a traditional procession which we were lucky to come across. Dinner there was cheaper than in the rest of Rome and was also one of the best meals. Dessert was great with a torta di pera e ricotta. Live Italian music is played in the streets and by the restaurants by street musicians. There are also many stalls selling items such as jewellery and people in the area are friendly as in the rest of Rome. We happened to be walking past a church and a few boys aged around 16 from Mexico came to stop us so that we go and pray with them. They were missionaries and together with priests were there that night. Afterwards we went for a wonderful gelato further down the road at what the locals say is the best gealteria in rome...They also serve milkshakes with any flavour of ice-cream you choose.

Feel all the italian vibe. If you have a gift for good Italian food, nice places to walk and just see people, this is your place. No advanced tips required...maybe a good sense of orientation...but just walk and discover

Maybe Rome's most beautiful neighborhood. We were staying in Vialle di Trastevere so we could enjoy this place every day. The place is full of picturesque streets and beautiful bars and restaurants, but be careful of tourist traps. The most popular side is the west one, that is overcrowded, at least at summer. East of Vialle di Trastevere there are some quiet places where you can enjoy a photowalk, or a romantic dinner. At summer you can also enjoy a beer or a coctail by the river.

Great food and atmosphere galore!. Awesome place to come for pizzeria and ristorante! Many little cafes to done in with generally really friendly staff who speak good English. Food is fantastic, atmosphere welcoming and really well priced. After dinner head down to the river to go for a stroll and browse the markets (where you can also eat and drink). Plenty of opportunity to go out partying and drinking if you want to. Well worth a visit. Highly recommend La Fraschetta restaurant for authentic Italian experience.

Great place to live for a semester in Rome. Delightful old neighborhood just west of the Tiber from downtown Rome. Everything within the city is walk-able, though mass transit to and from most of Trastevere is limited. It's close (just south) of the Vatican, and has wonderful small shops, restaurants, grocers and bars. Hopping night life with a younger crowd. If you need a place to stay for a brief time, you could o much worse in Rome.

All time favorite neighborhood in Rome. We lived here for a year and might be a bit biased, but for us this is one of the most wonderful neighborhoods of Rome. If you go, be sure to get outside the tourist hub part of Trastevere...wander AWAY from the Piazza Santa Maria di Trastevere (once you can tear yourself away from the beautiful stone mosaics on the floor of this spectacular and intimate church)...Stroll south to Piazza San Cosimato in the AM and get fresh fruits and panini from the AM outdoor market. Sit in the playground on the piazza and eat your panini lunch, while watching local grandparents supervise their grand-children as they frolic on the play equipment. Take a strool farther up the hill to Villa Sciarra, a lovely park overlooking Trastevere. Meander over to the other side of Viale Trastevere and see the Bernini sculptures and catacombs in that less visited part of TRastevere...This is one neighborhood where tourists, local Trasteverinos, Italian actors, artists and workers and John Cabot international students all brush elbows...for better or for worse. We would not live or base ourselves anywhere else in Rome but here!

OK. I expected more from this neighborhood. In august it was "alone", almost nobody there, nothing to do. In Piazza Santa Maria there were a few Cafes and Bars and Restaurants opened. It did not impress me. The scenery is a bit "trip-to-the-mountains like" and some of the buildings are new and expensive, probably people live there, but that is all.

Old town ambiance, exuberant nite scene, Romans' hangout. What a great ought scene. This area is filled with small restaurants were locals come out for dinner and drinks. We had a great time. There are som many places around that it is difficult to chose from. We followed gut instinct by looking at whether the clients were locals and if the places were full or not and by taking a peek at he menu. By the time we left, a little bit after midnight, people were flocking into the area for the nightlife. Great area to hang out at nit like a Roman.

Travellers, but not the tour bus crowd. This area of Rome, literally "across the Tiber" extends for a long distance, from where the train station is, to the edge of the river where the bridge crosses at Viale Trastevere. While the immediate vicinity of the railway has little to recommend it, like many transport hubs, heading closer to the city and around the Piazza of Santa Maria there is a hive of restaurants, interesting shops and Italian life. Well recommended for travelling to Rome, rather than merely ticking the Big Items off the bucket list.

Italy by night. The highlight of the holiday was definitely my trip to the Trastevere, it's buzzing with people at night and it has all sorts of restaurants and ice cream places... Lemon granite while listening to the street shows they usually have on is an actual dream at night, go there during August because there is always something to see! I managed to be lucky enough to catch 2 live music shows just at the fountain and a fire juggler...all free and genuinely the best night out you'll have

Well worth a visit. Interesting place, contrast compared with other areas of Rome, such as the Vatican or the Forums. Great choice for a gastronomic visit, a lot of small trattorias with good cuisine. Also, walk through the small streets and shops were very good. But to stay in the area I would not recommend it.

A lovely lunch and walk, away from the crowds.. Our divine lunch, at a random little pizzeria that we have forgotten the name of, made this side trip very enjoyable. it's nice to get away from the crowds and there are quirky little shops to spark some interest. If your short on time, you could skip it. But if you have time, do try and find an authentic little place to eat... get off the main strip, turn a few corners (you will find your way out!) and find a gem. We did, and we wish we could remember the name of it, it was amazing.

okay to visit but not to stay .... Stayed in the Trastevere area for three nights, four days ... It was okay but found I preferred to spent time outside of the area, just cleaner and nicer. The cobblestone walkways, if not covered in dog Poop and speeding cars would have been neat. The area smelled. it was dirty and there was nothing authentic Italy aside from the old buildings, chruches and roadways. Total Tourist Trap. Walk just 3 minutes outside the area for a real coffee at half the price and 20 minutes outside of this area prices drop to half, with much better shopping options and real Italian food. I tried a few of the high rated restaurants but couldn't find a good meal; prepackaged, rehydrated and prebottled. Hounded by beggars and musicians for change and more English speaking people than Italian. It was okay to walk through for a few hours but I will definitely not be staying in this area again.

Not sure what all the fuss is about.... Apart from the food, which was amazing, I really don't get the appeal. Yes, parts of the neighbourhood are very pretty, but I honestly couldn't wait to return to Centro Storico. If you're in the area, it is a worthwhile visit, but I wouldn't necessarily make a special trip (unless you're a foodie like me!). We visited Trastevere after taking a peek through the Knights of Malta keyhole, which I would definitely recommend.

Old World Charm. Spend a day walking the small streets of Trastevere and you won't be disappointed. There is no hustle and bustle just people living their lives and giving you a glimpse of the old world charm of Rome. Don't miss the cookies at Biscottificio Innocenti and the pizza at Dar Poeta!
Fells like "Florenitne" in Rome. Best area to have drinks at 17:00 and snacks. Nice places to eat. very young area.You can have beer and snacks for 8 to 10 EURO

A lovely walk through a charming local neighborhood. If you get tired of the tourist packed sights in the classical center of Rome, take a walk through Trastevere. Trastevere is a beautiful local neighborhood that feels a little more like real Rome than some of the main attractions. Stop for a delicious Campari Orange at a cafe that squeezes fresh orange juice (you will know it by its orange table coverings). Sit and people watch. Stroll the streets. And just enjoy. A very pleasant afternoon at a slower pace!

Great atmosphere away from tourist hordes. This little neighbourhood was a delight and almost single-handedly reversed my poor first impression of Rome. Whilst still very much on the radar of tourists, you can be spared from the tour group hordes and find refuge in the quaint streets and fun atmosphere. There was a lot going on in terms of live music, casual wine drinking on the streets, performers, kids playing soccer, and a prominent 'alfresco culture' throughout. Don't miss it.
picturesque and lots of fun. Another not to be missed in Rome. I enjoyed walking around the quaint streets with all their side walk cafes, window shopping at the stores.

Love this area!. This was the best area to stay when in Rome -- Very walkable to the tourist areas, but enough away from it so you don't have to "fight the crowds" -- lots of restaurants and shops as well so you will never be bored! When I go back, I'm staying in this area again!

Love this neighborhood. My husband and I just spent our 10 year wedding anniversary in Italy and spent 4 days in Rome. We rented an apartment in Trastevere and were so glad. Within a few minutes walk from our place, there were hundreds of bars, cafes and restaurants.Fun little market for food every day on one of the plazas. Great night life and fun to just walk around an people watch. We ate dinner here every night. Was great to end the day close by to our apartment. The only downside I would say is that there is no Metro stop so if you don't want to walk, you have to learn which buses to take. That being said, I love to walk. We walked everywhere, even to the Piazza de Spagna. It took us about 20-30 minutes to walk to the Coliseum. Bring really comfortable shoes (like tennis shoes). I was trying to be more fashionable and did not bring tennis shoes for the daytime and that was a mistake.

A special neighbourhood in a Big City. It was raining, what should we do today, lets have a look at Trastevere. That's about how the conversation went. We really enjoyed the experience. Maybe not the rain but the location, across Isola Tiberina and walking into Trastevere was like walking back 60 or 70 years. The architecture which like Rome is centuries old. The narrow ally ways. The little Trattorias and bars, the kids playing in the ally ways (even in the rain), the river running by. If you have time don't miss it. It is likely closer the actual Rome than the Trevi Fountain.

Trastevere a place you must visit when you visit Rome. What a nice neighbourhood to take walk along the very pretty, cobblestoned and narrow streets. There is not o house that is like another. There is many open air restaurants if you want to eat or buy an icecream from the Gelatoshop. Italian icecream is very good indeed!

Did we miss something?. I can only conclude that we missed something everyone else found. It is reasonably attractive, but no more so than other areas. There is not much to see or do there other than eat. I can well believe that at night, if you go there for a meal, it's got a nice atmosphere. During the day it is nothing special.

A great base for exploring Rome. This was my favourite neighbourhood in Rome. I also loved Monti. Both have a more local flavour. Don't get me wrong - there were still tons of tourists, especially in the main square near the big church. The restaurants were better, and the narrow, cobblestone streets were full of character. We stayed near Via dei Salume and it was easy to walk to most sights in Rome. Wonderful

Old style real Italy. Take few hours to roam around this place having old colourful buildings and narrow streets. Visited Santa Maria church which is one of the oldest in Italy. Good open air restaurants to eat around like near Pantheon.

Very nice place to hang out. The neighbourhood is very pretty, with laundry hanging between windows and reddish-yellow walls. It's a lovely place to browse small shops (bags, urban clothing), and have a beer or more. It's also very cheap.Take the bus H at Termini to go to Trastevere, then lose yourselves in the small streets.

Il Piccolo Grande Chef da Nicola. The King of Artichokes is really the King of kindness! Wonderful menu of chef's recommendations. A must trip for the traveller to Rome to detour to Trastevere.
Via di Ponziano, 7/9

The neighborhood that delivers.. After 3 days of site seeing in Rome, we were wondering where was a neighborhood that exemplifies the Italy we Americans always see in the movies and on pretty postcards. Well, Trastevere is it!

My Favorite part of Rome. This neighborhood is so cool! Like an old Italian village center, in the middle of Rome.
Quiet during the day, but after dark Trastevere is the best place for night life in Rome.
This neighborhood is very popular among American students.

Great nightlife. I stayed in Trastevere for 4 nights while visiting Rome. It is a great city and I was able to walk to all of the museums, monuments, fountains, etc. that Rome has to offer. The city is very safe, clean and easy to get around. There are great restaurants, bars and shop or steps you can sit on and just enjoy the scenery. There is an American university in the city so you see many Americans, whish is nic to be around when in a foreign country. The nightlife is great!

Grazia & Graziella Restaurant Trastevere Rome. Found a terrific place for a glass of wine and tasting plate right beside S Maria church where the food and service was great so we returned for dinner 2 nights later. Delicious food, friendly service from Carmine in nice surroundings. There are many good places to eat in the area but we can recommend Graziia and Graziella

pretty disappointing. we were looking forward to strolling through this neighborhood for its atmosphere, and it was not worth the time spent. there are equally "atmospheric" side streets throughout the city, particularly in the centro storico area. the restaurants were poor, and it's pretty hard to navigate around. also, there are rather aggressive beggars everywhere- at one point i had to get pretty aggressive about telling them to beat it. these beggars are not italians- we were told they are "gypsies" and that the city recognizes it has a problem with this but has not figured out what to do. similar experience at the spanish steps, only not as bad. otherwise, didn't run into this anywhere else in the city. bottom line: there is no reason to go to trastavere- you can certainly find better things to do with the time saved.
Wander the Neighborhood. Spend some time just wandering the pedestrian/vespa streets and stopping occassionally for a gelato or a bite to eat.
Not very interesting when visited during daytime. I did not like the place very much, far away from the city life, yet I had a very good lunch treat at Graziella's resto.

Charming neighbourhood. We had read lots of recommendations about Trastevere, and spent a short afternoon just strolling around with no particular goal in mind. Just walking, enjoying the atmosphere, watching people, having a cup of coffee and a gelato and perhaps studying some maps and taking a few photos. Trastevere was so much more relaxing than the touristy parts of Rome. No awesome buildings (except for Santa Maria in Trastevere) and no amazing history, but real and authentic Italian. Take your time and enjoy the atmosphere!

Best a night. This is the best place to go after dark to stroll the streets and eat dinner. Beautiful streets with great stores and restaurants. Not touristy like some parts of Rome. I'd been to Rome a couple of times and had never ventured to this neighborhood. Big mistake. I will spend more time here next time I come to this wonderful city.
another maze. Nothing there, just old delapidated buildings, expensive pasta restaurants. Rabbit warren of buildings that you can get lost in, great.

A part of old Rome you must not miss.. You will always find a nice place to get a glass of wine or a meal to a very reasonable price. The old quarters are nice for a an evening stroll and the atmosphere is truly great.
NIGHTLIFE AREA AWAY FROM THE CENTRE. An area of restaurants and cafes and bars --something u can miss though as also far from other main sights if u r in rome only for a few days
Good Walking Neighborhood. Slightly off the beaten track, lots of good places to eat, a couple of churches loaded with beautiful art. Great place to spend an afternoon.

Trastevere. A must go area, it was a little difficult to get to by public transport from are hotel but not to far by taxi. always use the white taxis and make sure the meter is running.Very pretty area with its winding alleys and cobble stones lots of quirky shops popular it seems with locals and a few tourists. we ate at san calistus. after having be told it was the best pizzeria in rome. I do not agree with that. but intresting resturant. but if you are looking for a fantastic pizza i would try somewhere else

Walking around in Trastevere. I went to the TRastevere in the past but could not see where was this charm. This time, we spent a lot of time there, walking around, getting lost in the small streets and eating ice cream. It is really a nice area!

The spirit of Rome. Trastevere is the old and real Rome. The cobble streets, the smell of caffe (espresso) and the aroma from the pizzeria are just heavenly. Be sure to take out at least half a day to just have a leisurely stroll around the neighbourhood. Try to chat with one of the cafe owners while grabbing a coffee. Tip: The gelatos are much cheaper than the touristy area.

It's what you think of when you think of Italy. Great just to walk around, sit in the Piazza with an ice cream, hang out at a cafe, grab a pizza... anything. It's a wonderful little tiny town in a big city where if you live there, like me, you wave to the butcher on your way to work and he checks with you each November to ask if you want to order a Turkey.

My favorite by far. This is Rome to me. Cobblestone streets, old school buildings. My hotel was in this neighborhood, I swear one morning I woke up, looked out my balcony doors and saw an old italian woman hanging her laundry out to dry. Just like in the movies! The shopping here is great too. To this day my wife still gets compliments on her leather boots and simple cotton sweater. Oh, and the food is fabulous. I love this neighborhood. So much do that my wife and I are considering buying an apartment here.

in love. So typical of Rome! Amazing atmosphere, night or day, great places to eat, Santa Maria church and a lot of people by night (local or not).To go here, I went from Sant'Angelo Castle by foot, along the river. Although it was cold, it was worth it!! We roam around Trastevere and we found bars and restaurants, nice ones. So just explore..Good prices.A great place to visit or just relax, you will find Rome there for sure.

The "real" Rome. We spent a few hours roaming through Trastevere. It's much quieter than the rest of Rome. Barely any tourist/souvenir shops. A highlight was the church of Santa Maria - it was beautiful. We ended up eating at an osteria that was full of locals. No real menu - you ate what you were given!Check out the Almost Corner Bookshop for some quality English conversation - and books, of course!

Quirky, quaint and charming. This is a delightful area of Rome if you have several days in the city. Not worth the visit if you only have a couple of days - it would be better to do some history, culture, touristy sites and a few churches. Trastevere has a different feel to it - probably that it is real Rome and not just a tourist venue. Some charming buildings, lots of quaint shops selling a variety of items, a pleasant stroll over the river. You could pick up the atmosphere in under an hour, and stay for longer only if you love it. We did not find any public toilets in the streets we walked.

A Great Neighborhood Stroll. This is Rome's "Left Bank" or "Greenwich Village," if you will. It started becoming trendy years ago, but is still a place to wander through narrow lanes and still get the feeling of real ethnicity in this neighborhood. I think it has a whole different feel that the other side of the Tiber. For me, the mosaics in Santa Maria in Trastevere and Santa Cecilia, and the the panoramic view from the Giancolo are three of the real highlights here. I like to visit this area when I want to feel like less of a tourist.This is a wonderful area to walk during the day, and also for a fun evening out.

a great stroll. we were staying right by the Tevi Fountain.. and we walked all the way to Santa Maria - it must have taken us an hour and a bit...great views...and the best way to experience Trastevere...lot's of good and reasonably priced restaurant...walk, walk, walk

Pleasant places. Very cozy area. Good small restaurants. I was in Rome with my friends in January. Weather was given the remarkable (+15 С). Region of Trastevere of very small sizes. Attracts with the cozy, small small streets.

Time of your life. Our first time in Italy and stayed in Trastevere. What a find! We wanted to be with the locals and found the perfect place. Right outside our apartment were restaurants, bars, shipping and the most beautiful churches. Small cobblestone streets are lined with fantastic food and shopping. So much fun to walk around and get lost in the small street and see museums and coffee bars to sit and people watch. I didn't want to leave but I know I will be back.
have a walk here. i liked the area,is full of life and shops and trattorias and bars, has vivid colors,has the mediterranean air! for sure have a walk here!
Incredible Area. this was a really nice area across the river with so many places to eats, cafes Gelato and just so incredible of an atmosphere, the food was crazy everywhere in this area

A bit out of the way but worth the trip.. Every Sunday there is a massive flea market held at Porta Portese. It's easy to get lost in the sea of stalls selling everyday goods from clothing to DVDs. If you are looking for a fun way to spend a Sunday I would definitely recommend spending it here.

Some of the Best Food in Rome. Trastevere is one of the oldest areas of Rome, and you can find traditional Roman cuisine here. Narrow streets, incredibly old buildings, and incredible food. Try to avoid restaurants with menus in english (or menus at all) - this goes for anywhere in Rome.
Best area to get lost. it's the best place to get lost and just wonder around, I took at least 100 photos...and all these bars, cafes and restaurants, all so inviting.

Nice area, plenty of restaurants. Went here on a quiet time of year so the weather wasn't great and many of the restaurants were shut. That said it seems a nice place, lots of small alleyways and restaurants, quiet squares. Should be very nice for a hot summer evening.

Trastevere. If someone hadn't told us to go to Trastevere we would have missed such a wonderful experience. I loved the walk across the bridge to get there and the little restaurants are cheaper and real finds. We also found a great place that had a Happy Hour at 10 pm and it was a take away. We got $3 drinks and walked out with them. It is great for younger people because of the cost so it is a good place to go for a late evening.

If you have time... go!. My wife and I had about a week of relaxing time in Rome. We hung out here for a day. Cool place and cool vibe. Lots of young people, and good pubs down here. There are many cool churches as well.There is not one "main attraction' here. You're just going to hang out in an old Roman neighborhood. You'll understand when you get there...

Esthnic food street away from Crowded Touristic places!. As we know Rome is busy place with tourists, however, this place seems for more locals, young people. lots of small resto, mostly esthnic food. cute and pretty decorations. it is frequently visited by locals than tourists. Located Vatican side, acrossed the river. People only visit Vatican but not this neighbor streets which is quite attractive, specially in the evening.

Picturesque. It is said that it is the most Roman quarter of Rome. A little neglected and "wild" offers small, narrow streets, several churches such as St Cecilia or Basilica S. Maria in Trastevere. Genuine restaurants where the locals dine can be found. Very picturesque, not so crowded as Centro Storico, worth visiting.

Vivacious Trastevere.. A collection of narrow alleyways, tiny streets, all leading to some hidden gem. Trastevere is the real heart of Rome, where you'll find the real Romani, doing their shopping, having their lunches, their aperitivi, their dinners, away from the tourist traps. A place that makes you feel welcome, the first time you see it. It's home away from home.

beautiful and great food. This is the most romantic place i have ever been, just sitting watching the world go by in the cobbled streets of trastevere was the best thing we did in rome, the small restaurants have great food and do tourist menus that are reasonable and so tasty. There are loads of bars great places to have a glass of wine and relax after a day of sightseeing

Marvelous Neighborhood for Eating and Strolling. Some years ago I lived in Rome for several months. I would frequently spend my evenings in Trastevere, where the food is terrific and the streets are lively at night and romantic in a very Roman way. You can find restaurants all across the price scale. Don't bother looking for Chinese or Thai, it's Rome after all and Italian cuisine rules - and rocks too. It's easy to walk to Trastevere from Piazza Navona, Piazza di Spagna, or many other centers of touristic interest. The walk is particularly lovely in the early evening when the light is magical. Walking helps tune up the appetite as well. Eating out in Rome tends to be on the later side, which gives you plenty of time to wander first. Have a drink at a cafe if your tummy rumbles. That's a great experience too.
Great place to eat and watch.. Especially in the evening a great place to watch all kinds of people. Superbe restaurants and pubs. Friday and Saturdays hardly any parking opportunities.

a different Roman experience. The cobbled streets and medieval buildings are full of unique shops and workshops where you can find original creations by local artists, jewellers and tailors as well as the latest designer fashions.There are also plenty of cafes and restaurants, just avoid the ones touting the infamous "tourist menu" and you'll be fine. One I'd recommend is Trattoria Gli Amici, a cooperative. Plenty of others offer typical Roman fare at reasonable prices.

Don't miss this jewel.. Walking, eating, sightseeing, church watching, this place has it all.Have been coming to Trastevere for 30 years. Never miss it. Top rated restaurant is Sabatini, In the main church square, but really, one can have an excellent in any of the 50 or so restaurants within walking distance from this excellent restaurant. To get a real look at Roman life, and a feeling of inclusiveness, don't miss this jewel. Acturally, you can walk there in 15-20 minutes from the Vatican.Fun restaurant, touristy, yet really fun is Da Mel Petacco. See my review of this restaurant. I wouldn't miss it. We go every time we go to Rome.

Animated and cool!. Animated and cool neighboorhood crowded with young locals having fun! Centrally located and just a walking distance from all the major historical attractions. Full of bars and restaurants from all price ranges. Go there on a Friday or Saturday evening to enjoy the ambiance. The fun goes on until sunlight!

Away from the crowds. Just the other side of the water from Central Rome, within easy walking distance to all major sites. Cobbled streets, colourful buildings, friendly locals, great inexpensive restaurants.

A colored and old neighborhood. Trastevere is the oldest neighborhood of Rome and it's the most authentic one, with narrow streets and old buildings. If you're there, don't miss the Santa Maria in Trastevere Church.

My favorite area in Rome!. Narrow cobbled streets like you would imagine to find in Italy combined with the best restaurants for dinner and nightlife. What more would you ask? This is also very Bohemian and artsy area so expect to find small art galleries and designer shops, tucked between the bars and restaurants...

Nice place to explore. Trastevere was very picturesque and a lovely place to spend an afternoon or morning exploring. Not much to see though, other than the much-touted lines of washing hung across the buildings and vine-covered buildings.

great place to wander around. Trastevere is a great place to wander around. they have great shops and restraunts. they also have a few churches worth checking out. I downloaded Rick Steves walking tour for Trastevere on my i phone and it took me through Trastevere, to some churches and great gillato. I travel by myself so having the R.S. walking tour on my i phone i never got lost. this is a lively place but has some of the best restraunts in town
A beautiful area. This area of Rome is all about small narrow streets, cobble stones, lots of wonderful restaurants and unique shops. It is very lively, quaint, a photographers delight.

A very Roman-like atmosphere. DO NOT miss this area when you visit Rome: a wonderful neighbourhood full of the true Italian spirit: restaurants, little shops, squares and Roman churches filled with lively people to enjoy and appreciate their spirit..

Across the Tiber River. Across the river is the meaning of Travestere which was the original Rome. Not as touristy as the City the Romans built later. More quite here and has plenty of restaurants which are more reasonably priced with good food. Locals enjoy eating out here and with less chance of restaurants with very clever way of squeezing more money from visitors.

Not too many tourists. Well worth going, because it is not overrun with tourists. Although still bustling it has a different atmosphere from "the other side of the river". Lovely relaxed restaurants and shops.

This place has really changed, for the worse.. We were kind of disappointed in Trastevere. This place used to be an authentic little neighborhood lost in time - Mom and pop stores, old world charm - Now it's all fancy boutiques, trendy bars, and over-priced restaurants that cater to tourists.
Great value. A little bit out of the way of the main touristy spots, but well worth a visit, as 3 course dinner, wine and cocktails here cost the same as a main course and wine in helzevia and trevi.

Not as nice as I thought it would be. While the Trastevere area does have quaint narrow roads, it does not compare with the other areas around the Piazza Navona or the Spanish Steps. It is still more interesting to be on the other side of the Tiber. It seemed a rather sleepy area.

Worth a visit. Just go here and get lost. We shopped for gifts, entered an art gallery, prayed in Santa Maria and topped it off with ice cream from Dollce Sorriso (about 5 minutes north of the Island). What a day.
nice to wander. nice place to wander around, and a different feel to the rest of Rome. just over the river past the hospital worth a look if you have time

Very dynamic. A friendly neighborhood that is busy but not overwhelmed with tourists. The kids picked up on the energy-vibe and had fun, and we had a great family dinner at a sidewalk pizza place. Also shady and out of the sun. A taxi stand in close by, near the river.

I left my heart in Trastevere. I absolutely fell in love with Trastevere... We had an apartment on Via Dei Genovesi for ten nights. It such a quaint neighborhood. One of my biggest joys was standing at the open window, listening to the locals rattle on in beautiful Italian, the lovely ringing of the bells of St. Cecilia, the buzz of the scooters making their way through the narrow, cobblestone streets... It makes my heart smile. I loved meandering the streets here in the evenings. Some of the best food I had in Rome was in Trastevere. Go to Roma Sparita and enjoy their signature Cacio e Pepe with a bottle of Frascati. Ristorante Spirito DiVino is an absolute must! Family run (the father runs the place and he will give you the history of the building and describes the menu to you in detail and in your native language, the mother cooks, and son handles the wine) and some seriously delicious food - I had the pork which was, supposedly, from a recipe that was passed down from the favorite chef of Julius Ceasar - delicious. After dinner, the host will insist you visit his wine cellar - which is older than the Colosseum - and insists you take your wine and take your time there. :) If you want a true Roma experience and aren't afraid of some walking (we walked everywhere while in Rome from our base here) then I highly recommend staying here. It is a wonderful thing to be able to escape the crowds of tourists. Even if you choose not to stay here, at the very least go. Have dinner - have an adventure! Enjoy yourself!
A wonderful section of Rome. We had the best lasagna ever at one of its many little restaurants. This place is wonderful at night.

Go to Trastevere. I always enjoyed to walk along the Tevere River, and arrive in the district of Trastevere. Visit the beautiful church, Santa Maria dei
Trastevere, and at night enjoy a drink or dinner in one of the many rsetaurants around.

Dazzling - feels like a movie set. After a 21 hour flight from Australia, we were driven to this neighbourhood where our apartment was located. We couldn't believe it. A quiet, cobblestoned street with a tiny restaurant outside, one of those gorgeous Roman drinking fountains right at the door....I felt like we had been dropped into a movie set. It was exquisite.The rest of Trastevere was equally as beautiful and we were so enchanted it was hard to leave and see the rest of Rome. Only small minus about staying there was the distance to the attractions, however we mostly took cabs which were about 8 euros to the Colosseum for example. Public transport was also easily accessible.This is a must-see and stay there if you can. Our apartment was 1200 euros for five nights but between four of us, it was good value.

Heartbeat of Rome. Excellent area to visit with a variety of restaurants and hidden gems for shopping.However, there are some famous small trattorias where you have to book a table before you go since there are few.

Love the Area!. We loved this quieter, low key neighborhood of Rome, where we stayed for three nights! Great restaurants, cafes, sites... Don't miss the Church of Santa Maria in Trastevere - a ,most beautiful church!

If you haven't gone to Trastevere you haven't been in Rome. The look and feel of this neighborhood is fantastic. Take the time to visit one of the local pizzerias and just people-watch... I can only compare it meditation.
Great place to stay. Plenty going on to be exciting without being hectic. Lots of places to eat to suit all tastes and wallets.
when in rome..stay in the trastevere. loveedddd staying here. great location. amazing food and shopping around every corner. will definitely stay here on my next trip to rome. loved it!

When in Rome.. go to Travestevere!. We had a delightful lazy lunch on a hot day in this lovely district close to the centre of Rome. It was vibrant , colourful and full of happy tourists taking some time out from the madness of the major attractions. We ate outdoors in one of the many restaurants - the ambience was fitting , the wine flowed , and we loved our set 3 course menu as we whiled away a very pleasant two hours in a lovely setting . ...
the place to stay when in rome. we stayed in this place for 5 nights, it is very alive and restaurants there are very crowded , nice, tasty food and lovely peoplerecommended
picturesque block. we lived in Trastevere and I love the district. though the connection to the city center is not very convenient

Magical area in Rome. Our last stay in Rome was at a very nice apartment on a quiet street ( Via della Cisterna)of this wonderful area of the city. It´s an amazing experience walking through the tiny narrow streets, full of plants and flowers, colours, people and restaurants of all kinds, mainly pizzerias. I would reccomend anyone to rent an appartment there because you´ll never get tired of looking to all the attractions Trastevere presents, musicians, outside artists and in general a very funny atmosphere!I´d reccomend to have a glass of excellent prosecco at Enoteca Ferrara!!!! You´ll never forget that place!

Great place to hang; eat/drink. Extremely fun area on the "other" side of the Tiber. Young crowds. We are in our early-mid thirties, and grabbed dinner around 8pm and had drinks after. Perfect! No swarms of fanny-packed ugly tourists. Good energy. Good vibe. Started getting a little too young and a little too cannot handle my alcohol crew getting after it once you hit 11pm, but before that, it was pretty solid. By far the best area to hang out in at night if you are sub-40 and like more energy and less touristy. Also, felt more safe hanging out down there than even a sparsely attended Veneto. Good times.

Great place for food, drinks and atmosphere. Great place to end the day. Walk through the streets, enjoy the outside artists, music and live atmosphere.Many options for dinning and great ice-cream places to finish the evening on a sweet note

Great atmosphere. Trastevere is amazing. Tiny, little streets with lots of restaurants run by locals. Food is delicious - far less touristic than in the city center and much cheaper. Great place for an evening dinner and walk along the Tevere river. Easy access on foot or by local train from Termini station (change to tram number at the Trastevere station).
Nice neighborhood. Wonderful restaurants and cute little unique areas. Made for a nice stroll after we toured around all day.
Nice area. If you have the time, this is a great destination for an evening walk. Nice streets and restaurants.

Fantastic dining experience. Fantastic experience...great food, inexpensive above all great atmosphere.Were there on a week night and at midnight all restaraunts in the area were still full some of the stores too were open.Must visit if you are a foodie

Best nightlife- don't miss the river bank activity in summer. The area may be quiet during the day but it still had cute shops. At night the vendors are out, the fruit stands are busy and restaurants alive!! Twisting narrow streets emptying into small piazzas holding churches, monuments or staircases to sit on. Try Da Poeta for Pizza somewhere between the style in Naples and Rome or Casetta De'Trastevere for inexpensive and flavorful Roman fare. The river in the summer is great-White tent covered Hooka bars, futball tables, all types of food- Indian, Asian and Mexican( not typical in Rome). Just strool along and take it all in. Lots of shops set up. This is the place to see and be seen. Everyone is friendly and happy here, and why not?

My favorite part of Rome. This is authentic, medieval Rome, and the winding streets and old churches --plus great. affordable osterie and trattorie for lunch or dinner makes it a great place to wander and find new things or get lost. It also has my favorite Roman church, Santa Maria in Trastevere, as well as being near the Janiculum hill and gardens.

Excellent Place For Dinner. During our 7 days stay in Rome, we had dinner in Trastevere 3 times. There are a lot of very good reasonably priced restaurants and taverns; a nice break from the often utterly overpriced places you find around Piazza Navona or other central areas of Rome. After dinner, explore the narrow cobble streets and check out the little shops and boutiques or get yourself a nice gelato for desert.

Hidden Gem. This place is a bit awkward to get to - you have to change transport. However I did not regret for a minute I spent time travelling to Trastevere.For me, this was a hidden gem of Rome. It's so different, it doesn't even feel like you're in Rome. Small streets, loads of romantic restaurants, tiny colorful houses and friendly people... I enjoyed every bit of it - it's so cosy and warm! It's very quite and feels so far from all the hassle of central Rome.Also, this is a place to eat! Massive choice of gorgeous restaurants offering authentic Italian food at VERY IMPRESSIVE prices!
Super district. Great destination by night, dinner and walk around. If you go at the end of the day you may go up to Gianicolo for one of the greatest views of Rome

A great place to walk and eat. This area is a fantastic place to walk and explore on your own. There is a lot of history here and many restaurants to eat at. At dusk this becomes a hot spot of locals who parade the streets and eat their suppers. This area connects the Vatican with the Ancient central Rome although it is across the Tiber.

You want to find "real" Rome - well, so does every other tourist. First off - it's a lovely area. Definitely. Very Italian, lots of elegant, ivy-covered walls and romantic, cobblestone alleys. It ticks all the boxes for your Roman dream. Everyone says to come here to experience "real" Rome, so you do - along with every other tourist in city. I admit, I felt a little ludicrous wandering the streets once I realised that every other single person I saw was also a tourist doing the same thing. I felt like I was walking some movie set - the place was empty except for us tourists. We were all trying to do something different and ended up being absolute clones of each other and with not a local in sight! However, I think this was mostly because they were all at work, so probably the place is a little more authentic and 'vibe-y' in the evenings and on weekends.

Get lost and feel authentic!. Of all the monuments, landmarks and historic hooplah Rome has to offer, it was the neighborhood of Trastevere that I enjoyed the most. Although situated at the other end of map (relative to where my hotel was located) I found myself back there each night during my 6 day trip. When in Rome, you MUST go to Trastevere, eat, shop, sip and people watch there. Best gelato along San Francisco de Ripa, enjoy a spritz on one of the many bars and restaurants along the Tevere and authentic Roman food in a quiet restaurant in a hidden corner. Fantastic!

Beatiful Place. A couple of friends and myself went to this great place at night. The nightlife here is very bouyant, a lot of young romans having a great time. Many little bars packed ! Nice place to hang out at night, very local feeling.

Beautiful area to walk in the evening!. This is a very nice area with narrow alley's carrying a lot of boutique shops. I would suggest coming here in the evening because there's lots of festive lights and some shops stay open past dinner.If you're on a time constraint, it's not a place you have to go to, but if you have about an hour in the day or evening, you should check this area out quickly because it's an awesome boutique part of Rome.

nice area, good atmosphere-good place for dinning, relax or night life in a relaxed way. was a very nice area in Rome-full of small valleys and squares. countless cafes, bars, restaurants-very warm atmosphere which makes you very well welcomed even though being alone. Have a sit facing the street and take a drink, ppl watching can be just so nice for the afternoon while the sun is burning.

Great place to stay!. We have stayed in Trastavere a couple of times on visits to Rome. Plenty of holiday apartments that you can rent for a few days or longer. This time, we had a roof garden that was sunny in the morning, then shady in the evening - wonderful!Narrow cobbled streets mean that there are few cars (more Vespas though, so keep an ear out), while on every corner there is a local bar or cafe. You can walk everywhere and the local shops and markets (Camp dei Fiori is not far) are good for those on a budget and struggling with restaurant prices. Buses and trams are also there to get you into the City.

Artsy and crowded street nightlife. Spent a Saturday evening in August. After 10 pm this area is packed with locals visiting the many restaurants and bars, especially beer establishments. Very fun to stroll the streets and get a feel for what the locals enjoy plus people watch. Was disappointed in the amount of graffiti. Almost every building wall, doorway, sign, bench surface was tagged in some way. One poor restaurateur was scrubbing his sign just so you could read the establishments name.

A bit off the beaten path.... Get away from the most touristy part of the city and cross the river. This is where you will find the locals hanging out. This is also where you can find most authentic restaurants and cheaper meals. This is also where you can find more grocery stores and wine stores.
Real Rome.. Beautiful buildings and a fair few local restaurants to see here. This is real Roman life. Definitely worth a stroll on a more relaxing day.

Half price on all restaurants. Trastevere is nice, charming and peaceful. You can see laundry hanging out from the windows to dry (just like in "Lady and the Tramp") and if you are on a budget; this is were you should dine. Much cheaper than on the other side of the river!!

The Greenwich Village of Rome. Best seen at night. Cool artists' shops, great food...it is where the locals go to eat and hang out. Visit by day and you'll see the Hebrew signs in many store windows, reminding you that the area was a Jewish ghetto. Now a must-see for the true lover of Rome..

A must for the church but otherwise so so. We were told that Trastevere was the 'Left Bank' of Rome. Personally I did not find it to be that at all. Clearly it is the old quarter of Rome and has been described as being 'seedy'. Again I did not find this. It appears to be nothing than a old, residential area. Nothing remarkable but there are one or two buildings and restaurants that would not look out of place in a Sicilian Mafioso movie. We did find a good restaurant away for the tourist part of Trastevere. Word of caution, when we went the Tram service from Largo di Torre Argentina was not running and it did not look as if it had been for some time. It is however only a short walk across the bridge over the River Tiber to get to Trastavere. The banks of the Tiber did look a bit trashy and appear to be where a lot of the young people go to drink and socialise.
Perfect first day in Rome.. Plenty to do - national gallery, churches, shops, restaurants and gelato! Really recommend you spend an evening there.

FUN Place. My family and I were told by our hotel receptionist we needed to go to this area in the evening and walk along the canal. There were vendors selling their wares, outdoor bars and eateries and it was VERY NICE! We sat and had a drink and were people watching and had a very nice time. I highly suggest visiting this area.

A real gem!. We stayed in Trestevre in our trip to Rome. It was perfect. It is a very old neighbourhood with lots of interesting things, beautifully designed old buildings and little streets to discover. Most of the streets are very narrow and full of nice restaurants and cafes all over the neighbourhood. It is so relaxing, and charming, we looked forward coming back to Trestevere at the end of a tiring day in Rome and felt refreshed immediately. The little square around Ponte Sisto is full of Italians in the evening, sitting on the stairs of the fountain and enjoying the night with some wine and pizza. Ponte Garibaldi Bridge is another nice spot to walk around. Trestevere is quiet near to Campo De Fiori and Plazza Navona. Try Paraloccia Cafe( not the restaurant next door) for snacks and very good but inexpensive wine.

My favourite Rome!. Trastevere express another side of Rome, the boemian one, but it´s totally amazing!!! The streets, the restaurantes, the people... everything absolutelly special. A perfect place to let Rome welcomes you :-)
Where my college is. A person can feel the true Roman environment. Many pubs&restaurants, lots of young people, full of life on Friday and Saturday night and not as dangerous as Campo de' Fiori.
wow, lovely area. even picked up a free rome t shirt from the guys promoting rome in the park! lovely fountain, great views of rome
Ugly area. Not worth the visit, an ugly area with nothing to see
Wonderful. This is a great district, off the beaten path of tourists, in which to just wander around. Best restaurants and cafès in the city also.

Don't miss this great area.. It is "on the other side" of the Tibur. It started out with working class people and has arrived as a night spot for all of Rome. Great selection of neighborhoods to walk through and absorb Italian culture. Great selection of restaurants with a site for every budget. Great number of piazzas to experience the local people gathering in the evenings. Wonderful churches to view and attend.I did not know about this place until the tour was arranged and I agree you couldn't find a better place to "base" your Roman excursions.

One of the most charming areas of Rome!. I absolutely loved this pedestrian area, so full of charm. It is a real little haven of peace and calm and so welcomed after having been in the heavily touristic areas of Rome. The pretty narrow streets are full of lively restaurants, bars and small quality boutiques. It has a more authentic feel than many other areas of Rome. Do not forget to visit some of the churches in the area, particularly the magnificent Santa Maria in Trastevere in the Piazza of the same name, but be mindful of the opening hours. They’ll be closed at night if you are just coming to the area for dinner. I had some of the best pizza in Rome in a tiny little hole in the wall in this neighborhood but there are also loads of casual and chic places to choose from so something for everyone. Warning to women, it is better if you are not wearing heels, the space between the cobblestones in some area is frighteningly large. You risk ruining your shoes or getting stuck and twisting an ankle or worse. Woody Allen showcased Trastevere is his latest film, “To Rome with Love”. The next time I return to Rome (and I will because I threw a coin in the Trevi Fountain!) Trastevere is one of the places that I will definitely race back to.

cool. One of the places to be in the evening/ at night. Many bars and restaurants, crowds ... drinks. Good energy. For day time you can checkout the botanic garden, Gianicolo hill with nice view , fountain and park and the Santa Maria in Trastevere church and piazza
just it.... I just felt so lovely at this place...everything felt so italian...not so many tourists either...the rythim of this place is quite slow and that's what i loved mostly..

Good local spot. This is a good local spot. You have plenty good restaurants, and nightlife. You will want to cab it from here to the major sights though. We stayed at Hotel San Francesco and really enjoyed it. Highly recommend the area.

Across the Tevere.. At about 6pm each night, a cooling breeze blows through the Eternal City, making it not only bearable in July/August, but purely magical to be in amongst the 'passaggieri' people. Families, lovers, friends and tourists all mix and mingle in an age-old tradition of simply ambling through quaint cobbled alleys and corridors, breathing in the Roman philosophy of "dolce fa niente". There is something for everyone in Trastevere and I truly missed my sweetheart on this occasion as it was sooo romantic. We ate at Carlomenta Ristorante and 4 euro got us yet another classic pizza at a great spot.

Great place it feels like Greece. It is really a very nice area to walk arround. We visited the area during the day and night. There are many restaurands with normal prices. You should definately visit it.

Charming at night. Night time in Trastevere is a charming, relaxing atmosphere. If you want to mix with locals enjoying life come here for dinner and an evening stroll. Plus the restaurants are, I believe, the best in Rome.

Nice!. Small alleys, great restaurants, and good beer-bars. Trastevere has everything! We enjoyed the food we ate, and the beers at Ma Che Siete Venuti A Fa' is just great! Romantic to walk along the small alleys, and the romans greet you nicely!

Accross the Tiber. I just loved the extension of all the cobblestone narrow streets from the main city and the picturesque buildings. Just walked through the area quite quickly but would love to visit again & spend more time.

Nice area for dinner. Worth a visit with lots of winding alley ways with a gastronomical treat at each turn.
For an after dinner stroll there are bars and cafes along the river banks
Great nightlife. Good food, good atmosphere, lively and laid back. Another side to Rome...
Good restaurants.. Plenty of good restaurant, but not the most inspiring area of Rome. If you have a lengthy stay then you should go, but on a short trip Id opt for other regions first
Beautiful: A Rome Must. This is a family favorite. A great place to wander the streets or find a quiet place to just relax. Great restaurants in this area. A Rome Must
You really have not finished your trip to Rome. until you spend time wandering and eating in this area of Rome
great pizza!. We went to a bakery there which served also pieces of Italian pizza to take-away. great experience.
First Visit. Loved this area, my favourite area to hangout and watch the world go by.

Good for wandering and eating. We took the lovely walk above Trastevere from the children's hospital side along the Gianicolo, and enjoyed the views and sculptures and monuments before heading down the hill for lunch.Some narrow treets with many, many restaurants and people going about their daily business. Some areas bustling. Some areas quiet. We found a pizzeria with good pasta for lunch, and sat and watched the passing tourists and locals. A good vibe ... but sadly ended up at the botanical gardens, which was a total disappointment. Don't waste your money!
