A lovely part of Rome. Full of character with small coble stone roads with little restarants and shops in little alley ways. Comfortable shoes are the order fo the day, but the stroll is well worthwhile.

worth a visit. Really enjoyed an evening exploring Trastevere, lots of narrow streets and little squares to get lost in and soak up the atmosphere. There are some great value restaurants but some have hiked up the prices for the tourists so look around before you choose. Some interesting shops too. An easy walk from the Vatican or the Centro Storico or the H bus from termini takes you there.
Very cute. I wouldn't call this a must see for everyone. Its just a very nice and cute romantic neighbourhood. I loved it!

Real taste of Roma!. My husband and I made the trek to Trastevere and it was one of our favorite parts of Rome. It was full of young people and families, great bars and THE best gelato i had during my entire trip in Italy. Make it a point to visit, you won't be disappointed, and the food is good at any restaurant. Not close to a Metro line, so I would suggest visiting it after a morning at the Vatican.

Wonderful!. A great area, very laid back and picturesque. There's a photo opportunity everywhere you look and yes sometimes it's graffiti on a door but it feels arty rather than tatty. This was our favourite neighbourhood of Rome and the Piazza Maria de Trastevere is lovely. I'm already missing it!

Charming only if you dig lots of graffiti. Trastevere's reputation as a hip venue for people watching and edgy restaurants falls apart amid the mindless graffiti, congestion and dingy streets. We stayed in a former cloister -- a gated community that dated from the 18th Century. Outside the gate roamed a never-ending stream of individuals looking for a place to go. I always felt like I was leaving a sold-out stadium at the end of a baseball game.To be sure, Trastevere contains some outstanding historic sites and restaurants. But having lived through the desecration of New York and Chicago when graffiti artists were considered inspired, I fail to see the charm in Trastevere in 2012.

Worth the walk. This is the other side of the river from most attractions in the city, but certainly worth the extra walk to spend some time in real Rome, with more authentic restaurants and interesting streets.
A fabulous part of the city. Old buildings and streets full of real live Romans. Great area for eating, shopping and staying.

Not to be missed. Don't miss a daytime and night time visit to this artsy area. It's narrow streets can easily get confusing. We were totally lost but used our trusty iPhone map app to plot us out and back to our hotel. It works great in Rome.

Best area in Rome, blows the overated Spanish Steps away unless looking for designer wear. H bus from the station or a 64 bus getting off a Torre di Argentina and a Tram across the Tiber to Romes coolest neighborhood "TRAS ( to cross a boundry - like in trespass) Tevere ( the River IS the boundry and you are now on the right bank...the REAL one not to be confused with PARIS!....o thats PARIS is a Roman town covering up their old stuff from Roman times with the DISNEY version alla Haussman....Great Atmosphere without the FOOTLOCKER stores....average to great Restaurants, such as GLASS if you made a Rez in advance..., and the oldest church in Rome...To find your way out head over Ponte SISTO to the center by way of Campo di Fiore and find a Taxi on Victor Emanuelle as on weekends the Taxi stand by the river at Piazza Belli is a nightmarealthough you can catch the H bus if you are not too late or the tram back over the river .... Problems arise when you are after 1am

Great intriging medieval quarter of Rome. The heart of this quarter is the 4th century basilica of St. Mary in Trastevere, reached by turning from Viale Trastevere to Via S. Francesco a Ripa and walking several blocks. The quarter is either side of the large Viale Trastevere street and houses many beautiful , quaint old buildings, many boutique stores with neat objects, great bars and restaurants and many well-to-do expats love to live here and buy or rent homes in the small , winding streets of this old quarter where the inhabitants call themselves the "Noiantri", or "Us people". KNown for great night life, also.

Lively area, nice atmosphere. I loved this area of Rome. There are some great places to eat, and the bars looked like good places to visit. It has a nice chilled out atmosphere, it's not as hectic as the centre of Rome. It is quite a mixed crowd that visit - old and young. It reminded me of Venice, my Husband said that too - obviously minus the canals and gondolas!This is a pretty and lively neighbourhood, definitely go and visit whilst in Rome.

A lovely part of Rome. For those who like to walk and roam 'old city' places, this is the place to visit whilst in Rome. Cobbled narrow streets feature in this part of Rome. We went there on the first day we arrived. We first went to Restaurant Calisto to book a table as we were told that it was a very popular restaurant. We then visited the church Sta Maria in Trastevere. Afterwards we proceeded on to Orto Botanico which was a very nice botanic garden split up in sections such as the rose garden, the cane garden, the Japanese garden etc. There was a small entrance fee of €4 but it was worth it. After that we took a walk on the Gianicolo where at the top of the hill you see a lovely view of Rome. We then headed back to the restaurant for a meal where the staff where very friendly and the food very good.

Energetic neighborhood with great bars and restaurants!. Great place to have drinks and dinner! Younger crowd but plenty of people over 40! If you are in the mood for a beer at a pub - you'll find many here. Also many great restaurants to choose from. If we were staying longer in Rome, we would have went back here again.

All the Night Life!. If you are looking for fun and night-life this is the place to be.It is basically full of students, and gives such a young and fun student life feeling it is practically unbelievable.This is where all the hustle and bustle happens.Night life and bars are splendid. A unique shopping area as well with little boutiques and hand made ornaments.Restaurants and Cafe's and also live shows.We were staying at Trastevere, and it was so worth it.This is the city life we should all be exposed to!

A beautiful quaint are of Rome!!!!. If you think the only thing to see across the Tiber is St Peters,you are mistaken.If you want to see how the true Italian lives,eats,drinks espresso,visits with friends this is the place for you.You can go by bus,tram,taxi.Get there any way you can and experience the true Italian way of life.It is truely an experience!!!It was November of 2010 when i was there last!!!!

Vibrant Area. We stayed in Trastevere because our daughter was living there during her semester studying in Rome. We thoroughly enjoyed our experience there. We walked to the top of the Via Garibaldi to the Gianicolo gardens, through the residential areas, visited the various churches, ate at lots of different restaurants and enjoyed the experience of walking among families, young people and locals, all out for dinner or a drink or a gelato. Highly recommend it - Make sure you go beyond the Piazza Santa Maria Trastevere, which is all we had done before this trip. Head up hill on Via Garibaldi or wander among the streets leading away from the river.
A great place to visit and stay. My wife and I stayed in Trastevere on our visit to Rome. It is a vibrant lively Roman town just on the other side of the Tiber. Great place!!!

Splendid quarter. a magnificent quarter, linked to the rest of the city by the 117 and 116 buses, lots of boutiques and shops and pizzerias... Totally recommend it, especially by night (evening)...also visit Basilica of St Maria di Trastevere
Nice and lovely. The little streets and taverns, the wonderful gelaterias … It’s wonderful to get lost there.
Lovely Quaint Area. Lovely Quaint Area very different from the rest of Rome. Two fascinating churches which shouldn't be ignored.
No to be missed. Great place for a stroll in the evening, many good resturants.
across the tiber. saint angelos castle was very interesting, design and archetucture was quite unusual. beautiful views looking back across the river to rome.
Lots of eateries. I like how quaint and laid back the whole area is. Give the restaurants a try!

"THE" place in Rome - check it out - Great. The place is always buzzing. At night it is just incredible to think of the number of people walking around. It is "the" place to be. There are many restaurants, cafes, gelaterias, side walk vendors, and stores open till quite late.
True Rome. True Rome - small shops, narrow streets. Best restaurants and coffee shops in Rome.

Away from touristic places. I liked this area of Rome mostly for its tranquility compared to a noisy city center with millions of tourists. You can ear here cheaper than in the downtown area, and see more locals and buy things as well. Try swinging by in the later afternoon and enjoy the experience!

A must in the evening. Great place to go once you finish your daytime touring. Lots of great restaurants, bars and shops. As well, you get to walk over the Tiber, which is beautifully lit up at night.
Love Rome the people are so chique. The weather was perfect loved the history and architecture

Life is good. Trastevere means in the other side of the Tevere River. As such this quarter offers different experience. As being one of the oldest Neighborhoods in Rome the streets are narrow the building are smaller and the atmosphere is young. Make sure you plan ahead, rest the afternoon in the hotel, and visit Trastevere for an evening drink followed by a dinner in one of the many great restaurants. Shopping, bars, people, music, good food, are to be found plenty. Go!

This is one of the best things to do in Rome. You feel like you are in a little village, very charming, lots of interesting stores, it's the point in our trip where we said: Ahhhh, this is what we love, and it's an easy walk across the beautiful bridges over the Tiber to the Jewish Ghetto and into the center of Rome...it's lovable in Trastevere!
Don't miss it. Great neighborhood with excellent restaurants ...cross the Tiber at the Isla Tiberianna and you are there

Lively, Young and Charming!. Trastevere is a great evening out for young (and even older) couples who want to get awayfrom the more touristy area of Rome. Very close to the Vatican, and within an easy walk ofPiazza Navonna! The walk across the Tiber, alone, is worth the trip! There are so many outdoor eateries, pubs, bars.......and the ambiance with so many young and attractive locals walking and enjoying the music, activity and nightlife is a delightful change from the mandatory sites!

Great eats, sites & atmosphere. Trastevere - meaning 'across the River Tiber' - is an old, traditional, Bohemian part of room (a stone's throw from the Vatican) - a wonderful place of cobbled streets and cosy restaurants with character in every nook & cranny.

Good Food. Lots of places to eat at, but you have to go thru the side streets. Not much on Via Trastevere. You can catch the Tram from Area Sacra and get off over the first 3 or 4 stops. On the downside, there seems to be a lot of grafitti on the buildings, at least on Via Trastevere.

Best place to stay while in Rome. We rented a private apartment in Trastevere on a friends recommendation. What a great place- cobblestone streets, authentic family restaurants with decent (for Rome) prices. You feel like a local and get a flavor for life outside tourist attractions. We tend to avoid hotels and rent apartments whenever possible as we find it more comfortable for our family of 5... And the added benefit is we tend to see cities a bit more as a local than a tourist! So, even if you don't stay in Trastevere - take a few hours to wander it's streets, visit Piazza Santa Maria and the beautiful church there and have a nice dinner out of the crowdedness of Campo or Novana!

My favourite part of Rome. Trastevere (over the river) is where the , not so rich, ancient Romans lived and still do. The bars and restaurants are friendly and relatively inexpensive. If you want to feel like a local, head here, especially on an evening. Ooo by the way;Sunday afternoons are packed with local families,

Completely enchanting. Our family of 4, including 2 older teens, chose Trastevere as a base from which to enjoy a week-long tour of Rome. This was based upon having read a travel book years earlier titled Italian Days by Barbara Grizutti Harrison, in which the author describes in loving detail about the captivating neighborhoods of Trastevere. It did not disappoint! We felt we were living amongst real Romans, in a real working neighborhood, and the experience was completely authentic. Easy to get around on foot, and navigate into Vatican City & the heart of Rome by local bus. The architecture of the homes and apartment houses was very unique. We especially enjoyed taking photos of all the beautiful front doors, each and every one a work of art. Our teens enjoyed the Trastevere nightlife and they felt entirely safe going out on warm evenings to mingle with the young locals. We discovered several charming bistros and gelaterias within a block or two of our apartment, and the locals were extremely welcoming. Would highly recommend finding a vacation rental/apartment in Trastevere over a hotel in the inner city. Live like the Romans do!

Hiddent surprices in the narrow streets!. I book my hotel close to this area as i wanted to be close to the area where all the bars and restaurants are. Make sure u walk around there are so many bars!
Very quiet but excellent!!. This good area to experience the local, great for family restaurants and to mingle with friends...
for a night out. best place for restaurants and pubs, but also a tranquil place during the day to witness the leisure pace of Romans
Dinner in trastevere. One of the best areas to have dinner in rome. The food and scene is like no other. A great place to visit and a must see while in Rome.

Too much fun. I was staying nearby and had no idea where to drink at night time as central Rome was very touristy, then I went behind my hostel and found Trastevere. This area has lots of bars, lots studenty, all trendy. The drinks were cheap, the music was loud and there were lots of little places to sit outside in down small streets and alleyways. Some places open all night. Definitely a place for a heavier night out!

A pleasant area to stroll. A pleasant place to stroll, but only if you've got more than a few days to spend in Rome. We were there 8 days and appreciated the more peaceful, less hectic atmosphere but wouldn't recommend missing any of the major attractions in Rome for this.

Cobbles ,cobbles everywhere. Just walk and walk the narrow cobbled streets and savour old Rome with its bistros, restaurants, boutique shops and interesting churches. Fascinating by day and positively alive at night; yet safe.
Worth a stroll if you're in Rome for several days. A pleasant neighorhood in which to pass a few hours. It might be a bit over-rated, however with so many other things to see in Rome.

A real taste of Italy. We found Trastevere after it was recommended by my boyfriends Italian barber.Trastevere is an area of tiny winding streets that gave a taste of what I imagined to be the real Italy with washing hanging from balconies, cobbled streets and trattorias spilling out into the street.We explored both by day - enjoying lunch in the sun and then returned in the evening for a meal.Just wish we had discovered this area earlier in the trip.

Check out the specialty food shops around Piazza San Cosimato--they are the real Roman thing. Great for gifts.. Found numerous food gifts such as artisinal pasta, chocolates, sauces and truffles in jars, etc.

Great Neighborhood. So many restaurants!! Around every corner a great restaurant and lots of activity. There are so many young people just having a wonderful time. I am just not sure when these people sleep. Even close to midnight the outside restaurants are full and the streets are crowded. This is really a wonderful neighborhood to stay while exploring Rome!
atmosphere. take a taxi there and get som good food. A lot of nice places to eat and listen to music..
Unmet expectations. I guess my expectations may have been to high for this neighborhood. It was nothing special for me. Seems like a tourist trap in a city that has so much to offer.

Best place to hang out with friends. The truth is that there might not be any other neigborhood as good as Trastevere if you want to go out with your friends. There are many restaurants, and many more bars with young people, cheap prices in drinks, and loud music. There you can hang out with your friends, meet new people and have a lot of fun! You don't wanna miss it!!!

Excellent restaurants and sites. Trastevere is the new hype zone of Rome. As such, there is a plethora of restaurants in the area, offering different qualities and prices. Of course, they add atmosphere to the neighbourhood but at the same time seem to be transforming it into another tourist trap. Hope a right balance may be kept to save the nice spirit of such a lovely zone.

Quaint neighborhood. Love the quaint atmosphere in this neighborhood on the other side of the river. Lovely restaurants with outdoor seating provide great food and a great place to people watch, the prices aren't to bad either.
Great nightlife. This place is so cool at night. Alot going on. Great place to go and people watch.

Very charming!. It is a magic place, with narrow streets and nice bars and restaurants. The perfect place to walk by and discover little surprises in every corner. I found out a very nice restaurant there and enjoyed its seafood. Very good place to take pictures as well and or listen to street artists playing songs. Definitively, one of my favorite places in Rome.
Not another turist trap!. Its so real, small trattorias, good pizzerias, always a party somewhere near, full of life.

Not a must see. We found this area ok, but not with a lot to see. One distinct highlight though was Santa Maria in Trastevere church. It is stunningly beautiful! If you do go to the Trastevere area, you definitely need to see the inside of this church.
Picturesque. Lovely little old streets to wander around and explore. The main square is lovely with a beautiful fountain. Poorly served by taxis and buses, so you can end up walking a long way!
A Lovely break. My husband's favorite thing was sitting in the square of Santa Maria's and watching people. Mine was hitting the shops and street vendors and walking along the Tiber. Coop
make sure to walk around this wonderful area. try the food visit the great churches..dont miss it
The best part of Rome. We were very lucky to end up here on my first trip to Rome. I loved this area, just walking around the streets - it was lovely!
Really typical. Fantastic, a piece of real Rome, between movida and beautiful squares and streets

This is the real Rome.. Take time out for crossing the bridge into this important part of Rome. It's a little off the tourist-sights path, and well worth it. There are exceptional churches from antiquity here, as well as the best dining in Rome. And it's the only place where you will escape the hucksters and gypsies and see Rome as the present-day Romans do. If you're a bit ambitious, take the hike up the Janiculum Hill (where enemy armies would look down on Rome before going to battle, all through the early Republic era), and you will get the best views of the city, with the Vatican, Pantheon, and even Forum in clear view. It's also the freshest air and quietest location you'll find in your entire Roman experience.
Best part of Rome.. Great place to stroll before and after an evening meal.

Stay here!. We booked an apartment here through Airbnb. We wanted to stay in a proper Roman area rather than a part of the city populated by other tourists. It was fantastic! The food, hole in the wall wine bars, the people watching, nearby sites etc were just brilliant. Piazza Santa Maria comes alive at night with circus performers and night markets.
Great character. We wandered around the area early on a Sunday morning. Lots of character. We went into a couple of beautiful churches.

Must see part of Rome!. My first time in this part of Rome, and I fell in love the second we arrived.... every street, every alley, every trattoria is an amazing experience, especially at night! We stayed at Antico Borgo Hotel which was an amazing (and quiet) location, and only wish I had stayed a week in order to enjoy this area more. Don't miss it!
Super area - quiet with atmosphere. Dont miss the church of St Mary - amzing mosaics. Lots of great cafes and restaurants

Must see area of Rome. My favourite area of Rome! Full of bars, trattorie, restaurants, pubs... wander the streets by day eating gelato and come back at night to have drinks, aperitivo and more drinks!
Great part of town. Just wander the streets.. A pretty neighborhood with some historic churches and sites. Get a free audio guide from Rick Steve's website and enjoy it more.

Great at night.. This area is fantastic. The best place to stroll around at night. It's full of restaurants and people in winding streets. The food in this area was amazing and very reasonably priced. Could find great restaurants at all prices. Loved it!!!
Have to go there. Quaint. Cute streets, bohemian buildings and great walks. Eating outside as one will have to is eating with the smell of diesel fuel as cars and vans drive right by you.
Great for night time wandering. Really needs to be enjoyed at night. Lots of people milling about. Many cafes and shops. Fun to wander the small alleys.
Roman Berlin. If you enjoy the bohemian styles of Amsterdam, Berlin and Hamburg then visit Travestere. It has an amazing selection of bars and restaurants to suit all pockets and tastes
An extension of historic center. Nice, winding streets; feels similar to the historic district of Rome, across the water.

Beautiful. It may mean a little bit of walking, but you must visit Trastevere across the river. It's full of cobbled streets, washing hanging out of the windows and little old ladies sitting chatting on doorsteps. And the more you wander, the more tiny pizzerias you find, with little tables on the pavements - don't expect them to speak English, but they are all incredibly friendly and excellent value, especially at lunchtime. Theres some lovely little shops, hardly any of the 'tatt' type gift shops found elsewhere in the city - and if you feel energetic and walk up to Giancarlo, you'll be rewarded with fabulous views right over Rome, including St. Peter's. A lovely area to spend an afternoon rambling around, don't miss it!
Great fun in this area!. This is a great area for cafes, bars, and restaurants. Also on Sunday mornings there is a large market with just about anything you can imagine for sale.
Great Food..Great Bars. If you want to eat with the locals..then this is the place...
To dine like a Roman. The area where you can feel like a local. Excellent choices for restaurants in this area.
Authentic Rome. We walked here down the river for lunch after visiting the Vatican. It felt more like a little town and very peaceful. Some nice cafes and shops.
run over. by tourists. i will admit it "looks" very cosy, but we didn't see anyone local except for the shop keepers & waiters. disaapoi9nting, it looks like the hype has runied it.

Beautiful evening in a lovely neighborhood. We visited San Francesco d'Assisi en ripa to see a splendid Bernini and then walked along the streets to find a nice trattoria for dinner as twilight deepened and the lights came on. We ate at Pantone and bought pashmina scarves before taking the number 23 bus home.

A great place for an evening or two. Plenty of atmosphere with good restaurants and bars. We would recommend Trilussa Trattoria on Via del Politeama for a treat and Dar Poeta on Vicolo del Bologna for great pizza and atmosphere.
was ok...a bit touristy.... I felt this area was a bit over-hyped. It was VERY touristy and the restaurants that we went to were so-so.

Not sure what all the fuss is about.. We stayed in Trastevere. Everyone told us how lucky we were. I wish we shared the feeling. Buses or a tram are the best ways to get around. The highlight of the area is the Santa Maria church. It is really quite beautiful. Otherwise, a quaint, but uninteresting part of town given the rest of Rome.
Beautiful Neighborhood. Exactly what you would expect from Rome. Great to walk around and simply enjoy being there, to eat, have cafe...whatever you want. IL dolce far niente.

Hidden Gem on the other side of the river.... I found Trastevere thanks to the Rick Steve Europe Audio Tour (Free App for Smartphone) and I’m thankful. This place is truly a hidden gem. The restaurants are authentic Italian and the service was superb. Santa Maria y San Francesco a Ripa's churches are a most go. In the San Francesco you can find Bernini’s Beata Ludovica Albertoni (Blessed Ludovica Albertoni) don't miss it.
charming!. it's a time trip when you step trastevere!the buildings, the narrow streets, the stores, the people...it's amazing!!!!

lovely food. we travelled here a number of evenings - we had a fantastic meal for about 30 euro including four courses each and a bottle of wine - lovely restaruants dotted down the lanes - a very nice place to have a stroll and get a great feed!!

Saturday night is busy. This has a wonderful athmosphere. However if you want to eat in a good restaurant on a weekend night you must pre-book or else you may have to wait a long time for poor service

BEAUTIFUL THUS BUSY. Lots of tourists and lots of street artist or vendors and shops did not waste the atmosfere of this magic place, Trastevere is a must visit in the night of Rome. Go and have dinner (outside in a tiny courtyard on summer) at restaurant IL DUCA, you will love it (better to book in advance!)

Nothing special. After a day filled with 10 hrs of walking, I pushed myself and my daughter to get to this neighborhood after reading that this was where you can find cheap but good food, and an authentic local neighborhood. While it is true the coffee was mush cheaper here than in Rome proper, it was not worth the trip. The meal we had was average, nothing special, and the man at the counter of the coffe bar we stopped at was rude and made it very clear that he despised American tourists. So not worth the effort to get to this neighborhood!!

Loved, loved it!!. This is a place everyone should visit when in Rome. Charming small shops sending exquisite products, wonderful restaurants, a bohemian atmosphere. Don't forget to visit the Polvere di Tempo, a wonderful shop in Via del Moro 59 - where the owner enchants you with his clever conversation and kindness.

Beautiful. A fabulous little place full of history, you are able to sit outside a little cafe on the small streets & watch the world go by. Very friendly & relaxed.The cafes & restaurants were all very reasonably priced (some of the best prices we saw in Rome) In the evening a great place to have a few drinks it was buzzing with atmosphere
must go in Rome. I enjoyed this area very much, just over the River and the restaurants are cheaper and great atmosphere
Fun neighborhood!. Great area to just explore and get lost. Pretty crowded nowadays, but still lots of hidden gems on the little side streets. Great place to grab dinner and drinks.

A great place to stay. When you've had a day's sight-seeing, it's great to walk over the river and spend an evening strolling, people-watching in cafes and bars, and enjoying some excellent Roman food in one of a large number of trattorias
Very artistic. Little streets, great food, colour and rythm everywhere.

Don't miss this out on your visit to Rome!. This is one of the most charming parts of Rome and should not be missed. Really beautiful and peaceful - jump on the number 8 tram if you can't be bothered to walk.
Very nice walk. If you walk up to the garibaldi piazza you will get a stunning view of Rome but its not an easy walk
Fun. It is wroth to visit there. Small streets, very good restaurants and cheaper than the ancient side of the city.

Not to be missed........... Trastevere is often missed but is a lovely place to get lost and wander through its streets and explore the unique stores or have a coffee or negroni and watch the theatre of daily life in Rome pass by. This is the perfect place for a pizza and if you are in for something different, pizza with pear and gorgonzola cheese is great for a light lunch or afternoon snack. It is also a good place for fashionable leather bags unique jewellery pieces which will make for memorable gifts.

Nice bars, multi-cultural. Nice place to go in the evenings for drinks and dinner. We particularly enjoyed the cocktails at Baccanale and there is a gorgeous silver jewellery ship in Trastever called Giokeb

pictureque place. a great place to visit and walk around...and interesting neighbourhood.we just drunk a coffee,but i imagine that it is a nice place to eat also.it has great atmosphear...something between dark and culture
The older side of Rome. Takes a bit of effort to get there but it is a maze of winding and ancient streets and wonderful restaurants, cafes, churches etc. Not to be missed! Photo ops everywhere!

great restaurants!. This is a great area to spend your evenings and nights. It has great affordable restaurants and bars and feels a bit like a city within a city. We loved spending our evenings here.

Great place to walk around. Our last day in Rome and the weather was nice. We ended up walking along the city towards Trastevere. It was totally not touristy and had cute little cafe's and streets. We were kind of tired so we just sat in a cafe and had a cup of coffee more to rest our feet. Just a great neighborhood to walk around - would totally recommend coming here and having dinner in the area!
Eat with the people of Rome!. Fabulous area, easy to get to with taxi service.

If you live there you can only hate this place. When you move, you can only regret your choice and keep on coming back there every night (be careful of most restaurant!).
I don't miss drunk tourists in every corner, cars parked in private courtyards or summertime mess until 5 am, only one of the most lively place in Rome.
Adorable neighborhood. Cute neighborhood with an amazing old church. Great area to ramble, eat gelato, stop by a wine or craft beer bar, etc.

We'll be back. Trastevere is amazing if you visit Rome you must visit. It has everything. The bus service to the centre is first class every 10-15 minutes. Great restaurants and reasonable shops and also designer shops. The local cafes and bars make you feel welcome. The locals are so helpful and nothing seems to be too much trouble.
Cacio e pepe. Feel very easy, and just stroll around, or search for the many treasures of old Rome.

The best approach to Vatican. If you hesitate throwing yourself at the Vatican immediately, take your time, read Dan Browns "From Angels and Demons" and approach the Vatican slowly veering away from the strange signs you might suddenly see

Tyremarxx. Just take a deep breath, let it go, and wander through the alleys and back streets. Stop for lunch where you hear only Italian spoken. Do not go into a place where you are greeted as " 'allo, my frien' "

Nice neighborhood accross Tiber. Very nice section of the city to stroll about. Nice restaurants, wonderful piazzas, beautiful churches, and access to Giancolo Hill with it's very nice view of the city.

A place to enjoy one night in Rome. Dont go before 10 PM, because the fgun begins after that. Begin by visiting Santa Maria Basilica, its a piece of art that you will enjoy. After that you can tour aroun the place where you will find different styles of restorants, pubs and junk food shops. You can enjoy your time there for later hours than in Rome, and surely you will find the place that suits you.
unexpected. I enjoyed the narrow and colorful streets of Trastevere. It is a must to visit while in Rome and rarely any guide mentions it.

Charming. This is a cute little area on the other side of the Tiber River. It is far from the main tourist attractions so you will get value for your money with the cuisine, its more authentic and worth the trip. Also visit the Jewish ghetto for great kosher food. The shopping is trast is a lot cheaper also if you are after for some leather goods and market stalls

Sunset in Trastevere. When we went to Vatican, we walk back to Trastevere and witness sunset over Ponte Sant'Angelo (The Bridge of Hadrian) and had photos taken. They were the best photos with bridge and the sunset on the background. We walk through Tiber river to Trastevere and it was so peaceful and quiet, I recommend a little day trip to Vatikan and around.

An Awesome Experience!!!. The moment you enter the area you feel the difference. It looks completely different from any tourist area in Rome. It's full of local people on ice cream shops, cafes, restaurants. I saw a procession from a church which really felt that I was in Latin America and not in Europe. I saw a concert, and street drama. I will definitely visit Trastevere again.

blue collar area is fun to explore!. Trastevere means "at the other side of the Arno ." It's a working class neighborhood that is a good antidote to Via Condotti! It's not touristy, even though there are restaurants that cater to tourists. We visited Palazzo Corsini here, where we enjoyed the wonderful art it contains. There are little pizza by the slice and gelato places around it so that you can keep your strength up for all the walking that's involved.Don't miss Santa Maria di Trastevere, the first church to be dedicated solely to the Madonna. Like all churches in Rome, it's incredibly beautiful.Don't miss

Rome and not Rome. Trastavere is separated from the rest of Rome by the Tiber and as is the case in many other such separations, one gets the feeling that the separation is cultural as well as physical. The restaurants appear to have a very high standard of food but some of them appear to be just traps for the turisti.Both Chiese S. Crisogono and S Maria are worthy of visits but the high point of my last visit was Museo di Roma in Trastavere with two exceptionally good exhibitions, one of photographs and one of acquarelle but unfortunately these are not permanent exhibitions. However, if you are visiting soon, do go and if you are visiting later, look out for the listings; the standard was exceptionally high

Lovely neighbourhood to explore. We enjoyed wandering around this lovely neighbourhood which seems to be lived in by real people - lots of people out on Sunday morning walking dogs, going to Mass, going for coffees. Lots of little streets to expore.

Pretty good walk. We used Rick Steeves' podcast to walk us through it. Dissapointed that we did not learn sooner that the Santa Cecilia 's tomb, in the church of the same name, is opened for viewing only for a short time in the morning. Quite different from our other walks around Rome. The restaurants mostly seemed like tourist traps and/or were full. The happy hour that we ended up having was the worst one of the entire trip. I say, sight-see (and do the Jewish Ghetto before or after, too) and then go elsewhere to eat.

My favourite spot in Rome. Cute, special, crowded and lovely: Trastevere! It is definitely the area of Rome I like the most. Full of bars, pubs and amazing Pizzeria, each time I'm in the city, I have a tour in Trastevere! I recommend you a very simple and TASTY pizzeria: cave canem! In Piazza San Callisto. If you are looking for mohito, go to Freni e Frizioni, close to Piazza Trilussa: best mohito ever!

Quintessential Rome. Having travelled to Rome probably 20+ times in my life, I finally decided last year to make the move here... I'd visited Trastevere before but living here now it's even better! While some of the cities most beautiful sites are here (including Gianicolo Hill where you'll get a breathtaking view of the city, Santa Maria in Trastevere basilica) what you really need to do if you're travelling to the area is just throw away the map & get lost in the amazing little & winding cobblestone streets.. One of the oldest quarters of Rome, Trastevere is picturesque with its terracotta wash buildings & washing hanging out of apartment windows - It's like a little village in a big city! I've been documenting my life & times in the area at: www.trasteverecalling2011.wordpress.com Take my advice - a visit to Rome is incomplete without a stop in Trastevere!!

Simply Charming. Trastevere is a great place to get away from the crowded city streets. With a plethora of restaurants, specialty shops, bars and sidewalk vendors, it is truly a quaint area of the city which offers something for everyone. We did a lot of window shopping and visited a temporary outdoor market with vendors from places as far away as Sicily. We stopped by a small bar for drinks and were able to relax on the outdoor patio with the best Mojito ever made. It was the perfect change of pace from the cars and the crowds in the city center. It was truly a highlight of out trip
Best place to eat in Rome. Much better in Summer months. Loads of restaurants, bars and shops. Great value. A great atmosphere. Young and old alike. Like a different world

The best Italian food in the world here. My fiancé and I went to Rome for a summer vacation. It was my first time to Rome, and we stayed at a hotel which was walking distance from Trevi fountain and the Spanish steps. My fiancé has been to Rome several times. However, he had never gone to Trastevere in the past. This town was recommended by several people while in Rome, which is why we decided to pay it a visit. It was a cool, trendy and fun area in Rome. We went at night and there was a lot going on, it reminded me of a combination of the meat-packing district in New York city with a taste of old San Juan Puerto Rico. I loved the energy in this town and had a great time. I also went to the best Italian restaurant I have ever been to in my life called Rivadestra, which was amazing. It was very hard to find yet worth it when we found it. If you are in Trastevere, this restaurant is a must. You will thank me if you go there.

I wouldnt stay any where else.. This is the Roman's little bit of paradise. Hardly any tourist and none of the tourist menus here either. There are some great restaurants, bars and cocktail bars here. some nights there is also a market selling gifts and jewerly.
Very cool area. Very cool area of restaurants, bars and nice boutiques. On the other side of the Tiber.
Best Roman Eateries. You want to eat like and with Romans? Then this is the place for YOU.Yes, it is a little off the beaten path, but THIS is a true taste of what Roman food is REALLY like.
Pure Magic. I liked everything. The restaurants, pastry shops, churches, museums, shopping, cafes, art, musicand the trendy atmosphere of old Rome.

Great place off the beaten path. Walking around Trastevere was tremendous fun. Visiting the Church of Santa Maria in Trastevere allows you to walk through little, quaint streets and gives you a good sense of what the locals are living in. It's relatively quiet compared to the center areas of Rome and is worth the visit of you have time on your hands when in Rome.

Best part of Rome. Trastevere is what I had hoped the rest of Rome would be - charming and quaint. Honestly, although the history is amazing, I found Rome really disappointing. The people were unfriendly and did not seem very happy. It was one large tourist trap. The only plus was the amazing pizza and pasta.Trastevere was the exception. It is charming, full of cute shops and restaurants and an active nightlife. If I ever return to Rome, I plan to find a hotel in Trastevere and explore this area more.

Nice area to get away from the crowds. Nice area to explore - feels still like the real Rome. If you go here also visit Villa Farnesina (just a small walk from main square) and well worth the entrance fee to see this beautiful little palace

Quaint working class area. We enjoyed our walk around this area. The pedestrian friendly streets, quaint shops, churches were great. Most impressive was that this is an area where real people live. Laundry hangs between the buildings. Bus H gets you here from the Terminii.

Definitely Visit this Area. The Trastevere was an excellent district to visit to get a non-touristy idea of Rome. The architecture and city viewpoints are excellent and we were pleasantly surprised to discover the mausoleum for Garibaldi there.

wishing I spent more time here. On my next visit to Rome I plan on getting lost in Trastevere for 2 days just to be able to absorb it"s rich heritage and the lively nightlife.4 hrs here will not even scratch the surface of what lies in this beautiful city
wonderful area. Go see the two famous churches in trastevere. St. Maria in Trastevere has the most amazing mosaics and incredible atmosphere. St. Cecila also very interesting

Charming place. This charming place is a must see if your in Rome it will get you back in time and it is also a heaven for food lovers withall those restaurants in my opinion the best restaurants in Rome are here.
Rome's Greenwich Village. Great restaurants. Cute boutiques. Beware of pickpockets on motor scooters.

Nice small town away from the crowds. Trastever is a very nice distraction from the other sites. It is a small old (of course) town within the city that is nice to visit for a coffee, lunch, or dinner. It is a nice town to stroll around in and visit the local sights. I stayed in a B&B there which was nice.

Lovely old neighborhood. Charming neighborhood, old buildings, narrow streets, plenty of shops. Walked along the river beside the beautiful large trees. Also entered the Santa Maria Basilica - must see, especially if you're in the neighborhood.

great restaurant vibe. decided to catch a bus to Trastavere from the main station and paid 1E. easy drop off and great streets to stroll in. many restaurants to choose from and we chose one that looked a bit more modern and contemporary. FAbulous experience and dining pleasure

Unique neighborhood; great eateries; young crowd. This is a great area to spend an evening at...strolling through the cobbled streets and admiring the character so unique to this place.It's pretty crowded, but enjoyably so...the place is so vibrant! You have tons of restaurants and the price difference could be huge between neighboring restaurants, so, check out several menus before deciding on one! We had the tastiest Margherita pizza in our entire stay in Italy at a sit-down restaurant in this area and it cost just 2 Euros for a full pizza...A must-visit!

Our favorite part of Rome!. The quiet byways and sights of this increasingly popular area make it even more pleasant than Rome's main historic district, giving it a tranquil, small-city feel unlike other parts of Rome.Highly recommended!

Picturesque little streets, cosy atmosphere!. Our walk in Trastevere was relaxing and romantic. We had a nice coffee in the piazza in front of Santa Maria in Trastevere watching some street performers making big soap bubbles which was really fun for kinds and not only! We had dinner at a local restaurant but the must-do is to have a splendid tiramisu at a local small cafeteria-bar! All in all, Trastevere is a nice, medieval escape from the too touristic historical centre!
Loved the flea market. Although it was HUGE and PACKED.. it's open only on Sundays. We walked through town and felt the authenticity of the real life of the Italians

Unexpectedly vibrant and quirky neighborhood. We rented an apartment in Trastevere, which is right across the Tiber River from ancient Rome, within easy walking distance across the Ponte Sisto bridge. There are bus stops all over the neighborhood as well, and the Vatican and other points of interest are all easily accessible. Trastevere itself is quite old, and we loved the quaint buildings and narrow brick streets. It seemed as though there were restaurants and bistros every few steps, and every place we ate or drank had its own charm. The area has a very active nightlife as well, and we encountered such a variety of people as we walked about. When we were researching places to stay, there were a number of places in Trastevere that were incredibly reasonable. We would seek lodging there again in a heartbeat! If you are looking for a drink, we recommend a Birra Moretti or Peroni, as well as any of the fabulous blanco or roso house wines served at each establishment!

traditional roman neighborhood that can't be missed. As both Rome’s most ancient and hippest neighbourhood, Trastevere strikes a charming balance between the old and the new. Translating directly to “across the Tiber,” Travestere is located south of the Vatican on the West side of the river tucked away in its own little oasis, yet walkable from the city center. Long-time locals consider themselves the last remaining true Romans, and as a result, the quarter remains what could be considered Rome’s most aesthetically authentic area. Without a sleek refurbished facade in sight, the architecturally traditional neighbourhood with original narrow cobblestone streets and slender terracotta buildings is an unexpected yet pleasant contrast to the cool, vibrant culture, lively nightlife and trendy one-of-a-kind shops. Piazza Santa Maria has always been, and still remains to be the heart of Trastevere. Speculated to have been the first Christian place of worship in Rome, founded by Callixtus I in the 3rd century, Santa Maria brought people together through religion. Today, the Piazza is bustling with street performers, tourists, and local eateries during the day, and at night Santa Maria transforms into a student hotspot with stylish bar-goers, inexpensive drinks, and wonderful music. A must-see for all tourists! Turn onto any street in the area and you will see a number of traditional Roman restaurants with beautiful patios packed with both locals and tourists alike. Both trend-setters and bargain-hunters might enjoy Rome’s biggest flea market at Porta Portese on Sundays, while Piazza San Cosimato is home to a small daily market where many locals enjoy shopping fresh farmed goods.
Great Place don't miss oot.. If you like some nightlife and good eating places just dont miss out.

The area is somewhat Bohemian, small hotels and restaurants. The small restaurants and shops make the Trastever area unique in Rome. It has an ambience that fits with artists and students. Key things to see are the Weekend Flea Market (beware of pick-pockets! They work in teams now) , and vist the catacombs below St, Cecilia's Bascilica. The excavations are extensive, Use a guide for your tour of the Bascilica catacombs.

Very nice place and surroundings. The atmosphere is very nice : narrow streets, cozy places and a lot of shops. Most of them are not real tourist trap but... tend to be.Santa Maria in Trastevere is beautiful and very interesting.I'd say... Trastevere is a very nice for couples and young people having fun at night.I'd say... Trastevere is a very nice for couples and young people having fun at night.

Quaint, Quirky, and a favorite. Trastevere seems like the art district - We were there (but just passing through) twice, but it's got winding streets, art supply stores, people walking around with blank canvases ...

Hidden Gem!. Off the beaten path and definitely worth an afternoon walk or an evening dinner. Our hotel was in the area and was significantly cheaper than others. Everywhere we ate was a pleasant surprise, the area was clean and the people were nice. The area isn't as crowded with tourists so you get a good feel of the city and how the locals live. Relaxing, enjoyable and will return soon!

Trastevere: An authentic Roman neighborhood. My husband and I recently spent a week in Rome, staying in the Trastevere neighborhood, and I would recommend it for anyone looking fir a more authentic, Riman neighborhood experience. Although across the Tibor from most "must-see" Roman tourist sites, it's still an easy walk to most. The Jewish ghetto and the Colosseum area are particularly close. Trastevere itself offers a fine, cobblestoned neighborhood of small shops, beautiful churches, and restaurants.

Relaxing. If you want to take a break from the famous sights of Rome and its crowded centre, a walk in Trastevere will definitely relax you. It feel more like an Italian town than like a part of the capital and you will find a lot of good restaurants and cozy cafés to help you calm down.

Fountain is worth the climb. Went here for the much-publicised market on Sunday morning. Was not especially impressed with that, so started climbing uphill.Found the church of St Cecilia, patron saint of music, which was gorgeous.Then did some serious uphill work and eventually reached the Fontana dell'Aqua Paola. This huge marble backed fountain has a deep blue pool of cool water at its base. You can join the locals and dip your toes or fingers in the water to cool down from the climb, while looking out at a stunning view back over the city. It was very quiet, and that moment was my favourite of the whole trip to Rome.

Typical Italian. The little red and white tabled clothed restaurants make this suburb like exactly how Italy is imagine... cobbled roads and smalled than usual cars make this the ideal tourist place for me

Top 5 places to visit. This part of Rome was one of my favs.I could have stayed here all day.More locals here.Sit at one of the many piazzas and watch the world go by.Had a lovely meal in one of the many restaurants. The churches in this area and beautiful andcwill take your breathe away.
Trastevere. Worth a walk over for a little local flavor. One of the oldest churches is over there and worth looking at.

Authentic, unexplored, reminds you of older times. One of the most authentic and original neighborhoods of Rome! We got there walking along Tevere and crossed Sisto Bridge, not knowing what to expect, as we had gathered mixed and controversial opinions. I now wonder what the negative ones were really about... The place is like a fairytale! Small, narrow streets, little but warm coffee shops and restaurants, churches and old buildings to discover, slower rythms and of course much less crowded. It takes you back some years or transfers you to another smaller town and I really enjoyed this atmosphere. So close to the touristic historic center, but so far away speaking from an atmospherical point of view! I really recommend it, especially at night, for a drink! Take the tram (Line 8) which crosses Garibaldi Bridge and connects Trastevere with Largo Argentina (one of the most central Piazzas of Rome, close to Piazza Venezia).

most enjoyable and authentic exploring in Italy. we were so tired of the "i <3 roma" souvenir shops and "touristy to-dos" in Rome by the end of our trip. we were really excited to stumble across the bridge and get to experience what felt like a more "authentic Italian" afternoon in Trastevere. We visited midday and enjoyed sampling the pastries from one of the local bakeries, some cappuccino, and in general just enjoyed exploring the neighborhood. There were some great small shops and lots of locals going about their typical day.

Don't leave Rome with dining at La Scala in Trastevere. La Scala is located in the neighborhood of Trastevere. Trastevere is a wonderful neighborhood filled with history. La Scala is a local restaurant with very good l food and wine. And the restaurant features outdoor dining. Although we could not speak Italian and the staff could not speak English we got along famously. I highly recommend this restaurant and to especially stroll through the streets of this great neighborhood. Perfecto!

Nightlife!. The place to be in Rome for nightlife, dinner, drinks, party, always full of life, you can find lots of restaurants, bars, pubs, caffe, souvenir shops, artesans, just about everything. It is also the place where Romans go fo a little nightlife.In our visit, dinner at a nice restaurant here in trastevere was the cheapest dinner in all our Europe tour, and the dinne where we had a 3 lt beer... believe it or not... our check was about 30 euro includind beer, entree, and dinner for 2!Nightlife starts about 11:00 pm, restaurants start to get crowded about 11:30 but you can visit at any hour.

Nice to see, not so nice people to meet. First of all, great churches to see like St.Maria in Trastevere, St.Maria di Scala etc. Great Botanical garden, like big park, it was so good to be there 'cos temperatures were high for this time of year. Near by is Villa Farnesina with amazing fresco paintings by Raffaello.Many small streets with little restaurants and art galleries in which you can by some original pieces of jewelry, clothes and Murano glass items. Whole area is little bit quieter than rest of the Rome. Prices are same like in the rest of town, don't expect anything to be cheaper than in centre.Only minus are people, actually some of them.When you cross the Garibaldi bridge with street car no.8, there is square with Casa di Dante and big brown like tower. Behind is small street and on the corner is sort of bakery and pastry shop, Italians call it "farina", I believe. Well, on my first visit to this bakery, stuff was a little unpleasant and other time I went there, some other customers Italians, also. "The big thing" for their rude behavior was : I saw 3 ladies working there and 3 scales and 3 different types of food. I stand in front of one with pastry and Italian guy with dark glasses was talking all the time since my entry, but after a while, I noticed that he was probably talking to me but wasn't sure because I could not see his eyes and where he was looking. Of course , he was talking on Italian and because of my hair and eyes color , it was so obvious that I'm stranger and one simple gesture with hand will show me that no matter what kind of food I want and no matter 3 "ladies" working in 4 m long counter, we all have to be in one line and wait for one of them to come to us and serve! Sorry, where I come from it's just different and when we see tourist in situation like this, we are not expecting to behave like us, domestic folks, in every and each situation in town where he/she will spend just few days.So, great part of Rome to see and some not so great Italians to avoid in Trastevere!

Trastevere: the good and the bad. Trastevere is a beautiful area of Rome. It has lovely cobbled streets and cute little restaurants everywhere. I wanted to write this review to warn other unsuspecting travellers like myself. My best experience was at Restaurant Vascellari on Via dei Vascellari. The service and waiters there were unbelievably nice and friendly and the food was fantastic for the price. I went there on more than one night. THE WORST PLACE EVER was the corner "Snack Bar Gelateria" 10 Piazza in Piscinula right beside Cornucopia Restaurant. The Italian woman yelled at us because we took a second too long to order our coffees and then practically chased us out. That was the worst experience EVER in Italy. I hate that place. Don't ever go there unless you want to get yelled at!

What's the big deal?. We stayed in a nice hotel in the Trastevere neighborhood, but overall the area is a dump. The streets are littered with garbage, and the buildings are NOT quaint. They're unattractive (to understate what I'm really thinking but don't want to put in writing). Most disturbing are the transient young people who sleep on the steps of the piazza. There's a quaintness here somewhere, but I would not stay in this neighborhood again. Found an excellent pizzeria - Dar Poetica - which, along with the hotel brings the rating up to a "3" - but again the building was dilapidated. Oh, sorry, centuries old and charmingly quaint.

Nightime along the river is fun!. We walked across Ponte Garibaldi, and then down the steps to the riverwalk in Trastevere. Lots of vendors, bars and restaurants. It was fun just to take in the nightlife and people watch. Some of the bars set up tables or cushions along a ledge that you have to climb up to. One of them had set up small beds, for dining, but cute to look at. A nice stroll in the evening.
Sunday afternoons are dead quiet with nothing open. Arrived on a Sunday afternoon and nothing was open. All the stores & cafes were closed. Left soon after arrival.

Come visit in the evening and have a pizza dinner here!. Locals say Trastevere has the best pizza.While we had some of the best, I'm not sure if it was "the best". But do try Dar Poeta for their pizza. Show up early or wait to get a table.We used the Rick Steves free audio guide to explore this area. It was a nice free guide downloaded to his iPhone app. There is so much to see here, and it hit the highlights. We started it about 5PM and did the walk. It was great!A very fun neighborhood - lots of noise and youth and energy - across the river.

Don't Miss This part of Rome. I find myself drawn to Trastevere each time I return to Rome. The ambience is worth the effort to get there--restaurant after restaurant serving authentic Roman cuisine (for the most part), the bustling nightlife, and people-watching are activities that I enjoy here. Santa Maria in Trastevere is worth a visit, too. The medieval church with its beautiful mosaics and a few interesting chapels is a reminder of the culture that dates back hundreds of years in this long-inhabited part of Rome. Wandering the narrow streets without worrying where I'll end up always brings new discoveries. Of course, there are always new restaurants to try!

Don't miss it while in Rome - nice and quiet area. Trastevere is one of my favorite places in Rome. Mainly because you can escape the hectic downtown, have a nice walk, maybe even enter the beautiful botanic garden and just relax. Also you can climb the hill and have a nice walk with great views all over the city. Do not miss it while in Rome!

a nice night walk for dinner & drink. Don't miss a night walk in trastevere.Is the main place in Rome that offers night life in small bars . Prepare a walk for food and dinner .If you stay in the center of rome take a taxi to go and return (for safe resons )

Kind of other world feel. As others have said it does not feel like you are in a crazy capital city any longer; it is very neighbourhoody, which may be a word I have just invented (patent pending). The area has a run down look to it, with laundry draped across alleyways, graffiti and such but it real feels like the proper Italy of everyday people fortunate to live close to one of the worlds great cities. Easy to reach via the tram from the Argentina stop. Trastevere just feltreal to me and it was stunning because it was not trying too hard. Not too sure how it is at night. If I was to say it based on looks alone I would say it was iffy, but that would be being presumptuous so no idea... Enjoy, spend a couple of hours out that way getting lost in the alleyways and grabbing a coffee maybe.

True neighborhood vibe. To be completely honest, at first glance, Trastevere looked like the seedy Brooklyn neighborhood I'm originally from. I could have sworn I time warped back to Knickerbocker or Myrtle Ave circa the late 1970s and early 1980s. We came here to pay a visit to my niece's counsin who works at John Cabot University. As we got closer to the university, the area became prettier and prettier until finally my mom and I realized that it would be great to live here! After we met up at the university, we went to lunch at Ristorante Mareusa. Best - meal - ever! If you're not too stuffed or drunk, you must check out Chiesa di San Pietro in Montorio for a great panorama of the city. Then head to Fontana del Gianicolo just a minute walk away. There is bargain shopping galore on Viale di Trastevere as well. Basically, this area is littered, there's graffti everywhere and some parts are just shady. But, take a turn down a narrow street off the busy main roads and treat yourself to a much quieter part of Rome.

Great part of the City to see. Across the River from Old Rome is a bustling neighborhood, replete with small shops, history, narrow streets and even laundry strung across the small streets, even in Winter. Quite picturesque and a short walk “Back” in time away from the bustle of central Rome traffic and hubbub. More like a small village that a part of Rome for sure. A great Church and Piazza adorn the neighborhood and some top non-pretentious restaurants with great food too.

A very romantic place in Rome. If you look for a really romantic place in Rome you should visit the picturesque district of Trastevere. Trastevere is the place where you can still observe the daily life of the inhabitants of Rome. In the past it was mainly inhospitable place inhabited by foreigners who threw garbage and poured dirt straight into the narrow cobbled streets. Also there were slaughterhouses and tanneries. However, nowadays it is well preserved and the oldest district of Rome, with its lovely, overgrown with ivy and jasmine, houses and restaurants. We could see few tourists there and locals who went for a walk and spend a nice lazy Saturday afternoon. It is this time of a day when, in our opinion, is the best time to visit the area (although the guidebooks recommend the evening). We were very pleased with the play of lights at this time on a beautiful sunny day. We paid our attention to two particular churches. Church of the twelfth century with a beautiful golden mosaic. This is the oldest church dedicated to St. Maria and it is located in the heart of Trastevere at Piazza di Santa Maria in Trastevere. And the second one was the Latin American church, where we could see the black dolls of Jesus and the Blessed Virgin Mary in various forms which represent many countries in Latin America.

Noisy, but.... If you are looking for a quiet zone in a city as large as Rome you are probably being unrealistic, and Trastevere's charm is based, in large measure, on the fact that it still is home to many Roman citizens, who live there amongst the tourists. Our visit in October/early November came at a time when the tourist hordes were already diminishing but it could still be quite loud well into the early hours of the morning, especially on weekends. Be careful to pick an apartment or hotel room that is not located on one of the busier streets (and is preferably several stories off the ground level) if you prefer a quieter venue. That said we lived in the area for nearly 4 weeks and thoroughly enjoyed it...you can find some very good and not particularly expensive osterias, there is a buzz of street life to the neighbourhood that is ever-invigorating, and, if you pay careful attention you begin to recognize the locals, their habits and their peculiarities, which gives you a nice feel for the geographic personality of this area. Easy walking distance to the Vatican State and to the historic core of ancient Rome. We'd stay there again.

Dar Sor Olimpio al Drago restaurant- Definitely one of the best. During our visit to Rome we were taken by our local friends to dinner at the Dar Sor Olimpio located in a small piazza in the Trastevere area near the Tiber. I so enjoyed the food there that I am inspired to write a brief revew so that other visitors to Rome who appreciate the pleasures of a delicous cuisine wlll also discover this place of gastronomical delights. I for one, hope for a repeat experience in the not too distant future.We arrived through small cobble-stone paved streets at the restaurant, which seats around 40. Situated among charming ancient buildings the unpretentious decor had a warm and authentic feel. The staff were busy but gracious and at our request recommended for us a series of dishes, which they served singly in the fashion of Chinese banquets. I can say without hesitation that the chef has excellent taste buds and an exceptional talent with food. I would like to do a rave about all the dishes, but suffice to say that the first course of baby squids fried in the lightest and crispiest of batter was the best and most fragrant I have ever had, and I am not even ashamed to admit I took the largest portion of this in our table of four. But I should also mention the other equally mouth-watering dishes: tender octopus salad with small cubes of potatoes and cherry tomatoes coated in a rucola (in Australia we call it rocket) sauce; fresh prawns served on a bed of rucola with three sauces; scampi cooked just right and served with a cream risotto sprinkled with tartufi (truffles). We had to call a halt after our fourth cleaned-out dish when we had all gone passed elegant sufficiency.But we could not leave such a satisfying meal without indulging in some dessert. The Creme Brulet was the best - with a genuine eggy taste under a thin crust of caramel, while the Tiramisu was so good that my husband, who normally does not like creamy sweets after a meal, asked for his own portion after sampling a teaspoonful from his neighbour.After such alimentary delights we sent our compliments heartily to the chef, Mr Robert Giulietti, who honored us by coming out to our table. His appearance did not disappoint either, for he looked quite the authentic Italian chef. What an end to a delightful evening of absolutely delicious dining to discover that Mr Giulietti was actually born in Australia of Italian heritage! Italy's gain is our loss, but we will be back!

make sure you eat at Dar Sor Olimpio al Drago. I only had a week in Rome, but being a chef, food was my main attraction for my time there. I stumbled upon Dar Sor Olimpio al Drago whilst wandering around the trastevere district over the river and was immediately impressed by the menus on offer; a meat, a fish and a vegetarian menu with 5 starters, 5 mains and 1 dessert on each, at €18 for a 3 course sit down meal with a glass of wine, some sparkling water and fresh crusty bread it had the value for money box ticked. The location and ambiance were perfect and soon i was sat down, wine in hand, ready to eat.i had some home made pasta with pecorino and cracked black pepper to start with, a dish kept simple so as not to overpower the taste of the fresh pasta and knew immediately i was in safe hands. the braised oxtail came next, braised to minute perfection ( "eat it with your hands!" the chef shouted out to me from the kitchen, to my delight) finishing with the very best tiramisu i have ever tasted. a few glasses of red wine later i knew i had to get out walking around rome so as to work up an appetite for the fish menu i was going to have in the evening.That evening i made my way back to the beautiful little Piazza del Drago, all light up and bustling with locals ( a good sign when looking for a decent meal) and got a table at Dar Sor Olimpio again, Angela greeting me with a big smile making me feel very much like a regular on my second visit."Pesce?" she asked" si signora, grazie."From the fish menu i started with grilled scampi risotto, the scampi so fresh they were sweet, followed by swordfish steak sicilian style with olives capers and cherry tomatoes and then instead of the lemon sorbet on the menu the chef gave me another go at his delicious tiramisu, reading my mind, even though his restaurant was packed to capacity and he was by himself in the kitchen. Later Angela came out with a glass of limoncello on the house, suggesting i would need the digestive to help my poor stomach otherwise i might explode.If you are in Rome walk away from the touristy areas where the food is sub par and cross the river and eat with the locals at the Dar Sor Olimpio al Drago, I did. Twice.

Good place for a walk. The Trastevere area is worth a visit as it offers good walking around the River Tiber. There are a number of restaurants offering food of variable quality. Be careful of your choice - we looked for a restaurant that was being used by locals and we weren't disappointed - some of the others that were targeting tourists did not look so good in terms of the quality of food and the staff attitude was poor. It is worth spending a little time chosing the restaurant for you.

Good food poor service. We went on a.... Good food poor service. We went on a saturday night, sept 2010, it was very crowded and they neglected us for at least 20 mins. The staff was panicking although they were serving only 25 customers. Nonetheless the ravioli can be rated 6/10. The pepper pork was worth an 8/10. the cream brule was excellent.

Atmospheric, photogenic and not covered in Graffiti !. Been to Rome a couple of times and both times the couple of hours we spent in this neighbourhood were our favourite, Feels like an authentic experience, the setting across the river with the narrower streets makesstark contrast to the brasher graffiti covered areas. Loveley area for a meal and a relax.

Restauarant Trastevere - dar sor Olimpio al Drago. dar sor Olimpio al Drago has got to be one of the best restaurants in Trastevere. It is located in Piazza del Drago just off Via della Lungaretta. It is a far cry from the pizza and "Tourist Menu' restaurants. It might be a bit more pricey but worth every penny. We ate there twice (April 2010 - wish we had found it earlier) and my son and his wife who also subsequently holidayed in Rome (May 2010) also had a meal there and sung its praises. The chef, Robert, was born in Australia but returned to Italy with his parents when he was about 6 years old. I hope they are still in business when we return to Rome in 12 to 24 months time. As you can gather just cannot recommend this place highly enough.

Not deserving of the hype - Trastavere at night. After touring around Rome for three days and encountering wonderful food and service, I have to say that Trastevere was really a letdown. Granted it was Saturday night, but it was overly crowded, streets filled wth drunken (mostly) tourists chugging wine out of bottles like alchohol the Prohibition was coming back. And the food at a "cozy" trattoria was bland, over-priced and took two hours to be served (one hour for each course). My advice - want to enjoy the real Rome? Stay away from here. There are some wonderful places on Via del Governo Vecchio (look for Wine Bar Coco and Mimi - great food, great service) and generally, anywhere Romans go is a safe bet. And boy, do they go out!

Trastevere - Don't Miss it!. Trastevere has two beautiful faces. One is during the day, when it is a pleasure to have coffees and ice creams while enjoying the peace of a sunny afternoon. But the other is at night. Once the sun sets the coffees become cocktails and the peace is replaced by an international crowd that blends in with the romans. The area has three major Piazza's that are connected to each other with infinite streets and narrow "Vicoli". Piazza San Cosimato is the largest and most active by day, with its great market and several shops. Piazza Santa Maria is the most celebrated for its beauty and historical importance. And Piazza Trilussa is the meeting point for the night. All you have to do is walk around (driving in Trastevere requires the skills of a ninja) and find the restaurant, bar or pub you like best. One night won't be enough, you will want to go back and explore more, there's live music and plenty of true roman experiences to be made...have fun! Ciao!

Don't miss Trastevere. The first time I went to Rome, we skipped Trastevere. Don't do that. I discovered on my many trips since that it's a charming medieval neighborhood. It has great restaurants and wine bars. The Church of Santa Maria in Trastevere has actually become my favorite in the city! And there are usually evening prayer services at night so it stays open later than most churches. When I am visiting the area to have a good dinner, it's nice to pop in there before hand and admire the beautiful medieval mosaics.

Great place to stay. We sayed in Trastevere region of Rome and can recommend it.Accomodation in this area is less expensive than in the centre of Rome so you can get more for your money.Travelling to the centre of Rome is no problem. Crossing over the river from the via Trastevere there are lovely views up the river, all the attractions are within walking distance for people who enjoy walking. We even walked to the Vatican through the park where there were great views over the city. There are also buses along the via Trastevere across the river and to the train station. You can buy a bus pass for a reasonable price from the money you have saved on accomodation.Trastevere is probably best in the evening, along the banks of the river there are stalls selling snacks, drinks and other goods. In the side streets there are many small restauants and often street entertainment in some of the piazzas. The area is busy in the evening, it feels very safe, without being claustrophobic.On Sunday morning there is a big street market about half way along via Trastevere on the left out of town, a wide variety of new and used items, including clothes, at reasonable prices.

Trastevere: Rome nightlife. I'm a student of Fine Arts in Rome and just arrived in Rome I wanted to discover lively and funny places where to spend a night with my friends and meet other people from all over the world. I gave a look to an English website www.rome-explorer.com which is full of ideas if you are fond of art, jazz, music, good cooking and much more. I was looking for something dedicated to Trastevere and I found useful ideas and information about shopping streets (viale Trastevere), restaurants, hotels, entertainment places and nightclubs. I suggest you to take it into consideration if you want to spend a pleasant night in Trastevere.

True Roman Neighborhood-the Porta Portese market was the best. Trastevere (trass-tev-rAY) was one of my favorite experiences whilst in Rome; it was quieter than Vatican city and just as charming as Piazza Navona. On Sunday mornings, there is a huge outdoor flea market which sells absolutely everything; I am an avid coin collector and found the most amazing stuff for a fraction of the price for what I would pay in the US.Neighborhood corner markets selling produce, flowers and Italian spices; children playing soccer (football) on a grassy knoll, yelling in Italian. The Santa Maria Church is significant architecturally and historically, and worth a visit. It features the recycled remains of Roman columns.I hear this is a very fun area to wander for after-dinner drinks, but I came here during the day when it was sunny and dreamy.

A "must do " when in Rome. Put this place on your list of "must do's" in Rome. My Husband and I went at night as our hotel (The Forty Seven) was just over the bridge.This area feels more like a small Italian town rather than part of a capital city. We did not know really where to go so just wondered through the small streets which are lined with restaurants and café bars spilling out on to the street. There are not so many tourist here in my view which was nice.We found a bar which was dimly light with candles and was nicely full of locals. We had one or two! bottles of fantastic red and had a fantastic meal of very simple pasta which was also brill.I would definitely recommend coming here at night to soak up the true Roman atmosphere.

Wonderful place out of the hordes of tourists. Trastevere is close enough to the tourist attractions to walk (or hop a tram), yet it is out of the hordes of tourists. It is warm and inviting, and you feel like you are more a part of Rome.

What a neat place!. We stayed in a little apartment for a week and had the best time! We arrived just as the wild strawberries were making their appearance at dinner. We were able to wander into some very off-the-tourist-agenda places and after a few awkward moments of being appraised, were treated well. After dinner in the evening we sat around a large square where old men and women gossiped and children knocked around a soccer ball. I have never felt so relaxed. A truly REAL place.
